Patterns with a side of Y2K ğŸª©ğŸ©¶ğŸ’«
-
When exploring thrift shops, youâ€™re likely to find a variety of patterned clothing, like this dress I styled as a shirt, that always make me think about the fascinating history behind patterned textiles ğŸ¥¹ğŸ©·. We have many ancient textiles from Greece ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡· , China ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡³ , and Egypt ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¬ that show patterns created through weaving and dyeing techniques to produce geometric and floral designs. During the Middle Ages, there was significant development in intricate patterns, and during the Renaissance, the colonial trade further enriched these gorgeous designsğŸ“œ. Of course, the Industrial Revolution and technological advancements made digital printing more accessible. Itâ€™s fascinating to think that our earliest ancestors, who might not have liked todayâ€™s fashion, have influenced the way we style and wear things today! ğŸ©¶
-

Lately Iâ€™ve realised just how astonishingly beautiful life is. So much so, just the thought makes me want to cry. Itâ€™s a constant battle which flourishes into growth. & Iâ€™ve been feeling and seeing myself do so much growing every single day the past few weeks. my first 3 months of co-owning @thrift__mt ğŸ¥¹ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ğŸ§šğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸âœ¨ has been a whirlwind. A dream and a half. 2020 kelly is crying out of not believing I am actually living this exact life. Now donâ€™t get me wrong, if it has been anything, it definitely hasnâ€™t been all sunshines and rainbows. Itâ€™s been a lot of work, stress, anxiety, frustration and fixation. But at the same time, itâ€™s also been a lot of â€˜wowsâ€™, laughter, adventure, realisation that iâ€™m actually doing this, and understanding that I want nothing less than a life that fulfills me. A life of jumping off of cliffs to make things happen. & where I get my bread needs to be of purpose. Not just a way to make money. 
So, if I could give any of you reading this a suggestion, it would be to follow what makes you feel most alive as fearlessly and fiercely as humanly possible. Life is too short to spend it doing things that drain your energy and give you nothing but money in return. & make sure the energy youâ€™re surrounding yourself with is helping you be better than who you were yesterday, and not helping you stay cozy in your comfort zone because thereâ€™s only so much you can experience from thereğŸ§šğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸âœ¨ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼

& this isâ€¦ just the start.

How thrifting changed (or shaped) my life; a timelineğŸ§šğŸ¼

From being 5 years old, sorting through piles of clothes on a mat on the floor at the carboot sale in Marsascala and going home to give my mum a well-deserved try-on thrift haul in the kitchen of everything I would have managed to findğŸ¤£ 

To spending all my free time in between lessons at Junior College at Happy Paws charity shop where I would promise myself Iâ€™m not buying anything day in day out & would go home with bags of clothes.. day in day outğŸ¤“ miskina l-mummy

To deciding to share my first thrift haul on youtube that basically made me stick out like a sore thumb from most my age at that time because I wore â€˜usedâ€™ clothes.. but also started my journey as a content creatorğŸ™ˆ

To asking mum to teach me to sew as Covid struck - which led to me starting Thrifted District Vintage in 2020, where I reworked headbands, scrunchies and bags for breakfast, lunch and dinner ğŸ½ï¸ 

To renting my first office in Zurrieq & taking Thrifted District full-time, ending up deciding I need to go back to teaching and putting TDV aside, and spent my Saturdays running around charity shops & thrift store around Malta & compiling a thrift-map for anyone wanting to give thrifting a tryğŸ¥¹ğŸ’˜

To flying out to Cagliari with TDM Malta to give a sustainable fashion workshop with Zoe & a few weeks later to London with @greenie.mt on my first content trip where we went around charity/thrift shops & shot contentğŸ¥¹ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼âœ¨

To coming back to my job as a Teacher, and starting to work on reworks with Chris for @thrift__mt and a few weeks later deciding I was done pouring my energy in a job that wasnâ€™t giving me the same energy back & quitting my job as a teacherğŸ™ˆ & a few weeks later, went from re-working to co-owning @thrift__mt & now - here we are.

All the while, I was obviously styling my thrift finds 24/7ğŸ¥¹

Sometimes I wonder whether my purpose has anything to do with thrifting or whether thrifting is just a key that will lead me to my true purpose. All I know is that what made me â€˜weirdâ€™ growing up, slowly became my whole lifeğŸ¤ğŸ¥¹ 

So, please embrace what makes you â€˜weirdâ€™, it might just change your life.

Almost forgot about thisğŸ¤§ğŸ’« So, whilst the weather is still as uncertain as it gets & itâ€™s still windy, then hot, then rainy, then sunny all in a matter of minutes, here are 4 outfit ideas based on how I would style vintage Leviâ€™s (all from our shop @thrift__mt ) opting for a more overall over-sized lookğŸ’«âœ¨ Been loving the big pants, little top or little pants, big top combinationğŸ¥¹ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ğŸ’˜ Which outfit would you see yourself wearing?ğŸ¤“âœ¨

As you besties know, this summer I travelled to London with @greenie.mt ğŸ’« Since I had never been, I was ecstatic to explore itâ€™s thrift spots and markets, but together with that, I was met with the harsh reality of the large quantities of homeless individuals who make the streets of London their homeğŸ˜” I spent most of my 3 days there thinking how that could easily be any of us. Unfortunately, I feel that there is only so much we can do to help people in such circumstances get back on their feet, especially as tourists. But, one thing we can definitely do is to support places that in turn support rough sleepersğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ I think as tourists, it is inevitable that we are going to be shopping around in some way or another (especially if youâ€™re planning a Christmas holiday!)ğŸ¥°London is also flooded with charity shops - most of which, like Crisis, support people who are facing homelessness - all the while you are finding yourself your next thrifted treasureğŸ¤

& if youâ€™re heading to London, finding a Crisis charity shop is the easiest with 10 locations all around London. I would suggest you to look them up on google maps and finding which one is the closest to where you are heading, like Brick Lane or Camden Town where you will also find endless streets transformed into thrift markets of dreamsâ˜ï¸âœ¨ğŸ’«

Truth be told, thrifting is in my veinsâ¤ï¸

My sister & I were lucky enough to be brought up in a subconsciously sustainable household - where my motherâ€™s love for sewing and anything handmade blended with my fatherâ€™s love for vintage trinkets ğŸ—ï¸ 

Even though now as the mentality around thrifting is shifting, I still remember receiving messages from people who considered this hobby & love as something completely disgusting ğŸ˜… While everyone is entitled to their own opinion, I believe that embracing thrifting and sustainable living is not only an eco-friendly choice but also a way to express oneâ€™s unique style and creativity ğŸ«¶

On a personal level, our love for thrifting has brought my family closer together ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ‘§â€ğŸ‘§ Itâ€™s more than just shopping; itâ€™s about spending quality time together, sharing stories, and seeing what we can repurpose - especially now that we do not live together â¤ï¸

Honestly? I was a few tears away from crying throughout the whole SwapğŸ˜­ Just seeing everyone give away their no-longer needed clothes or accessories and other people falling in love with them was just top tierğŸ¥¹ Little Kelly is jumping up and down inside of me at the thought of not only thrifting & sharing it online but physically creating a space for others to engage in it tooğŸ¥²ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ğŸ¤ @zoelouwize thank you for being you on all levels girlieğŸ‘¯â€â™€ï¸ & thank you @tdmmalta for the amazingly beautiful experienceâœ¨

Honestly? I donâ€™t think I have ever felt so myself, as much as Iâ€™ve felt these few weeks aways from my home country. I love Malta in so many ways, but I cannot explain how free Iâ€™ve felt to truly figure out who Kelly is. 

Kelly who now can make full on conversations with strangers she meets at charity shops, or Kelly who hears a song and just starts dancing in the middle of a street without a worry of what people passing by might be thinking, or Kelly who actually feels indipendent and confident in doing what feels right in her heart. Get out of your comfort zone - whatever that looks like for you; maybe it could be going out more or taking a path youâ€™ve always wanted but always felt anxious just thinking about. Life is so beautiful when you feel yourself grow, and slowly starting to embody your highest selfğŸ¥¹ğŸ¤ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ Prague - youâ€™ve been amazing; now onto a weekend London before we get back to our routineâœˆï¸âœ¨

#praguegirls #minimalfashionideas #blackoutfitâš«ï¸ #secondhandshopper

Live from Prague (in my completely thrifted outfit.. including my bra haha)ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¿ğŸ¥¹âœ¨ I have so much to show you bestiessss about today (& things I bought!!!!), but until then, hereâ€™s a little video of me & my happy dance in Wenceclas SquareğŸ˜‚ğŸ€

#praguegirls #praguefashion #sustainablefashionista #minimaloutfits

â€˜â€™I donâ€™t want to thriftâ€™â€™ (and thatâ€™s okayğŸ«¶ğŸ¼) but you can still engage in sustainable fashion!ğŸ’– Girlie, your role is not to be perfect, but to be more informed so that you can buy and do better. 

Companies nowadays use a lot of marketing techniques to appear more sustainableâ€¦ But once you start to delve deeper, you realise things arenâ€™t as they are making them to beğŸ¤  

At Sardinia, we went to H&M and since we donâ€™t have it in Malta I thought Iâ€™d have a browse. The amount of clothes with cheap fabrics like polyster, nylon and conventional cotton was beyond me, and the prices were also stupid expensive for what youâ€™re getting.

Green-washing is obviously not your fault, but as your online bestieğŸ‘¯â€â™€ï¸, I donâ€™t want you falling into their trap; so hereâ€™s 4 things you can do instead -

1. Buy more sustainable fabrics like organic cotton, linen, wool and less unsustainable fabrics such as synthethic fabrics. Not only do they harm less but also last longer because of their durability.

2. Read clothing tags and be an informed buyer. Know what youâ€™re buying so that you understand how much the item will actually cost you in the long run (if youâ€™ll have to repurchase in a couple monthsâ€™ time because it wonâ€™t last) - you can also read about â€˜Cost per Useâ€™ğŸ¤ğŸ¼

3. Buy from actual sustainable brands like @plantfacedclothing , @veja , @been.london , and not fast-fashion corporations trying to â€œfixâ€ the harm theyâ€™ve caused and are still causing. It might cost more, but it will also last more, which will save you a lot of money over timeğŸ’…ğŸ¼

4. Donâ€™t buy if you donâ€™t really need toğŸ¥° Move towards a staple closet with a majority of minimal clothing and a few statement pieces so that you never feel like you â€˜â€™donâ€™t have anything to wearâ€™â€™ğŸ©·

& Donâ€™t feel overwhelmed. Weâ€™ve all been there, but now that you have internalised this information, try not to allow fast-fashion stores to consume you and start making more informed purchases. There is no one way of being a sustainable shopper. Youâ€™ve got this girlieğŸ€âœ¨

Throwing it back to my daily Sardinia outfit checksğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ğŸ’…ğŸ¼ I love documenting my outfits & seeing my style change & Iâ€™ve been pushing myself to do it more often!â˜ï¸ Currently, my style has become super minimal, scandi-inspired & I cannot start to explain how much my wardrobe is wardrobe-ingğŸ˜‚ I donâ€™t remember the last time I felt like â€˜I have nothing to wearâ€™ or super stressed about the outfit Iâ€™m wearingğŸ¤ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ + letâ€™s not forget how money-saving this is because even though I thrift most of my clothes, I donâ€™t ever feel the need to follow trends so my clothes last me years on end (hopefully a lifetime with correct careğŸ¥¹)ğŸ¤ğŸ«¶ğŸ¼ 

Which outfit was your favourite? Mine was the 4thğŸ€ğŸ‘¼ğŸ¼âœ¨

Werbung (wegen Markierung)

Der Rock ist super hochwertig und aus 100% Seide und ich kann gar nicht glauben, dass ich den einfach in einer Tauschbox gefunden habe und er somit umsonst war ğŸ«¶ğŸ» Die Ballerinas von @brunateofficial haben 10â‚¬ im Second Hand gekostet. Die Kette ist von @dior und ich habe sie auf Vinted fÃ¼r 150â‚¬ ergattert und die Tasche ist von @bvlgari und die hat meine Mama vor locker 20 Jahren selbst preloved gekauft und ich hab sie mir fÃ¼r die Fashion Week und geliehen âœ¨

Da sieht man mal, dass ein Outfit fÃ¼r so einen besonderen Anlass nicht unbedingt Ã¼bertrieben teuer oder neu sein muss ğŸ’« Wie gefÃ¤llt euch der Look? â¤ï¸

Hattet ihr schon BerÃ¼hrungspunkte mit dem Thema Minimalismus?

Meine Flohmarkt-Tipps fÃ¼r VerkÃ¤ufer ğŸ‘›
_____________________________________

Speichern nicht vergessen, falls ihr auch bald mal Flohmarkt machen wollt ğŸ«¶ğŸ»

1. Meldet euch rechtzeitig fÃ¼r einen Flohmarkt an, mittlerweile sind StandplÃ¤tze sehr beliebt, sodass man schnell sein muss bei der Anmeldung

2. Sortiert Kleidung aus, die zur aktuellen Saison passt - achtet darauf, dass die Kleidung gewaschen und bestenfalls gebÃ¼gelt ist 

3. Besorgt euch einen Tapeziertisch und/oder Kleiderstangen - gut sind auch Tischdecken fÃ¼r die Tische und wenn ihr habt einen leichten Spiegel

4. Wechselgeld - aus Erfahrung empfehle ich 40â‚¬ in MÃ¼nzen und 5â‚¬ Scheinen

5. Kleider und Blusen wÃ¼rde ich direkt zu Hause an BÃ¼gel hÃ¤ngen (am besten dÃ¼nne DrahtbÃ¼gel) und die Kleidung direkt in KleidersÃ¤cke hÃ¤ngen, damit ihr die Sachen einfach und sauber transportieren kÃ¶nnt 

6. Denkt unbedingt auch an ausreichend Proviant und GetrÃ¤nke fÃ¼r die Zeit und eventuell einen Campinghocker, falls ihr mal sitzen wollt

7. Eine praktische Tasche fÃ¼r euer Kleingeld ist sehr wichtig und auch ein warmes Outfit, ich hatte jetzt im MÃ¤rz sogar eine Skihose an, weil es ein Outdoor-Flohmarkt war 

8. Preistechnisch solltet ihr euch der Location anpassen, ich habe gestern beispielsweise im Schnitt 5â‚¬ fÃ¼r Pullis und Blusen bekommen und 10â‚¬ fÃ¼r Jacken bzw. MÃ¤ntel - bedenkt, dass die Leute handeln und setzt den Preis erstmal etwas teuerer an, aber auch nicht zu teuer, da ihr sonst auf den Sachen sitzen bleibt 

9. Vorsicht vor Dieben: Wertvolle Sachen in eurer NÃ¤he behalten, bei Schuhen erstmal nur einen hinstellen und den anderen im Auto behalten und die Kundschaft beobachten 

10. Have fun und scheut euch nicht, auch mal Nein zu sagen, wenn Leute frech oder unangemessen verhandeln

What is your favourite thing to do when youâ€™re scared about something? For me, that is to pretend ğŸ’­

Iâ€™ve never taken outfit pictures of myself outside before, even though Iâ€™ve wanted to for a long time. And since I donâ€™t have a garden, that means I had to go somewhere public to do so. I was really nervous, but as I walked out the door I pretended that I had already done this 100 times before and that it was a habit of mine. I WAS the girl that regularly takes pictures of herself in public without feeling embarrassed about it. To think this way made me feel more confident and it helped a lot! Sometimes, delulu is indeed the solulu ğŸ˜

Not to say that I wasnâ€™t nervous at all, and the pictures arenâ€™t perfect (I didnâ€™t even notice that I got some dirt on my coat while adjusting the camera ğŸ˜…), but when youâ€™re trying something new I always think that itâ€™s more important to just DO THE THING as opposed to getting it done perfectly. Thereâ€™s a common myth that making sustainable choices is always more time-consuming than its non-sustainable counterpart. For example, mending a worn-out shirt vs. buying a new one. But is it really true? ğŸ§

The other night I used my fabric shaver to restore the knit sweater Iâ€™m wearing in this post. It took me about an hour to shave the whole sweater. If I had instead thrown out the sweater and decided to buy a new one, it would have taken me AT LEAST one hour to go to the store, find a similar sweater I liked, try the sweater on and then make my way home again. Even if I would have bought the new sweater online, it would probably take as long as it did for me to shave my current sweater to find and pick one that I like. And then Iâ€™d have to wait for the sweater to be shipped and arrive at my house, which would have taken at least a day. Also, no matter if I wouldâ€™ve bought the new sweater in store or online, weâ€™d also have to take into account the time of the person sewing the sweater â³

No matter how you do the math, making the sustainable choice actually SAVES you time (and money) when it comes to taking care of your clothes. Then again, thereâ€™s a whole discussion to be had for if we really have to benefit personally from making sustainable choices to make them. But thatâ€™s a post for another day ğŸ˜‰

How are you taking care of the clothes you already own? â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹

caption:
Want to know a funny story about the t-shirt Iâ€™m wearing? ğŸ‘•

Well, funny may be an exaggeration. But itâ€™s one of my boyfriends old t-shirts that he wanted to give away. But as his girlfriend, I of course get first dibs on any clothing he doesnâ€™t want to wear anymore (and sometimes on clothes that he still wants to wear, but thatâ€™s another story ğŸ˜‚)!

I knew I didnâ€™t need any more t-shirts because that is my #1 clothing category according to my @whering__ app, but what I didnâ€™t have was any cropped t-shirtsâ€¦ One scissor and a couple of minutes later I had this cute, printed cropped t-shirt that can be worn as is or as a layering piece ğŸ’™

So what is the lesson here? Repurpose before anything else, I would say. Donating and recycling are very important practices to uphold a sustainable society, but as a consumer you also have a responsibility to make the most out of the things you own before passing them on to someone or somewhere else ğŸ¤

What are your best tips for repurposing clothes (or other items)? ğŸ’¡

Am I obsessed with these boots? Yes, yes I am ğŸ–¤

I was on the fence about chunky boots, or chunky shoes in general, for a looong time. The main reason is that I value comfort very highly in my choice of clothing, and I suspected that chunky shoes would make my feet feel heavy, and thus, uncomfortable. But now, I happily admit that I was wrong about that! ğŸ˜„ 

So what made me buy these boots in the first place? Well, Iâ€™ve been on the lookout for some knee-high boots for almost two years. But Iâ€™ve recently come to the conclusion that I donâ€™t like heels (the few heeled shoes I own are amongst my least-worn clothes). But I didnâ€™t want boots where the sole was flat on the ground either. Chunky boots seemed like a good middle ground and this made me willing to try them out. Plus Iâ€™ve always had a thing for 70â€™s/80â€™s platform boots, like the ones ABBA used to wear, and these ones are pretty close to that, right? ğŸ•º

Did you ever buy a clothing item that managed to surprise you? âœ¨

Read this before you declutter your wardrobe â€¼ï¸

Iâ€™m actually not a fan of the whole â€œdeclutteringâ€ trend going around social media right now, mainly because I see a lot of people decluttering a ton of their stuff only to buy all of it new again. This goes for clothes, decorative items, art supplies and a lot of other things. I think this is problematic because it ultimately fuels overconsumption and makes us less inclined to practice gratitude for the things we already own ğŸ™

Iâ€™m definitely guilty of engaging in the same cycle with my wardrobe in the past. This is why I try to only do one â€œbigâ€ declutter once a year, and even then I try to keep the item count small. I also ask myself these questions before I get rid of anything from my closet:

ğŸ‘— Why am I getting rid of this item (and is there a solution)? If the answer is simply â€œI donâ€™t wear itâ€ then the natural follow-up question is â€œWhy?â€. Maybe I need to style it differently. Maybe it needs to be tailored and/or mended. Most of the time there is an answer, and a solution, to the problem of not wearing a particular item. But if not, that begs the question ofâ€¦

â™»ï¸ Can it be repurposed? Maybe the fancy pants you bought for the office that have become worn out can now be wfh-pants? The permanently stained t-shirt can become sleepwear? The discoloured scarf can be cut up into wash cloths for cleaning? Anything that keeps clothing in your home, and thus out of landfills, is a win for the environment. But if the item in question is still in great shape, or you just really want it out of your house, itâ€™s time to ask the final questionâ€¦

â¤ï¸ Can you find it a new home? Sadly, a lot of the clothing we send to goodwill, second hand and vintage shops still run the risk of ending up in a landfill. Check with your friends, family, workmates and other acquaintances if they could use some of your decluttered clothes before sending them away. 

Let me know what you think about this! Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts about decluttering oneâ€™s wardrobe, and/or in general!ğŸ’¡

#slowfashion #sustainability #secondhandsverige #decluttering #sustainablefashion

Ten of my outfits last Summer. I easily could repeat each of them for tomorrow's theme 'signature style' in this week's style challenge by @noppans_bryderier.

Did you know? This account turned one year a couple of days ago! ğŸ¥°ğŸ‰

On march 3d to be exact, but I was sick at the time. But now Iâ€™m back, and I just want to say thank you to all of you lovely people that have decided to follow me on here since then ğŸ’• Iâ€™ve learned so much from the #slowfashion community here on Instagram, which has also led me to take a greater interest in #slowliving , as well as #sustainability overall! â™»ï¸

Some of you might not know this, but I am an active member of a Swedish political party called @miljopartiet and a board member of their local faction @miljopartiet_botkyrka . Starting and maintaining this account has definitely gone hand-in-hand with my political engagement, and will continue to do so. I see a lot of people on this platform who are worried about the future of humanity, all while feeling powerless and not knowing how to help. I would say that if you have the time and energy, try engaging in local politics! It is such an awesome feeling to surround yourself with people who want to help society in the same ways you do. You can get that from social media, of course, but I found it to be even more powerful to experience irl as well ğŸ’ª

Thank you again for your support, I hope you have a lovely day ğŸŒ¸

Couldn't leave this vintage wool coat from Scapa of Scotland. Such great quality and tailoring. I used to glance at the Scapa brand and collected the luxury paper lookbooks as a youngster (as well as those from Strenesse and AgnÃ¨s B). As a student in the late 90's I sometimes bought wool jackets and skirts from a similar style brand Josephine & Co in the sales. Not sure though if this Scapa jacket still is my style, even if Miuccia Prada recently decided that coats are getting more fitted. It's good to start with an inexpensive vintage quality jacket to find out if I'm ready for more fitted outerwear myself. I eventually will sell this red wool beauty further, but not yet.

Tried to get the vibes from Prada AW24 in my outfit this rainy Monday, day 1 of the #stylechallenge #allasecondhandfynden with @morecolourtothepeople. Today's theme is "all the skirts" and that's a easy one for me. I have an awfull lot of skirts in my closet ğŸ˜œ.

Good skirts are pretty easy to find in good shape 2nd hand (in my opinion). Don't look to much what the size tag says, try them on or ask the seller for the waist in cm. And try them with shoes, bc most skirts look a bit strange without, especially when You wrongly think that You're not a 'skirt person'. There is a skirt for every (wo)man, I promise! 

Secondhand jumper and bag, vintage wool skirt, about 6 year old coat Didriksons, Mary Jane shoes Vagabond last year.

A vintage LL.Bean chore jacket for #allasecondhandfynden  with @morecolourtothepeople. Today's theme is 'jackets'.
I bought this vintage jacket the day after Prada showed their oversized distressed canvas jackets for  AW24. I knew it would by a general  trend, but hadn't expect to see it so widespread. A lot of cheep (and expensive) fast fashion versions suddenly popping up everywhere, which felt so disappointing! 
However, after the 'storm' I happily still feel, more than a half a year later, that this kind of men's jackets suit me. 

Bought a new wool beanie in the best green hue Today! Made in Sweden ğŸ˜€.

My Black Friday sum up so far besides toileteries and Eborian makeup, cat litter,  cat food, panties, tights, fleece sweaters, fotbollsocks and some sportgear for my children. Still thinking about a stationy steamer and also looking for new earpods for my daughter.

Apperently my Instagram is broken according to all the emails I get from people who wants to fix it. ğŸ˜†

Well I donâ€™t remember dropping my account to the floor or abusing it in any other way. I kind of treated it the same way as always. 

The difference is time and COVID. When I started my account it was during the pandemic when people didnâ€™t have all that much to do and we bonded here and had so much more time to spend here. 
A lot of people went back to the normal life and donâ€™t have the same time to spend here. 

For me it is the same. I donâ€™t have the same amount of time to spend here. But I really love to post and communicate with those of us who still are here. I love to Spread awareness about sustainable style, normalising second hand outfits first or shopping in your closet. Sharing my knowledge about vintage and encourage you to find your personal style. So I share things here for me and for those of you who still see my posts. â¤ï¸

Thank you so much for being here! â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸

I hope you will have a fantastic day â¤ï¸

Confession of a thrift shopaholic. 

How I went from: I see it, I want it, I get it! To a more conscious thrift shopper. 

First of all I believe that it is easy to over-consume second hand clothes when you start going from fast fashion to second hand and that is all right. I think it is part of the process so donâ€™t feel bad when people who have come further in their slow fashion journey start to talk about overconsumption with second hand, you will get there too but if you are a beginner then letâ€™s just applaud that you have started to buy second hand first! â¤ï¸

I used to buy sooooo much clothes second hand and in the beginning I came home with so much that I ended up not using. I went from not finding anything cus I didnâ€™t know how to search to finding so much treasures that just screamed my name. All the clothes I didnâ€™t end up using gave me a guilty conscience. 

I then started to do like this: 
-first I take a basket when entering the store.
- I take everything I like and put it in the basket.
- I go to a less crowded part and go through all my finds. 
-do I need it? Will it work with my existing wardrobe? Can I come up with at least 3 different outfits with it?
-if itâ€™s a yes; then it goes down in my basket again and if itâ€™s a no I go back with it. 
-the things that have made it now has to be tried on or measured with a measuring tape. If it fits then it goes back to the basket if it doesnâ€™t fit I take it back. 
- if I have time I go to look at furniture and other sections of the thrift store. 
-I then go through the basket a last time and now I really have landed in what I want to buy so I keep the keepers and leave the other things in the store. 
-this takes time but I donâ€™t end up with things I donâ€™t end up using anymore. 

I also donâ€™t shop as much as I used too but that is beacuse I love what I have in my wardrobe and I am more picky with what I want to add. 

Do you recognise this? Where are you in your second hand journey?

Itâ€™s friday! Lets sparkle and shine! âœ¨âœ¨

I just love this dress from ROTATE that I found from @vinted I just feel instantly fantastic fabulous when I put it on. It is so comfortable and the colour is AMAZING! And the sparkle is fantastic too! 

@lisacaspani.slowfashion is writing about clothes being an armor and a mood changer and this dress is helping me cover up a really tired teacher who started her day crying beacuse she woke up early and had a dream that her co-workers where angry at her. It felt so real that my PMS mind convinced that it was the truth and I felt so useless. Woke my husband up and had him give me a big hug before I left the house. When I got to work everything was just fine and no one was angry with me. It turned out to be a great day and now I am enjoying a chai latte at one of my favourite cafes all by myself â˜ºï¸âœ¨

I hope you will have an amazing Friday â¤ï¸

I am amazed of all the support and kindness this corner of Instagram always gives. It was so refreshing to find a place where people actually are nice and threat each other with respect. 
I love the sisterhood and the women supporting women.
In the beginning of my account it was the pandemic so everything just happened online. But when you got to meet all these lovely and amazing people and they where just as kind as they where online I was so grateful. 

Every time I meet people from here I am amazed how genuine they are and how including. I have not come across any snobbery just kindness and love. 

Thursdays gala was a tribute to slow fashion but it was also a display on love, sisterhood and kindness. I hope you all felt just as included as I always feel. â¤ï¸

I love the slow fashion family! It is the best and you know what the best part is: there is always room for more. â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸

Thank you again @slowfashionhubstockholm and @clarionstockholm @ems.secondhand @vintage.vitalite @stinaloving you created magic! Thank you for all your hard work! â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸

ğŸ¤ The Slow fashion gala 2024 outfit. ğŸ¤

What I wore for @slowfashionhubstockholm and @clarionstockholm event: Slow fashion galan 2024

I went with an all white look for the gala. 
I found this broken tulle skirt when my local charity shop @rodakorsetsecondhand had a sale to make room for new things. It had so much tulle so I fell in love and bought it. When I thought about a gala outfit this skirt came up in my mind so I fixed it and made it wearable again. 

The next thing that came to my head was this epic bow from HM innovation. Found this via @sellpy and had used it before. It looked amazing with the skirt so now I just had to decided what to wear under it. 

I tried many different shirts but I always returned to the sequins shirt that I found at @myrorna.mastersamuelsgatan @myrorna 

Now I had to decide what shoes to wear and how to fix my hair. I tried many different shoes but I thought it looked best with these black boots that I found via @sellpy 
Since the shoes where black I knew I must add my hat from @hericane_thelabel

I added gold earrings from @vintage.vitalite and a gold braclet that I recently found @stadsmissionenssecondhandsthlm in SÃ¶dertÃ¤lje. 

So my look has elements that are repaired, reused, recycled, supporting a small business by two amazing women and with things from 3 different charity shops. ğŸ¤

I hope you will have an amazing day â¤ï¸â¤ï¸

We had a very early flight home this morning. It has been quite a tough couple of days due to circumstances, but we've tried to do some fun things too in between.

We choose to travel by airplane for the first time in more than one year (my third flight during the last 5 years), which is a pity bc I aimed for not flying at all under 2025.

I only went 100% #secondhandfirst as of January 2023, but preloved clothing was never a weird concept to me. Of course, when I was younger I didnâ€™t even know that â€œsecond handâ€ was a thing. For me it was normal to wear hand me downs from my mother, my sisters, relatives, friends or sometimes even the children of my parents friends. I could lie and say that it was because my family has always been extremely environmentally aware, but for the most part it was because of money. My parents worked really hard at jobs that donâ€™t always pay that well, so to buy new clothes for three girls who just kept growing was too expensive at times. 

I think thatâ€™s why the idea of buying and wearing clothes that have already been worn by someone else has never been a turn-off for me. I know some people still consider clothing that was previously worn by a complete stranger to be â€œickyâ€. But you know what else is icky? Having a person not even get paid a liveable wage to work overtime sewing everyday, just so that you can buy a brand new piece of clothing and feel on trend. 

If you struggle to adjust to buying second hand first, I would recommend the following:

ğŸ¤ Explore second hand clothing with someone who you trust and feel comfortable around. If they can wear it, so can you! 

ğŸ’¡ Look around for all the different ways to buy second hand. There are so many different ways to do so today and I guarantee that you will feel comfortable with at least one of them!

ğŸ™…â€â™€ï¸ Lastly, if you get really, REALLY turned off by buying second hand, I recommend to set a low-buy restriction on yourself for a month, 6 months or a year. Stop shopping for trends, buy only the absolute necessities and learn to love what you have (I will probably have to write a separate post on this one) 

How did you learn to buy #secondhandfirst ? ğŸŒ¸

My brain at 5am this morning.
Trying to write something with an overwhelmed brain thrinking about my full time work as a teacher 45h/week, writing a book, preparing the last jury work for the Slow Fashion Gala, my own company and still have time for my family. 

What to wear for the gala. Goals for my lessons. Anserwing mails for the book. What to plan for the substitute on Friday. Should I bring more clothes for the store in Stockholm. Did I wash the clothes my son and daughter need for the week? What do my son need for his baptism? Writing a presentation for the book. Planing my own lessons. 

I love all these parts of my life but at the moment there is a lot going on in every area so I am kind of tired but also very happy beacuse I look so much forward to the gala! It gives me so much joy writing this book. I love my work as a teacher and my students. I get so much love from them and my old students. My husband is amazing and does so much to help me. I am so glad my son wants to be part of an after school activity. I canâ€™t give my company so much time at the moment.

It is hard to find a good balance when you find joy in so many things and love being part of things and helping people. How do I use my energy right? I am a restless soul so I am not good at taking it easy. 

Can anyone relate? â¤ï¸

I hope you will have a fantastic day â¤ï¸

Just a tribute post to the coat I made.

When I saw this bedspread at my local charity shop I thought it would make a great coat. I looked at it but left it. When I returned to the charity shop a week later it was still there. So this time I bought it. 

I looked for coat inspo on Pinterest.  I then draw a coat and combined elements from several coats like puffy sleeves, a long coat, a long ribbon in the waist, large pockets. 

When I started to measure the fabric I realized that I had to shorten it to get wide sleeves and it wouldnâ€™t be enough fabric for the large puffy sleeves of my dreams. So I did some alternations to make the most of the fabric. 

I think it turned out so good and I am so happy with the result. 

I hope you will have a great Saturday â¤ï¸

The bedspread is bought from @rodakorsetsecondhand in Mariefred.

Since 2017 I have walked away from fast fashion and almost everything in my wardrobe is bought second hand. 

Since 2008 my interest in finding clothes second hand started. And my friends Hanna thought me how to find things in stores I used to find overwhelming. 

In about 1988 I remember that I got a dress who my bestie also had and I styled it with a belt. This is where the style interest started. 

Since about 1986 I started playing with my grannyâ€™s button jar and her left over fabric from work. She used to make clothes to our Barbie dolls. 

In 5:th grade everybody in school had a body in three different colours and with a flower print. It came in gray, maroon or dark blue. We also had heavy hair inspiration from Beverly Hills. 

In high school I started searching for my own style and I tried many different styles. I also found alternative rock and started dressing so that people would know my music taste by just looking at me. 

Style has always been a big part of my life and I love to express myself with my style. 

Well this post become a walk down memory lane. 

I hope you will have a fantastic day â¤ï¸

I am a big fotball/soccer fan and one of my favourite teams are @acmilan from Italy.

My dad has always been a huge sports fan so he spread his interest on to me and my sisters. Thought it was about time to let my curtain dress, I made out of a pair of old curtains, come out and play again. And I added pink wide pants and the macrame dress I made on top. 

Sometimes this is what I need in an outfit other times I go with totally different words. 

One thing I am totally sure of: no one on planet earth looked just like me yesterday. And for 99,9 precent of the population they are just thankful for that but 0,01 percent might see this as somewhat interesting. ğŸ˜‚

I kind of like the idea that I am all alone with this look. I am shouting out that I am unique and weird. I always felt weird and like I didnâ€™t fit in my whole life and now I am finally fine with not being everyoneâ€™s cup of tea. Because I am a unique coctail with colourful fruits and sparkle on top. I am more is more. I am a freak. I am a weirdo. And I do think I belong here. (Referents to the song creep beacuse always hear lyrics in my head)

I am actually glad when I donâ€™t look like everyone else and that is what I love about vintage fashion, sustainable and personal style, I get to be 100% me. 

I know unique styles is not for everyone and the amazing thing with second hand clothes is that whatever style you are going for you can find it second hand. Since trends go in cycles, beacuse the fast fashion companies wants to sell more new clothes so that one rich man can make more money, everything is already out there. So go search the second hand stores and hand pick items that will make your wardrobe more you. And donâ€™t give anymore of your money to that one rich man who apparently thinks he is superior to the people who, under slave like conditions , have to make his companies clothes. Thank you â¤ï¸

Yay! I feel so good beacuse I finally was abel to create something this weekend. 

I made this amazing coat out of an old bed spread I found at my local charity shop @rodakorsetsecondhand 

I just LOVE how it turned out. 

Gonna try to explain my creative process. 
When I found the fabric last week I thought about making a coat. But I was in a bad mood in the store and didnâ€™t end up buying anything. When I revisited the store one week later the fabric was still there and this time I bought it. 
I held it up and thought that the round corners would look amazing in front. 
I then went to Pinterest to find inspo and knew I wanted a long coat with puffy sleeves. I drew a model and figured out how to put a coat togeather and how many parts I would need. 
I also looked at my own coats to see how they were put togeather. 
Since I had the fabric I had I had to choose between a short coat with puffy sleeves or a longer coat without puffy sleeves. I went with the long option. 
Then I started to cut out the pieces I needed. 
I zigzagged the edges and then started putting pieces togeather. 
I had to decide if I wanted it to be light or a little bit darker. I went with the light version but had second thoughts all through the process ğŸ˜‚

I made sleeves and added pockets. I also made a really long belt. 

I am so glad that there was almost no left over fabric! ğŸ™Œ

I hope you like it. I made it with my pink Singer simple  from @singer_sverige

What you love to wear is much more important then what others may or may not think. 

I celebrate me each day I put on an outfit and it feels great. 

Yes I sometimes have been asked, where I am going, or if I am going to a masquerade, whatâ€™s the special occasion and so on. But that is just because I donâ€™t dress like everybody else. I do stand out in a crowd. 
But more often I actually get nice comments from people. 

Dare to wear what you love â¤ï¸

Have a fantastic Wednesday. â¤ï¸

caption:
Here are 7 random things about me: 

I am superstitious and have learnt a lot of these from my grandma. Not walking under laters, not putting keys on table, that in means bad luck if a black cat runs over the road and so on. 

Right now I am rewatching Gilmore Girls and I am on season 7. 

When I was little I used to pretend that I was Storm in x-men so that I could control the weather and fly! ğŸ™Œ

I really enjoy exploring new citys and I like walking around looking at old buildings and churchâ€™s. 

My nickname growing up was the living jukebox but it was supposed to be hurtful but I really always have loved singing so I didnâ€™t mind and I kept on singing. 

I have never learnt to eat coriander or drink coffee. 

Iâ€™m an alternative rocker but I have turned into someone who thinks: a good tune is a good tune and that usually is a song I can sing along too ğŸ˜

Do we have anyone of these in common? â¤ï¸

On the 29 th of April 2023 this skirt was first posted in a post in my feed. 

Since then I have worn it more then 12 times. 

What made this a good buy? 
It had a lot of elements I love in a good piece of clothing. 
It is vintage.
One of a kind.
In a fabulous green colour. 
In a really great model. 
And will work with a lot of my existing wardrobe. 

Before I bought it I created five looks with existing pieces of clothing in my wardrobe in my head. 

I have practiced buying second hand and vintage  clothing since before 2007 and since 2017 I have only been buying my clothes second hand. I know it takes time to learn how to buy second hand clothes. And even after all this time I still make a buy that I think will work but then it just get stuck in the wardrobe. And that is ok. If you are here for perfect I wonâ€™t fool you. Run fast away from my feed.
 I am a 43 year old teacher who am trying my best to spread awareness about sustainable style and slow fashion. I do it on my free time because I really enjoy it. This is not work for me. I donâ€™t make a penny or a Swedish krona on this account. But this account give me so much more then money ever will. 

I have found my sustainable tribe with a lot of loving and kind people from all over the globe and that gives me hope. â¤ï¸

Thank you for supporting me and for leaving nice encouraging comments, I really appreciate it and I really hope you want to continue to follow the slow journey of my fashion and style story. â¤ï¸

Happy Saturday all you lovely people. ğŸ’š

Thereâ€™s hope, thereâ€™s a silver lining! â¤ï¸

I hear a voice calling and it is telling me to choose a more sustainable life. 
To choose kindness both towards others and to myself. 
To lead with a good example. 
To be humble. 

I am not perfect but we donâ€™t need perfect. We need a lot of people doing good enough. Each step towards a more sustainable life is a huge win. 

Donâ€™t build a high fence around the sustainability concept, make it a small threshold with a large welcome sign! â¤ï¸

I might just be a shallow instagrammer sharing photos of my outfits on a daily basis but I do try to spread awareness and show people that sustainable style can be so much fun and personal. 

I hope you will have an amazing Monday.

caption:
One thing that is so liberating for me growing older and getting to know myself better is that I donâ€™t care how people look at me when I walk down the street. 

I am part of my own runway and I wear what makes me feel good on a daily basis. 

Me myself and I are the stylist and together with the mood of the day puts together an outfit. 

I love what I wear and I wear it with pride and it just feels so liberating and fun. 

I feel so much better when I love my outfit. It is my armour of the day. 

I used to look at envy with those who had the courage to have a personal style. One day I just decided that that can be me too. 

I started buying more clothes second hand and noticed that I felt so much better when I wore really colourful clothes. So here I am owning my own style and not caring if other people think it is too much. It might be for someone but certainly not for me! ğŸŒˆ

You can start today! What clothes in your wardrobe sparks extra joy for you? It is the sequins? The brown suit? The lace dress in white? The knitted rainbow cardigan? Start wearing more of those then and when you go to a second hand store to buy new clothes make them match the things in your wardrobe that sparks extra joy for you â¤ï¸

I hope you will have a magical Sunday â¤ï¸

Yesterdays outfit: 
ğŸ’š blazer from @myrorna 
ğŸ©µ dress from @sellpy

Many influencers I follow here on IG are last days talking about the transition of autumn into summer, which to me feels a little provocative when they are living in climates with higher temperatures atm than the warmest summer day in Sweden this year. 
Today and tomorrow promises with 24Â°C-26Â°C  to be one of the warmest this July-August in my place and therefor I don't want to talk Autumn yet. I chose a white skirt today and added a dress as a light coat. 
The whole outfit is secondhand except for the bag.

#secondhandfashion #secondhandifÃ¶rstahand #secondhandfirst #prelovedfashion #makesecondhandyourfirstchoice

Want to know a secret about this outfit? ğŸ”

The only thing bought second hand is the (barely visible) necklace from @rodakorsetmariatorget 
Everything else was bought at various fast-fashion chains. The blazer is the most recent purchase, and was bought mid-summer 2022. Why am I telling you this? Because I think it is important to know that you can start your sustainable fashion journey at any point in your life. I only went 100% second hand as of 2023, before that I bought some clothes new and others from second hand. But since I discovered that I can find everything I need second hand, and I also find it a much more fun and relaxing way to shop, I decided to stop shopping at other stores all together. And it has worked really well so far. 

Does that mean that I have to throw away all of my clothes that werenâ€™t bought second hand? No! That would be wasteful. The most sustainable clothes are the ones we already own, we just have to find new and better ways to use them instead of buying new things all the time. 

Are you buying second hand first? â™»ï¸ 

_________________________________________

Monday morning and the weather is nice!
@reinventionfashionist and I discussed the other day why we as fashion- and vintageinterests since we were youngsters in our midfourties are moving from a more ecclectic and retro style to modern. We both noticed we'd circulated further beautiful vintage pieces that we didn't wear anymore. I'll show some of my sold items in stories later today. I'm still looking for high quality vintage pieces (classic items can also be vintage) and they can be quite bold, but I'm leaning more to the 90's nowadays and, most important, I'm often sizing up. This crochet 70's vest still works for me if I combine it with  feminine and classic items. No retrofeeling here. No vintage style (hopefully).

The whole outfit is vintage/secondhand except for the bag and ring.

10K! Wohoo and thank you so much â¤ï¸

Itâ€™s been standing there for some days now but I patiently have been waiting to see if it will go down but I think I am finally here. â¤ï¸

Thank you so much for wanting to be here with me and for all the love and kindness you spread. â¤ï¸

This started as a covid account where I shared my outfits but never in a million years would I have thought that it would bring me friends from all over the world. And such kind and supportive friends. I am so greatful â¤ï¸

When I hang out here with you I get this amazing energy and it is so refreshing to hang out with people who genuinely straight other peoples crowns up and who want good things to happened to others. â¤ï¸

I hope you will have an amazing day and thank you so much again. â¤ï¸

Can't we just continue this summer life? 
Sunny weather (21-24Â°C) and blue skies but quite cold nights (14-16Â°C =good night sleep!) and some rain every 3rd-4th day make the perfect summer climate for me without AC. I can read a book in the sun on the beach, paint a window, go sightseeing, go for a walk or a bike tour, choose a workout in the shadow or go rollerblading.

Here is an really easy lace skirt remake. 

I used the left over curtain fabric that I took the ruffles from for another project. 

I used the existing channels and put an elastic band in both channels. 

I then measured how long I wanted the skirt to be and cut off the extra fabric. 

This is an easy fabric because you donâ€™t have to zigzag the edges. It took just one seam and then it was ready. 

I hope you liked the video and how the skirt turned out. â¤ï¸

Dressed for a meeting at another hospital first thing in the morning in an outfit inspired by Prada SS24, combining a distressed and oversized chore jacket with a feminine skirt and pointy heels. 
I already bought this mended vintage LL.Bean jacket a few days after the Prada SS24 show last Autum.  It's been repaired and cleaned by a little company specifically mending LL.Bean (Unfortunately, I didn't save the tag). This company  really was ahead, even of Prada! 
Ofcourse, as expected, Prada-inspired chore jackets are popping up everywhere on the high street atm. 
I'm happy with my vintage chore jacket (one newly produced does have as much environmental impact as 250 secondhand jackets), but I'm looking with a little envy at the leather collar of the jacket from COS...

Also miss my yellow linen skirt and a simple grey cashmere cardi. I'm not a fan of the limitations of a travel wardrobe more than for 5-6 days. The weather forecast was a bit colder than turned out, so I packed too heavy pieces that will not be used as frequently as expected (or not att all), like this denim blazer, my burgundy LL.Bean canvas coat and my long wide jeans. But last year it was the other way around, so I felt I had to prepare for colder weather this year.

I have always expressed myself with my style and clothes has always been important to me. In this post we revisit my teen era. 

Music defined me in my teens and I knew everything about my favourite musicians. I also picked out the album cover and learnt all lyrics by heart. 
Here are some more music facts for you ğŸ¶ 

1. I have two tattoos inspired by my favourite band the smashing pumpkins. 

2. My style icons growing up was: Debbie Harry, Shirley Manson, Gwen Stefani, Dâ€™arcy

3. I used to create mixed tapes with songs from the radio. We also swapped tapes with eachother. Bandit 105,5 rock â¤ï¸

4. I won tickets to a No Doubt show by phoning a radio station and singing No Doubts Hey You. 

5. I knew all the lines to the movie Empire Records because it was me and my friends favourite movie and we wanted to work in a record store. 

7. Here are some bands I have seen live:,Placebo, Smashing Pumpkins, Radiohead, Foo Fighters, hole, Ash, Weezer, the Hives, blur, magic numbers, the wannadies, Kent, the cure, muse

8. I was at Holes show at the Hultsfred festival and a young woman died in the audience at this show. 

9. Iâ€™ve been to these festivals: Arvika, Hultsfred, Roskilde, Fanclub, Where the action is. 

10. M-tv played the best music at night with Alternative Nation and Superrock. I used to stay up and watch those shows. 

Have clothes always been important to you? What did you listen to in your teens?

Woke up with a big need to be creative. 

Went to my local charity shop to find some fabric. I found an old curtain with a ruffle and I could see a top in my head. I also found some things for another project. 

When I got home I moved the sewing machine outside and also a TV so I could watch the Olympics. 

I made the top and I am really Happy with the result. I Will share it tomorrow. 

Today I might start with the other project. â˜ºï¸

I hope you will have a fantastic thursday.

#vintagefashion #smartyofsweden #smartydress #karinsklÃ¤nningsarkiv #506070tal #506070talsklÃ¤der #bookresearch #svensktdammode #vintagedetective #vintagedetektiv #clotheswithhistory

Call me the fabric whisperer! Or maby the curtain whisperer ğŸ˜‚

When I look at fabric at charity shops it has to speak to me in some way. If I had found this curtain as just fabric I would not have made this top. 
The ruffle is what made me buy it. And it was not a lot of fabric so I could only make a small top. Since my sewing skills are limited I have to find creative ways to close the garments I make. (No zippers or buttons just yet) Here I went with ribbons. 

I loved making the ribbons. I used a part of fabric that was left from the top. I folded them and used an iron to make them stay folded so I could sew them. 

I am really happy with the result and I hope you like it too! ğŸ’šğŸ’™ğŸ’š

I found the curtain at my local charity shop @rodakorsetsecondhand 

 My sewing machine is a Singer Simple 3223 @singer_sverige

One of the reasons why it is important for me to get dressed everyday is to celebrate the body that I have. 

I feel so much better when I get dressed. Here is a list of small acts that have helped me to be kinder to my body: 

- I never buy clothes that donâ€™t fit the body I have now.

- I follow accounts that are body positive because we come in all shapes and form and we are all beautiful. 

- I donâ€™t compare myself to others because my body is unique and what I got, so I work with it not against it. 

- I canâ€™t follow accounts that talk about losing weight and getting skinnier because that makes me question if these are things I should do too and it makes me question my body. This is something individual off course but for me it is not a good option. 

- thrifting means finding unique pieces and of the clothes donâ€™t fit I think: I wish it was larger so it would fit me. I donâ€™t think I wish I was skinnier so I would fit in it. 

- I battle unkind thoughts about my body and am reprogramming my brain to find beauty in what the beauty industry wants us to hate about our bodyâ€™s. 

- I am ageing so is my body. So I try to embrace the changes and learn to love them instead of seeing them as flaws. 

What do you do to be kind to yourself and your body?

I hope you will have an amazing day and remember that you are beautiful and unique â¤ï¸

Why I choose second hand first? 

- because of the environment. ğŸŒ 
There are already so much clothes produced to last for the six coming generations. Fast fashion is one of the worst environmental bad guys letting go of all that emission. And we donâ€™t even sell all the clothes thatâ€™s been produced. The clothes that are sent back are thrown away and end up in a dessert somewhere. Fast fashion companies are also destroying the land that their factory is at by the strong chemicals they use for colouring and so on. 

- because of human rights - ethical reasons. â¤ï¸
The people who make the clothes for fast fashion companies donâ€™t even have a living wage. They have horrible working conditions and are abused. Women who work donâ€™t use the restroom because they are afraid of being raped. They work long hours and still canâ€™t afford a house, food and medical help. They are the modern slaves and this has to stop. The fast fashion companies makes so much money. I know they offer a lot of money to influencers so why donâ€™t they use all that money to raise the wages for their workers? I have been offered 1000 dollars by posts from some companies and they are villing to send me a lot of clothes. Swipe for screenshot of two of the mails. 

- because of creative and personal reasons. ğŸŒˆ
I love searching for treasures in thrift stores and I love how it has developed my style. It is a creative process and I feel amazing. So my style has actually made me feel better. I love searching for unique pieces. 

Why do you choose second hand first? 

I hope you will have an amazing Monday! â¤ï¸

Spent another day at the amazing Gripsholms castle. 
In 1537 they started building this castle. It was Gustav Vasa who wanted it to be built. Now the castle holds the largest collection of portraits and the famous stuffed animal -  Leo the lion. 

1. Me at the castle in front of some of the paintings. 
2. Walking in to the first court yard. 
3. One of the towers - the Vasa tower.
4. Mandatory group shot in front of pointing picture. 
5. The castle through a window. 
6. Group shot in old mirror. 
7. The famous stuffed animal - Leo the Lion, he has his own merch. 
8. Peter and his doppelganger 
9. Waiting for the others. 
10. One of my favourite paintings at the castle. 

This is just one of the royal castle you can visit when you are in Sweden @kungligaslotten 

I hope you will have an amazing Friday.â¤ï¸

Ugo Correani is one of fashion jewelry's best-kept secrets. For two decades, starting in 1973, the Rome-born designer worked behind the scenes from his humble Milan atelier for some of the industry's biggest names, including Chanel, Versace, Valentino and Christian Lacroix.

So I saw this reel where the clothes flew in and then got attached to the person. I saved it and thought about how I could create something similar. Love a creative challenge! 

I first tried to do an overlay in CapeCut but you had to have a pay version to use the effect that I wanted to use. 

I then tried it in Pics Art and I found that when I added a photo and removed the background I could create an effect and make the piece of clothing â€œflyâ€. 

The film is a really long clip of me standing in the same place and adding on layers. 

Start the camera.
Stand still.
Reach for the blouse and try not to move my feet and then put it on.
Stand still for a while. 
Reach for the skirt and put it on. Stand still for a while and so on. 

The total clip of my doing this is 3 minutes and 8 seconds. I then made that long clip in to short clips that I wanted to use. 

I first tried filming the objects and then adding them. In capecut you can remove the background on film but I couldnâ€™t get it to remove and keep the right pieces. In Picsart I couldnâ€™t remove the backgrounds on films but on photos. So I took seperate photos of all the items and then added them to the clip where I wanted them. I then put them all togeather and made this 10 second short clip. 

I really hope you like it. â¤ï¸

If you take the old way from SÃ¶dertÃ¤lje to Mariefred you will pass by Qvartinge antik. @qvartingeantik 
It is a big barn who has antiquates and second hand on two floors. 
They have most home decor and furniture but also some clothes, books and other stuff. 

They are open Saturday and Sunday 11-15

We make at least one visit her a year. I just love going through all their treasures. 

They also have a cafe. 
You canâ€™t bring dogs or a stroller here. 

You donâ€™t have to buy new. It is way more personal to find your indoor decorations second hand. â¤ï¸

My feed before and after the 10th of may. 

I just had to make this reel Since it looks like I am living in my hat but I am here to let you know this and contradict some of the rumours going around: 

- no I donâ€™t sleep with the hat on. 
- people have seen me leave my house without the hat but they just havenâ€™t got any good photos of it. 
- I didnâ€™t cry when the hat blew off my head and almost ended up on the car road, it was just a strong wind tearing up my eyes. 
- I havenâ€™t written a love song to the hat. 
- the hat doesnâ€™t watch TV with me. 
- I havenâ€™t named the hat cuz there is not a perfect name for such a perfect hat not because I donâ€™t want to ğŸ˜‚
- the hat hasnâ€™t had any effect on my sense of humour it is just as bad as ever ğŸ˜‚

I hope you appreciate my bad sense of humour and enjoy my new hat approved feed. 

Happy Sunday all you lovely people. â¤ï¸

Second Hand September was launched by @oxfamgb back in 2019. Itâ€™s a campaign that seeks to encourage people to buy only second-hand items for one month. Itâ€™s a great opportunity to try out second-hand for the first time or refocus your efforts and reflect on your existing shopping habits. Whether you pledge to take part for the whole month or give second-hand a go just once, youâ€™d become part of a growing movement of people shopping preloved over new. 

Iâ€™ll be sharing tips all month, so follow for more, but hereâ€™s some ideas to get started for the first time thrifters and the experts among us!

Itâ€™s a fact that we all need clothes. Not just for function but as a way to express ourselves and build connections. Fashion shapes culture, identity and adds to our sense of community âœ¨ But if what we wear comes at the expense of underpaid garment workers or environmental destruction, is it really worth it?

Sustainable fashion isnâ€™t just about eco-friendly fabrics or thrifting (though we love both! ğŸ’•); itâ€™s also about ensuring that the people who make our clothes, work in safe conditions and are paid fairly. Itâ€™s about making mindful decisions and knowing the impact of our shopping habits.

Because no outfit should come at the cost of someone elseâ€™s well-being. When we choose better and invest our money in fashion that respects both people and the planet, weâ€™re not just dressing ourselves - weâ€™re shaping a future where fashion benefits everyone, not just a few.

Sustainability is NOT about buying eco-friendly products, but itâ€™s about reducing overall consumption and waste. By making intentional choices about what you buy, what we wear and the companies we give our hard earned money to, you can make a big impact on both the industry and the environment ğŸŒ¿âœ¨ğŸ¤

#sustainablefashion #consciousconsumerism #sustainableliving #ethicalfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #ecofriendly

As we step into 2025, how about making a collective New Yearâ€™s resolution to embrace more mindful shopping habits and the impact our clothes have on the planet, the people who made it, and even your own sense of fulfilment ğŸ–¤ Here are some easy steps to support sustainable fashion, that wonâ€™t affect your budget:

1. Think Before You Buy: Before making a purchase, pause and reflect. Does this item truly add value beyond the initial excitement?

2. Take Good Care of Your Clothes: Extend the lifespan of your wardrobe by learning proper care techniques for different fabrics and considering repair services when needed.

3. Think Circular: Embrace a circular economy by shopping secondhand, upcycling, or repairing items instead of discarding them. This approach reduces waste and conserves resources. 

4. Shop Consciously: Support brands dedicated to sustainability and slow fashion. Seek out quality materials, zero-waste policies, and efforts to reduce environmental impact.

5. Shop Less, But Better: Resist the allure of fast fashion bargains. Invest in pieces that align with your values and are designed to last beyond a single season.

6. Donate or Resell: Give your pre-loved items a new life by donating to charity or selling them through resale platforms.

Remember, low prices often come with hidden ethical costs. Be mindful of the human and environmental impact behind steep discounts. Choose ethical brands that prioritize fair labor practices and sustainability.

Whatâ€™s your top sustainable fashion resolution for 2025? Share below - Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts! âœ¨

On Monday we had a trip to @londonmuseumofwaterandsteam in Brentford which was fabulous. I am a huge fan of the grandeur of Victorian engineering and this place did not disappoint. It is also really geared up for kids too with lots of childrenâ€™s activities including a miniature steam railway.

Finally â€˜Authenticâ€™ in Kelvinbridge next to Retroâ€¦ itâ€™s run by a lovely couple who have such a good eye for vintage homeware as well as a large selection of vintage suede shearlings and knitwear.

Coming up to Christmas the shop gets pretty busy, on top of that I had a cold so I needed to pace myself and to me this means curling up on the sofa in the evenings with hand stitching. 
This latest little frock is something Iâ€™ve been meaning to make for a while since I found this lovely denim remnant in a charity shop a couple of years ago. I used one of my favourite patterns from the Japanese Sweet Dress Book. Since I discovered this book I have made several versions in many different fabrics. The only adjustment I made this time was to the armholes.
I decorated the tucks with feather stitch, one of my favourite embroidery stitches. Due to the lack of fabric I had to have a seam down the back so I made this into a faux button back with appliquÃ© and running stitches. The pockets were also decorated with appliquÃ© and running stitches.
The neck and armholes are bound in black gingham (from a thrifted shirt)
The tartan slacks were thrifted many years ago.
The shoes are by Fly Londonâ€¦a Christmas present from Pete

Greetings from my sewing roomâ€¦itâ€™s my birthday but sadly we changed our plans due to the weather but every cloud has a silver lining so itâ€™s meant a bit more time stitching. 
As itâ€™s also the new year I thought Iâ€™d show you what I will be working on over the next few monthsâ€¦but as you know these plans might change depending on what ideas or fabrics I come across. 
I had two wonderful new books as gifts, Soulful Stitch by @deenabeverley and @casholmestextiles and Forage & Stitch by @artistcaz I canâ€™t wait to delve into these over the next few weeks.
I am also starting on a jacket transformation projectâ€¦more of that later.
On the knitting front I am knitting an Outlander style shawl from a free pattern from @regnmia 
On the sewing front I found these two wonderful old Sanderson curtains last year, they will probably end up as frocks but I havenâ€™t got any farther with that yet. The other fabric is a very soft brushed cotton that is being made into a cosy winter petticoat which will be embellished with lace and embroidery.
Todayâ€™s pinafore is made from a 1960s curtain, worn over embroidered jeans and a thrifted cashmere sweater I dyed yellow.
Whatever your creative plans are for 2025 I hope you have a lot of fun.
#sewover50 #sewover50jan #sewingplans #curtainstocouture #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #sustainablefashion #sewinginspiration #newyearplans #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyoulove #mysewingroom #handstitching #handknitting #ageismisneverinstyle

In support of @curtainstocouture I thought I would show you a pinafore, my own pattern,  that I made from a vintage Sanderson loose cover that I persuaded @justjillrosalind to let me have. Secondly I wanted to share the joy of embellishing thrifted items, in this case a pair of denim jeans. You can turn a very basic utilitarian garment into something really rather nice that you will enjoy for many years.
One of the things about making clothes from used textiles is that you often have to piece bits together, it is not as simple as cutting out from a large piece of fabricâ€¦but in my opinion much more satisfying. The bindings on the pinafore are made from a thrifted cotton shirt.
As you may have noticed I love embroidering and applying appliquÃ© to my clothes, I love both the results and the process. Denim is a really lovely fabric to embroider as it is nice and firmâ€¦but donâ€™t choose one with a lot of Lycra in it. I have included a couple of closeups of the embroidery.
The necklaces I made from old broken beads and trinkets collected over the years.
I bought the cardigan from my friendâ€¦thank you Jill.
Thank you for posting your pictures of what you are making from upcycled textiles. Donâ€™t forget to use the hashtag #curtainstocouturejanuary so we can find your posts for #followerfriday and also enter you into our fabric giveaway.
#sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #fastfashionsucks #slowfashionmovement #slowfashion #upcycledfashion #sewover50 #sewover50january #ageismisneverinstyle #ilookmyage #grannychic #oldladystyle

Sustainability Sunday. In spite of the name, here at Curtains to Couture HQ we donâ€™t only sew with old curtains, so I thought I would show you some of the clothes we have made from various other old textiles.
This is just a selection and I have marked each picture with what it is made of.
We all love a cotton tablecloth, particularly gingham or embroidered, they make such pretty summer frocks and because they have been laundered regularly they are generally lovely and soft.
Another great source of fabric is the duvet cover. These days many of these are made of poly cotton but if you can hunt down the cotton or brushed cotton ones I would recommend you snap them up. As well as these making cosy frocks and jackets I personally use the brushed cotton or flannelette ones to make petticoats and line winter clothes. If you can find king size there is just so much fabric.
I know there are some people who think old quilts should not be cut up but in my opinion giving them a new life is a brilliant ideaâ€¦ otherwise these can just be stored away in cupboards which is such a waste.
Another beautiful fabric is old ticking, this is generally striped and was used to cover mattresses or pillows, it has a tight weave so the feathers would not poke through. This is really nice for frocks and summer coats.
Lisa @vintage_dahling also made an amazing garment, made from a feed sackâ€¦just remember nothing is off limits.
There are also a number of makers on IG doing amazing things with vintage tea towels.
Apart from all of these amazing soft furnishings there are always remnants to be found, large and small which can be incorporated into our wardrobes. Another way to reuse old fabrics is rework garments you find in charity shopsâ€¦if itâ€™s nice fabric you can always find a use for it.
In the next couple of days we will be launching our January challenge so stay tuned and thank you for your continued support
Marcia xxxx

Iâ€™ve now finished in the shop after a brilliant week and my cold is clearing up so Iâ€™m currently in a good place. 
Today I wanted to show you a couple of winter clothes Iâ€™ve made from thrifted brushed cotton duvet sets. Back in the day we would buy sheets and blankets and they would be used until they fell apart. Now it seems that duvet covers are replaced quite frequently resulting in many sets turning up in charity shops. Unfortunately many of them are poly cotton but there are still many good quality ones out there waiting to be upcycled.
I made this frock several years ago from a king size brushed cotton duvet cover and pillow cases, there was even enough left to make a little coat. The pattern is a vintage McCalls 7917 designed by Laura Ashley.
The coat I made last year again from a couple of duvet covers, one for the lining and one for the main fabric. Again it was a vintage pattern, Style 2410.
Both of these garments are so cosy and perfect now itâ€™s turned a bit cooler.
We had a bracing walk in Woodbridge today, which apparently is the happiest place to live in the UKâ€¦not entirely sure how they decide this. Anyway it was looking beautiful today so I have included a few pictures.

There has been a flurry of new followers recently asking about my shopâ€¦so here it is. 
I had wanted an antique shop for many years and eight years ago, after retiring from my proper sensible job, I threw caution to the wind and opened Smoking Monkey Antiques in my adopted town of Bury St Edmunds. I wanted to create the kind of shop that was not predictable, somewhere that would always surpriseâ€¦the kind of shop I enjoy finding when on my travels.
We are lucky to have some very loyal customers as well as many visitors from all over the world. Now it is established I can never imagine it closing so I will continue to work until I physically canâ€™tâ€¦hopefully at least another ten years.

Red flannel petticoat and blue linen pinafore both hand made by me.

@slowfashionchallenge Day 9, lace details, so for me today is all about showing your petticoatsâ€¦or â€œCharlieâ€™s deadâ€ as people used to shout at me.
As you may have noticed there is generally a petticoat or a pair of embroidered jeans showing under my frocks. I have petticoats in different weights of fabric from fine cotton to flannelette depending on the weatherâ€¦but they must always have a lace trim.
Todayâ€™s petticoat is made from two old heavy cotton pillowcases, I dyed them yellow together with some broderie anglaise lace. Basically the skirt is one pillowcase and the frill is made from the other. I ran elastic through the top, added a bit of feather stitch, a few appropriate words and some narrow ribbonâ€¦and you have a winter weight petticoat.

About a month ago I posted with my Christmas frock plansâ€¦well itâ€™s finished. My inspiration was a frock I found on Pinterest but being a practical kind of girl I wanted something that can be worn all year round for any occasion.
I wanted fullness without the bulk so I chose this beautiful shaped pattern from @cottonandchalk and cut the skirt into strips then stitched together so you get the layered look without the bulk. I then hand stitched cotton lace onto the seams. I added patch pockets and a little button detail to the front bodice.
Fabric wise, this is all from my stash, the gingham is an old tablecloth, a piece of vintage Laura Ashley cotton left over from a project, and the bindings are an old shirt.
The petticoat is a piece of lace I found in a charity shop many years ago. As itâ€™s cold I wore it over my usual flannel one.

Today seemed an appropriate day to talk about rainwear again. I am now in the shop and I can confirm this mac really does keep you dry all over.
A few years ago I decided I needed a really nice big raincoat and the only one I could find that I liked was Â£600. 
I was lucky to find some deadstock red waxed cotton on EBay for very little money and I used this vintage Style 2410 pattern. I deliberately made it very roomy to accommodate winter layers.
I was very nervous about using waxed cotton but I took my time and it was nowhere near as tricky as I thought it would be.
I recently washed it using a special solution I found in Seasalt and it cleaned well and it retained its waterproof qualities.
I am not expecting many customers today so I have brought my Christmas cards to write.

@slowfashionchallenge Day 8 Fabric Focus
I love fabric and my sewing really is fabric led. As I very seldom buy new fabric I canâ€™t be fussy about the sizes of the pieces I buy so I have developed ways of squeezing pinafores out of the smallest of pieces. I mainly buy old curtains, bed linen or old remnants. These I find in charity shops, vintage fairs and I have a friend called @justjillrosalind if you know you know. 
However you are often left with lots of small pieces and as they are far too pretty to waste the answer has to be a patchwork frock. Some of the pieces in this frock I have had for many years. The bodice was made from a linen frock that no longer fit.
As you can see it is an all weather pinafore, the left hand picture was taken today at Petworth and the warmer looking one was taken over the summer. The second picture shows all three of my patchwork frocksâ€¦I havenâ€™t ruled out another one.

@slowfashionchallenge Day 12, Shopping Advice
As you know I make most of my clothes from old fabrics, often from existing garments I find in charity shops. 
When I am in charity shops or vintage markets I tend to look at the fabrics rather than the actual garments. An example of this is my green needlecord jacket. I fell in love with the soft green fabric but was not keen on the style of the tunic.
The answer was to cut down the front, shorten just below the pockets and use the excess to create the front bandsâ€¦and you end up with a jacket that has already had several outings.
Another bit of advice is donâ€™t go charity shopping for specific things, keep an open mind and you never know what treasures you might find. Everyone is a winnerâ€¦you have something lovely, the charity gets much needed funds and you have saved something from landfill.
#slowfashionchallengenov24 #curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewover50november24 #upcycledfashion #upcycledclothing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #sustainablestyle #dopaminedressing #dopaminestyle #ageismisneverinstyle #ilookmyage #grannychic #oldladystyle #kawaii

This is a simple pinafore I made earlier this year and as you can see it really is a frock for all seasons. It is made from an old gingham tablecloth and a couple of remnants from my stash. It is one of those frocks I just made up as I went along.
One of the reasons I make pinafores is because they are so easy to adapt to any weather. In the summer you just add a tee shirt and cotton petticoat and in the winter a sweater and flannel petticoat keep out the chills.
As you probably guessed the middle picture was yesterday morning. Yesterday I teamed it with a thrifted black cashmere polo neck sweater, red flannel petticoat, secondhand tweed jacket and the shawl I knit several years agoâ€¦and of course a red beret.
I think red is just one of those colours that feels good  in any weather, and I think it is particularly good on cold dull days.

@slowfashionchallenge Day 14, sustainable quote.
OK, so you might be wondering why this concept would affect sustainability. 
Particularly since the rise of social media which can really play on our insecurities, we are continually being told we would be happier if we looked different or wore different clothes. As a result of this we spend a lot of money on beauty products, treatments and fashionable clothes, and this is an ongoing thing producing a lot of waste and pollution. The sad thing is this will not result in happiness just depleted bank accounts. 
The sustainable way forward is to accept yourself, develop your own style and look, donâ€™t be a poor imitation of someone elseâ€¦just be yourself.
Self love and self acceptance is definitely the way forward. I so wished Iâ€™d learned this lesson earlier in my life.
A huge thank you to the organisers of the Slow Fashion Challenge, Iâ€™ve learnt stuff, met new people and had fun.
I knit the cardigan from a bag of thrifted yarnâ€¦and itâ€™s so cosy.
I made the frock many years ago from vintage Laura Ashley fabric. 
Petticoat is made from red flannelette
