@slowfashionchallenge Day 11 National Recycling Week. Itâ€™s not just fast fashion that causes a lot of textile waste, it is also bedding, sheets and duvet covers. When I was young everyone bought white linen or cotton sheets and pillowcases and these were used until they completely wore outâ€¦often being mended along the way. However in the 1960s, coinciding with the increasing popularity of the duvet, bedding became a fashion thing. Nowadays most people change their sheets and duvet covers very frequently and as a consequence of this you will always find bedding in charity shops. Unfortunately a lot of this is polyester and frankly not very nice.
So, why am I standing here in my winter coat?
I often buy cotton duvet covers in charity shops, they are generally very cheap and there is loads of fabric waiting to be recycled. My winter coat was made from two flannelette duvet covers, one for the outside and another one for the liningâ€¦you would not believe how cosy it is.
The other pictures are a coat and dress both made from a king size duvet cover and pillow cases.
We hear a lot about fast fashion textile waste but this change in the way we buy bedding is very rarely mentioned yet it produces a lot of waste that ends up in landfill.

No greenwashing bulls***t here 

Hereâ€™s part 2 of a popular reel I did a few weeks ago sharing some of my favourite small, sustainable, slow fashion brands. Thereâ€™s so much greenwashing going on at the moment with high street and fast fashion brands so I wanted to continue to shine a light on some brands who do things a bit differently. These brands reuse existing materials, source them sustainably and offer customers made to order on their products to reduce waste (I always think that good things are worth the wait!). I think â€˜made to orderâ€™ is the theme of this part 2 as pretty much all of these brands work on this system. 

A quick brand summary: @kindredofireland is quite a new brand to me, they make the most incredible locally sourced linen pieces, this amazing rainbow stripe set was created specific to my measurements and I couldnâ€™t be happier with it.

I absolutely adore Maria at @gingham_palace we met last year at her London pop up and sheâ€™s such a lovely, incredible lady. The brand is Spanish and makes iconic cotton PJ sets (which you can absolutely wear out too) and her new bow shirts and summer sets look amazing too.

@stalf.studio I adore Paris and her brand Stalf. Think easy, comfy basics which go with everything in your wardrobe. The designs are simple, materials luxurious  and made to such high quality.  I love the little design details like the flutes sleeves on this top which gives it a touch of something special. 

@upfromadream_ Olivia creates the most beautiful, girly, floral, floaty dresses of my dreams and Iâ€™m so happy I got one of these in one of her recent drops. She uses deadstock/vintage materials and I love the puffy sleeves and it has pockets of course!

Finally @lillian.greenough is definitely for the animal and knitwear lovers. I love her nature themed designs and she knitted this whale knit at impressive speed! It is super luxurious, 100% wool and the craftsmanship is spectacular! 

Light and dark wash denim trousers are @_beyond_nine

#slowfashionchallengenov2024 day 2, 30 wears. I enjoyed scrolling through the introductions yesterday, it was good to see familiar faces and many new to me. 
I donâ€™t tend to make clothes for specific occasions, I find this puts me under pressure and the fun goes out of the window. Often these special frocks are worn once then languish in the wardrobe. However, this frock was made for an occasion, the reopening of the shop after the first Covid lockdown and as you can see it has not languished in my closet. This is the frock I reach for on so many mornings, it lifts my spirits and makes me feel good.
As you can see itâ€™s an all round year frock which I find very satisfactory.
It was made from a pair of 1970s curtains and some thrifted gingham. You have no idea how many people tell me their mum used to have these curtains. There isnâ€™t a pattern for this frock, like many of my clothes I made it up as I went along.
Today I am wearing it with a thrifted tweed jacket that I bought about twenty years agoâ€¦again I must have worn this a lot over the years. 
@slowfashionchallenge #sewover50 #sewover50november #so50reworn #upcycledfashion #slowfashion #sustainablefashion #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #curtainstocouture #kawaii #oldladystyle #ageismisneverinstyle

#slowfashionchallengenov24 Days 2&3, life cycle check and the art of layering. As I was very busy yesterday spending time with family I am combining them both in one post.
As the majority of things I wear are not new when I find them I am never quite sure what their story is. I try to buy natural fibres, these are nicer to wear and better for the environment but often, you cannot be certain as labels are missingâ€¦I like to think that I am rescuing unwanted garments and fabrics and giving them another chance. As there are already so many unwanted textiles languishing out there it just seems the right thing to do.
I love layeringâ€¦some may call it an obsession but I get a great deal of pleasure getting dressed every dayâ€¦playing with colours, textures and patterns. I appreciate that living in the UK is probably the ideal climate for this type of dressingâ€¦not too hot and not too cold.
The boots are a recent secondhand buy from EBay.
Petticoat is made from two thrifted pillowcases, dyed yellow and embroidered.
Pinafore is from a piece of vintage brushed cotton.
Sweater is made from a thrifted remnant of a printed knitted fabric.
The coat is made from a piece of 1960s cotton velvetâ€¦definitely one of my most worn pieces.
The scarf is made from a worn out tee shirt.
I see no reason why these garments will not continue to be worn and enjoyed by me.

Just thought Iâ€™d show you what I will be working on for the next few weeks. There are some wonderful tartan creations to be found on Pinterest and Instagram so I thought Iâ€™d make myself one for Christmasâ€¦and beyond.
I really like the way tartans can be mixed with ginghams and other fabrics, so inspired I thought Iâ€™d put my own slant on that idea and make a festive pinafore.
I wanted fullness without lots of gathers so Iâ€™m using Cotton & chalk pattern no.10 which gives you width at the bottom and a great flareâ€¦over 3 metres at the hem. The skirt is in five horizontal panels and the bodice will be tartan with some kind of frill and button band down the front. All of the seams will be covered in narrow cream cotton lace which I will stitch on by hand.
This is a work in progress and I am not completely sure how it will end upâ€¦but I know I will have fun and hopefully it will be ready for Christmas.
All of the fabrics are secondhand and were in my stash so itâ€™s a nice economical make.
#sewover50 #sewover50october24 #sewingplans #workinprogress #recreatethelook #christmasfrock #tartandress #christmasdress #slowsewing #kawaii #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatyoulove

Following on from yesterdayâ€™s autumn beret we have even more pom-poms, this time itâ€™s the seasonal wreath I made for the shop.
I love making pom-poms, it is very satisfying and it is something to do with all those odd bits of yarn we seem to end up with. I use a plastic pom-pom maker which is significantly quicker than the old fashioned cardboard method. I bought several of these metal frames many years ago but you can always use an old metal coat hanger formed into a circle.
When you have cut your yarn after you have finished winding, leave several inches of yarn when you tie around the middle as you will use this to tie them onto your frame. You can then add whatever takes your fancy, I used a big bow and a few foraged acorn cups.
This one will now stay up until I get the Christmas pom-pom wreath out.
Todayâ€™s frock is my autumn patchwork one, worn with thrifted striped sweater and cardigan.

I enjoyed wearing the cardigan so much I decided recreate it using the green yarn and this is the result. I know this is going to get a lot of wear once it turns colderâ€¦plenty of room for layering!
It is an Aran weight yarn and I used 5.5mm needles, and if I am sensible I will keep the pattern safe.

Welcome to our @curtainstocouture second Sustainable Sunday.
Over the years there have been two non fiction books that have had a lasting effect on me. One of them is the 1984 book Seeing Green by Jonathon Porritt, the first book on environmental issues I had ever read.
The other is Finery by Maria Da Conceicao which was published in 1979â€¦this is the one I am talking about today. I was rather hard up in those days but I saved up Â£7.95 and bought a copy. It really had  a profound effect on the way I saw clothesâ€¦and still does. This remains my most treasured book, it is as relevant today as when it was written, the absolute antithesis of fast fashion.
This was clothes as wearable art, not throwaway items, it explains that by using your sewing and knitting skills you can give personal character to your clothes and have that sense of pride that goes with wearing a work of art. These are clothes that you are going to want to keep for many years, not just for a season. 
The garments Maria made did not need expensive fabrics, she made them from old tablecloths, old lace or thrifted clothesâ€¦you just needed basic sewing skills and imagination.
This is the philosophy of Curtains to Couture, we can still have beautiful clothes and homes by creating items using resources that are already in the systemâ€¦we do not continually need to be buying new. 
I have included some of my favourite images from the book and the final picture is a skirt I made from scrap fabrics and lace not long after I discovered this book. The photo was taken in the early 1980s.
#curtainstocouture #sustainability #sustainabilitysunday #clothesasart #wearableart #slowfashion #slowfashionmovement #sustainablefashion #mariadaconceiÃ§Ã£o #reducereuserecycle

Fast fashion and sustainability can never go hand in hand. Brands like H&M, Zara, Gucci and Louis Vuitton and many more, may boast â€œsustainableâ€ products but many still harm the planet and exploit workers behind the scenes. True sustainability means transparency and ethical practices at every step - not just clever marketing.

The takeaway? Donâ€™t just take their word for it. Letâ€™s dig deeper, demand better and support brands that genuinely care. Look for brands that prioritize transparency and sustainability across their entire processâ€”not just in their ads. 

ğŸŒğŸ’š #ThinkBeforeYouBuy #SustainableFashion #Greenwashing #Sustainableliving

I know itâ€™s not just me! And hereâ€™s the thing: a badly made garment from low-quality fabric is never a good addition to any wardrobe. And no one wants seams that unravel, buttons that pop, or colours that fade after just a few washes ğŸ™ƒ

A long-lasting wardrobe isnâ€™t just about beautiful clothing; itâ€™s about the full package: thoughtful tailoring, strong seams, sturdy buttons, linings that last, and high-quality fabric composition.

Iâ€™m a hand luggage only girl and hereâ€™s how I do it! 

Iâ€™m currently travelling from Colombia to Peru and Bolivia with a 50L backpack. The weather is mostly sunny and up to 30 degrees, but the high altitude stops can get as cold as 1 degree at night. 

Whether youâ€™re travelling for a weekend away or an extended trip, packing with carry-on only can reduce costs and friction for your journey. If youâ€™re into your fashion, however, it can feel like a challenge to fit your outfit opportunities in, whilst adhering to the climate. With that in mind, hereâ€™s some tips on how I maximise my outfits with hand luggage only:

1. Pack according to a complimentary colour pallet that works for you. For me, that means picking two matching colours and one pop (greens, blues, and reds) and sticking to neutral bases for the rest.

2. Pack outfits not items. Donâ€™t just pack your favourite individual items; pack items that form a mini capsule wardrobe to mix and match, and test it out in advance. I try to make sure every item can be relayed with at least two others in my bag.

3. Pack with a strong foundation. Base your outfits around wearable basics that perform day to night. For this trip, Iâ€™ve packed comfortable and breathable cotton, linen and wool basics that will regulate my temperature in different climates and will last a few wears without a wash.

4. Maximise variety with accessories. Iâ€™ve packed a few hats, a silk scarf, and patterned scrunchies to switch up my outfits without taking up tons of space.

5. Maintain your clothes whilst your away. Hang up items at the end of the day to air them out and spot clean any spillages straight away, which will help to get an additional wear before a wash. Clothes made with natural fibres like cotton and linen will stay fresher for longer. If youâ€™re planning an extended trip, book accomodation that has a washing machine or pack some hand wash (easier on flight-free trips without liquid restrictions) to wash and rewear your clothes.
Are you a hand luggage fan? Would love to hear your thoughts on how you maximise your hand luggage below!ğŸ‘‡

Patience pays off in the world of slow fashion ğŸ¦‹ğŸ’š

Fashion is becoming increasingly circular thanks to the number of people embracing resale, and itâ€™s great to see. Last year I spotted this Cos jumpsuit new on the high street, but Iâ€™ll always shop #secondhandfirst, especially for pieces I donâ€™t truly â€œneedâ€. After keeping my eyes out on resale apps, consignment stores, and in charity shops, I finally came across it on @vinted. Itâ€™s in my favourite colour, a very adaptable shape with drawstrings at the waist and neck, and even better for being second-hand. 

The main message of this post is to remind everyone that you can very often, with a bit of effort, find high street fashion popping up on the second-hand market if you wait long enough. This jumpsuit was cheaper than the new version, and I got to play my part in keeping fashion circular. 

As a side note, however, it feels uncomfortable to celebrate how fast new items are let go of. I think the ideal is somewhere in between: everyone to play their part in making considered choices when buying new, whilst planning to look after their clothes for years to come, and ultimately sharing them back into the secondary market when the time is right.

#secondhand #vintedfinds #secondhandfind #preloved #circularfashion #fashionblog #fashionblogger #slowfashionblogger

Iâ€™ve entered the wedding guest season of my life and have been reminded of that feeling of not having something to wear ğŸ‘—ğŸ‘”

Hereâ€™s some options on how to take a slower approach to formalwear:

â­ï¸ Wear something you already own: once you own a formal outfit for a particular season, keep repeating it. Itâ€™s so refreshing looking forward to an event without worrying about what to wear, when youâ€™ve already tested an outfit before. You can switch up accessories to keep it feeling fresh. 

â­ï¸ Borrow: find some friends or family to borrow from. The same goes for lending. If anyone knows me in person and wants to borrow a formal outfit Iâ€™ve worn before, let me know and we can keep it circular!

â­ï¸ Try renting: with enough planning time in advance, you can rent formalwear smoothly from places like @rites.co @byrotation and @hurr. Think about how many other people have outfits theyâ€™ve only worn a few times for an event!

â­ï¸ Buy second-hand: if the above hasnâ€™t worked, buy something second-hand and then set out to repeat it. Thereâ€™s so many lightly worn formalwear pieces on second-hand apps waiting to be worn again.

For my wedding guest outfit in this picture, I planned to borrow this same dress from my Mum. When it didnâ€™t fit as well as Iâ€™d hoped, I bought the next size second-hand on @vinted knowing it was an option Iâ€™d feel happy in. Iâ€™m determined to rewear this and lend it out too ğŸ‘—

How do you approach formalwear in a slower way? 

Finally, congratulations to Steven and Serena. It was a beautiful wedding ğŸ’š

Curtains on the Catwalk
Iâ€™ve just had quite an adventure, I went down to London on my own and attended the very splendid @londonfrocktails and what an evening I had. It was fabulous to meet so many women Iâ€™d previously only spoken to on line.
Part of the evening was the catwalk where we all showed off our home made frocks, and believe me there were some amazing creations. In keeping with the ethos of @curtainstocouture I thought I should wear an old curtainâ€¦so it really was curtains on the catwalk. This was a frock I made several years ago from a vintage Sanderson curtain, but I did add more froth to my red net petticoat to give it a bit more body.
I was far too busy having fun and talking but unfortunately I failed miserably at taking pictures. Fortunately a lot of women did and I have really enjoyed looking at their instagram posts. Thank you @judithrosalind for my catwalk pictures.
A huge thank you to the organisers @susanyoungsewing @sewthreadbear @ooobop @thatlenaking 
Thank you for @what_lizzie_made and @lou_lou_seamsodd for joining me on the catwalk.
Finally thank you @katys9296 for sharing the weekend with me, I feel Iâ€™ve made a new friend.

We just wanted to remind you that @curtainstocouture will be launching Tuesday 1st October.
This venture is a collaboration of five friends who love to make clothes from old household linens, and we want to share our enthusiasm with you. The plan is to have fun, help save the planet one curtain at a timeâ€¦and have more fun.
These little squares are all garments I have made from old curtains, tablecloths and beddingâ€¦as you can see itâ€™s not just pretty frocks, although I do love a pretty frock. 
We do hope you will join us. 
@justjillrosalind @vintage_dahling @slowsewmo @clare.burnage 
#sustainablefashion #sustainableliving #sustainablesewing #savingtheworldonecurtainatatime #sewover50 #sewover50september24 #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #upcycledfashion #thriftedstyle #vintagefabric #secondhandfabric

#septembertextilelove24  day 3 is sustainable. Sustainability has always been important to me, I think growing up in the 1950s and 1960s it was not an optional extra, it was a way of life, mainly for economic reasons but also there was not that much stuff around.
Sustainability is such a huge topic but I will concentrate on the part that is pertinent to this challenge and talk about  textiles. Currently making my clothes is a huge part of my stitching life. I love clothes but I am very aware of the environmental impact of fast fashion, so making my clothes out of secondhand fabrics, fabrics that are already in the system, seemed to be an answer to this quandary.
Since starting on this journey I have discovered that my dressmaking is going into a new direction. Many of these old fabrics are of a wonderful quality and the colours and designs are beautiful. These are fabrics that you want to take your time with, you want to embellish and you know the garments will last for many years.
It is surprising to me how often people change their household linens which means there is a constant flow of old bed linens, tablecloths and curtains into charity shops or sadly just sent straight to landfill.
The yellow frock is made up of two different old tablecloths. The green and pink is a duvet coverâ€¦there is so much fabric in a double duvet cover!
The dark green is a vintage Sanderson curtain and the jacket is a thrifted tunic reworked into a shirt.
It is important to me that I can enjoy my stitching and not be over consuming new and valuable resources unnecessarily.

Iâ€™m really loving the current weather, really feels like September should be, warm and sunny but not hot. Perfect weather for autumn layers.
With this in mind I found this green needlecord tunic in a local charity shop. I wasnâ€™t too fussed about the style but I thought it would make a lovely jacket. Basically I cut down the front,  shortened it to just under the pockets and used this piece to make the front bands. I was intending to add some kind of fastening but it seems to work very well without. As you can see I added a bit of top stitchingâ€¦because I love doing it. Iâ€™ve worn it twice now and I think itâ€™s going to be a really useful layering piece.
In the spirit of #secondhandseptember everything I am wearing, apart from socks and undies are secondhand. They have this really lovely slogan which is â€œDress For The World You Wantâ€, itâ€™s really nice that you can have so much fun with your wardrobe and know that you are doing the right thing.
I made the frock several years ago out of a 1960s glazed cotton, the pattern is from the Japanese Sweet Dress Book.
The thrifted jeans I embroidered over lockdown.
Everything else have been bought secondhand

ï¿½Continuing with the introductory posts for @curtainstocouture 
My name is Marcia @marcialoisriddington and I love old stuff, by day I run my antique shop Smoking Monkey Antiques, and by night I make my clothes using vintage or thrifted fabrics.
One of the wonderful things about Instagram is that I have found friends with a similar passion and this is how curtains to couture came about. I started buying old fabric from Jill several years ago never thinking that this would lead to a real life friendship. It was really through her that I met the other amazing women.
Sustainability in fashion is such a huge and important topic but in my mind that is no reason why working towards a sustainable wardrobe should not be fun. I personally think turning a pair of vintage curtains into a frock is a great deal more fun than buying a new one. The other rather good thing is that you tend to develop your own style rather than follow trends, and you never meet anyone wearing the same frock.
I have been sewing all my life and growing up in the 1950s and 1960s make do and mend was a way of life, so making stuff from second hand fabric is nothing new to me. 
These pictures are a selection of my wardrobe made from old curtains, bed linen and soft furnishings. I also have a passion for patchwork which is a wonderful way to use up all of those tiny pieces of fabric youâ€™ve had for years. With the exception of socks and undies what I wear now is made by me or secondhandâ€¦and I like it that way.
I hope you will join me and my friends on our mission, they are @justjillrosalind @vintage_dahling @slowsewmo and @clare.burnage 
If we all do our bit we can make a difference.

Two people told me in the last week that they'd shopped on a resale app for the first time, and it absolutely made my day. There's an ever-growing community online of people encouraging slower and more sustainable approaches to fashion, but hearing people try it out for the first time (and it going well) is even more exciting. 

More people are buying second hand every year, and it's pretty cool to think that talking about second hand online, wearing it to the office, and sharing pictures of preloved outfits, might contribute towards that. 

If you're someone that hasn't shopped second hand before, and are slightly apprehensive to give it a go, here's a rough list of things that you could get out of making your next clothing purchase preloved: 

ğŸ’› Contribute to a more circular economy: as soon as you see the vast quantities of clothes already available in the preloved market, it's pretty scary to think how many we continue to produce. The next clothing item you want probably already exists, and someone else is waiting to give or sell it to you.

ğŸ’› Save money: When you buy second hand, you'll pay a fraction of the cost of buying it brand new. A lot of clothing on the second hand market has only been lightly worn, or might even still have the tags on. It's sad to see, but it's a good entry-level way into second hand shopping.

ğŸ’› Support good causes: the charity retail sector has excellent stock, but you can also know that, when you shop, you're donating your money to a good cause. 

ğŸ’› Look after people and the planet: the fashion industry is currently one of the most damaging on the planet. It's resource intensive, has a huge waste problem, and the garment workers within it are very often overworked and underpaid in dangerous conditions. Switching a few purchases to second hand is a good way to lower your consumption in that industry. 

ğŸ’› Find some gems: shopping second hand opens you up to an abundance of clothing, that doesn't just come off the shop floor because it's not trendy anymore. Last season's piece out of stock? See if it's being resold. Want to find a 70s inspired dress? Why not buy the real thing!

What are we going to wear? Something we already have! ğŸ‘•

Replacing that worry of "What am I going to wear for X event" with the feeling of knowing you can just wear something you've enjoyed before is pretty liberating. 

Here's a quick reminder I put together of some of the wonderful things you can get out of wearing what you already have, instead of shopping for a new wardrobe. 

I'd love to hear if you've got any ideas to add â™»ï¸

Spring is in the air, and it's making me want to do a bit of spring cleaning this weekend. My wardrobe feels like a good place to start ğŸ§¹

This time of year, I'm usually starting to switch over my wardrobe from winter to summer. It's a valuable time to consider what was worn this winter, if my summer pieces still work for me, and whether they belong in my wardrobe.

The natural next step is a bit of a declutter - but how can I do this responsibly? 

It might be easy to think "Out of sight, out of mind" when decluttering. The reality is that our old clothes, homewares, and general knick knacks are probably all out there somewhere, and it's important to take responsibility for the stuff we decide to get rid of.

Here's five quick tips on how I try to approach a more considerate clear out. Let me know if you've got any tips to add, and save this for your next spring clean!

Same skirt, 6 outfits ğŸ“ˆ

Once you start limiting your wardrobe to only clothes you absolutely LOVE (and not just like), it becomes pretty easy to rewear what you've already got, instead of scrambling for the next thing. The #75hardstylechallenge absolutely put this into perspective for me. The more I wore the clothes I loved, the less interested I became in shopping for something else.

A key reflection from the challenge was that there were a few clothes I wore A LOT, and a lot that I wore only a small amount. Aside from the pieces that were more occasion or season specific, it's made me want to figure out what's in those few clothes that I should be applying to everything I add to my wardrobe in the future.

What's one of your standout pieces that you wear all the time? What is it that you like about it?

A day in the Underbanks, Stockport ğŸŒ¼ğŸŒˆğŸ‘—ğŸ«ğŸ­ğŸŒ¸â˜‚ï¸

I've been up in Manchester, visiting my family, and yesterday we headed to Stockport for a day out in the Underbanks area. It was such an enjoyable trip and everyone we came across was up for a chat. Here's what we did:

We started off at the Stockport Hat Museum for a guided tour. Stockport was a centre for the felt hatting industry in the 19th century and the tour took us through the history, from the cottage industries to the industrial revolution, and the grim realities along the way. A highlight was the hat gallery at the end, showcasing hundreds of hats, historical, cultural, contemporary. I obviously wore a beret for the occasion.

Next, we walked into the Underbanks area. There's lots of colourful street art - one piece has recently popped up made out of discarded bottle caps. The 'Rediscovering the Underbanks' initiative seems to have heritage at its centre and it's great to see history being preserved alongside new businesses here. The ornate Winter's clock was restored a few years back and the market hall was bustling with traditional businesses: bakeries, veg shops, a fishmongers, a hardware store, a bottle shop. I needed a carabiner to clip onto a bottle and I could buy a single one for 35p. Loved that.

There's an impressive selection of independent businesses. Highlights for me: (1) @emikostudios for workwear inspired clothes made right there in Stockport. They felt beautifully made and I loved that you could see the name of the seamstresses that crafted them. I bought the turmeric coloured jacket. One thing I learnt about my style during the #75hardstylechallenge was that I enjoy wearing boxy shapes and earthy colours and this ticks those boxes. (2) @topofthetownvintage for true vintage pieces. I bought a blouse here but even just being in the shop to browse and chat was a delight. Highly recommend visiting if you like bright and bold vintage clothing. (3) @still.life.story for beautiful lifestyle bits - dried flowers, handmade scrunchies, soaps, candles and more. (4) @squound and (5) @20thcenturystores for eclectic homewares. 

I've run out of space, but I could go on! â¤ï¸

Slow fashion is so much more than how and where we buy our clothes. It's about: 

(1) slowing down the pace of our fashion consumption altogether; 

(2) respecting the clothes we already own by wearing them frequently, maintaining them for longevity, and repairing them when they need it;

(3) building an understanding of where our clothes come from, how they are made, who makes them, and what the environmental and social impact of that process might be; and 

(4) letting go of clothes we no longer want in a responsible way. 

What does slow fashion mean to you?

Introducing a new member of my wardrobe: a @hades_wool alphabet scarf ğŸ€

This was a lovely surprise birthday gift, but I'd seen Hades' striking designs before. Hades Wool is a British knitwear brand recognisable by their bold heritage knitwear designs that are inspired by counter-culture. Beyond design aesthetics, Hades Wool is known to prioritise quality and responsible craft. The brand's scarves are made in Hawick in Scotland and they embody everything I like in a sustainable business - unique, timeless designs that are made to last, and give you confidence in where and how the products are made. Finally, the scarf is reversible. What more could I want! 

Sustainable businesses are great and I'm always looking to learn about more. If there's a small sustainable business that you love, let me know in the comments â¤ï¸

Excitement is mounting, only two days till the launch of @curtainstocouture on 1st October.
The pictures today are taken in Abbey Gardens, our local park, I think you will agree the flower beds are looking rather beautiful.
I have decided that I needed a few plainer garments to wear with my floral coats and frocks. Over the last couple of years I seem to have acquired some nice old velvet curtains so I decided to make a little pinafore out of a small brown one. Although I made this coat dress several years out of a wonderful vintage Collier Campbell curtain I really havenâ€™t had much to wear it with. The pattern is the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wrapsâ€¦one of my favourite patterns.
I used my usual pinafore pattern and bound the neck and armholes with some striped cotton from my stash. I really enjoyed working with this old cotton velvet, it is a little bit faded and beautifully soft so I will definitely be making some more of my winter wardrobe from these old curtains.
The sweater is my own pattern made from a thrifted remnant.
The jeans are my usual thrifted and embroidered ones.

Sadly a day late with #septembertextilelove24 but yesterday just got so busyâ€¦so I will cover introductions and colour combinations in one post.
Soâ€¦my name is Marcia and Iâ€™ve been sewing and knitting since I was very young. I am a complete amateur but what I lack in technique I make up for with enthusiasm. 
My day job is antique dealer and I have a shop in Bury St Edmunds called @smokingmonkeyantiques. I love old stuff, I love things that have had a life and come with a story. This passion carries over into my textile life and I generally buy my fabrics, yarns and haberdashery secondhand. 
My current passion is for making clothes out of vintage or old fabrics which are often embellished with appliquÃ© and embroideryâ€¦I like to see clothing as wearable art.
Sustainability is currently at the forefront of my current thinkingâ€¦the statistics for fabric and clothes going into landfill are truly horrific.
Colour is something that makes me very excited, I think itâ€™s probably got something to do with
 being brought up in the 1950s where vibrant colours were not encouraged round our way!
In this rather wind blown picture I am wearing one of my patchwork frocks, mixing colour and pattern in patchwork is such a delight as you never really know how colours will go together until you have tried.
Piecing small bits of fabric is also a great way to use some of those treasured scraps you have kept for many years.
I love the autumn and this year I am getting very excited about incorporating some of these autumnal colours into my winter wardrobe

I love making frocks but to be honest I really have plenty of them, so this summer I have been making accessories to wear with themâ€¦mainly light weight jackets to wear on cooler days. So far I have made three of them and they are proving to be very useful as well as rather fun to make.
This is a frock I made several years ago from a pair of vintage Sanderson curtains, not only is the fabric very pretty, the quality is superb so it should last me for many years. 
The jacket is one I recently made from a thrifted gingham tunic, I rather like the gingham and floral mix.

Iâ€™m not sure why but I only wear pink on hot sunny days so this frock had not come out of the wardrobe this year. However today itâ€™s going to be like summer so hereâ€™s my pink frock. I am off to the shop so I am hoping the sunshine will bring people flocking down St Johnâ€™s Street.

My frock was based on McCallâ€™s M8320. I mixed the floral fabric with an old yellow gingham tablecloth, a thrifted yellow shirt, two dyed doilies and stranded embroidery thread. I love making patchwork and as you can see from a few of these old pictures it is not a recent passion. Apart from the frugal appeal of using up all of your odd bits of fabric, I love mixing colours and patterns.
Three unloved and unworn frocks in my wardrobe provided the main fabric for the three patchwork frocks hanging on my wardrobe. They are all basically the same pattern but each one has its own colour palette. Itâ€™s always good to use up existing fabrics in your wardrobe or stash and they are such fun to make. These can be worn all year round but as Iâ€™ve mentioned before I always feel the pink one is my summer patchwork frock.
The jacket is made from antique ticking and is a variation of the coat dress pattern in the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wrapsâ€¦possibly my favourite and most worn jacket.
The shoes are a recent Ebay bargainâ€¦and I love them! The petticoat is a thrifted 1990s skirt.

If youâ€™ve been hanging out here for a while (love you, btw ğŸ’•), you already know the fashion industryâ€™s got some serious ethical and environmental baggage. But hereâ€™s the thing: fast fashion isnâ€™t just bad for the planet, itâ€™s hustling YOU too! These brands are cranking out rebranded trends faster than you can say â€œadd to cart.â€

And then they pay influencers and mags to convince you that the clothes you just bought *two weeks ago* are old news. So you gotta keep up, right? and give them more money ğŸ’¸. This FOMO is the fast fashion trap, and the excitement fades right after you rip open that package, then itâ€™s right back to scrolling for more. Thatâ€™s a LOT of energy spent on shopping!

Hereâ€™s the truth: your can look amazing, stay true to your style, and be sustainableâ€”all while spending way less. Forget chasing every new 15-minute trend. Wear what you love, and free your mind for way more important things!

Here are some common misconceptions about sustainable fashion that I hear time and time again. Letâ€™s clear them up, shall we?â£

â–ªï¸â€œItâ€™s too expensiveâ€
Sure, ethical fashion is pricier compared to fast fashion, which uses cheap, low-quality materials and exploits labor to keep costs down. But affordable, sustainable options are becoming more accessible, and hereâ€™s a tip: buy fewer, high-quality pieces and care for them properly. In the long run, youâ€™ll likely save more than you would on constant fast fashion replacements.â£ This outfit for example is made of mostly preloved finds from @oxfamgb and @ebay_uk, mixed with new trousers from @the.revivas and @jlrlondon handbag - I guarantee that the final price tag would be very similar to most fast fashion brands.

â–ªï¸ â€œItâ€™s hard to find.â€
Maybe that was true years ago, but today there are countless sustainable brands worldwide. If youâ€™re not sure where to start, follow sustainable fashion influencers like @besmacc, @andreacheong_, @saint.thrifty, @twinbrett, @izzy_manuel and @rosieokotcha. They do the research for you and offer plenty of inspiration to help you make thoughtful purchases.â£

â–ªï¸ â€œOne T-shirt or pair of jeans wonâ€™t make a differenceâ€ 
No one expects perfection. The idea isnâ€™t to overhaul your wardrobe overnight but to make thoughtful changes over time. Whether thatâ€™s buying second-hand, supporting eco-friendly brands, or simply buying less, every little step helps reduce your fashion footprint.
 
â–ªï¸â€Fast fashion creates jobsâ€ 
Itâ€™s true that the fashion industry employs millions, but fast fashion thrives on unsafe, underpaid and overworked labor. If consumers shift toward ethical brands, the demand for better practices will grow, and the industry will adapt. Ethical and sustainable fashion can still provide jobs, just with better conditions and fair wages.

Now, letâ€™s keep the conversation going: What misconceptions about sustainable fashion are you tired of hearing?

@sewover50 did a wonderful post about gingham makes a few days ago so I thought Iâ€™d show you a gingham frock I made a few years ago. You will probably not be surprised to know it was made from a couple of tablecloths, the pattern is from The Sweet Dress book by #yoshikotsukiori .

3 things I'm enjoying about doing a #nobuy challenge ğŸ«¡

1. Less buying = more rewearing. Reducing the amount I'm adding to my wardrobe means the amount of wears per item is naturally going up. I feel like I'm building a more recognisable style this season, rewearing key pieces more than I might otherwise have done.

2. More experimenting with what I already have. I'm enjoying coming up with new ways to wear the same items. This skirt has made regular appearances in my daily outfits, and I'm enjoying working out all the different ways I can dress it up.

3. Resetting my consumption habits. I'd lost the power of waiting in my purchasing behaviour. I love a secondhand resale app, but the barriers to buying something have become so low recently - you can buy a cheap top secondhand almost as fast as an online fast fashion purchase. It's brilliant to see the secondhand market booming, but I lost the appreciation for waiting, planning, and thinking hard about my buys. After the challenge is up, I'm looking to build in more of these barriers going forward - maybe a low annual limit to force me to really think carefully about adding something to my wardrobe. 

Five weeks down and five weeks to go! #75hardstylechallenge

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 7 DIY Love. As youâ€™ve probably guessed the majority of my wardrobe is DIY so this prompt seemed a good time to show you my latest project.
I recently found this old linen shirt on the Â£1 rail in a local charity shop, a couple of little holes and marks but the fabric was so soft and butteryâ€¦it was probably on its way to landfill. 
I shortened it, removed the collar and cuffs and neatened all of the edges by hand. Then the fun really started. I love hand stitching, I find it very therapeutic and a very pleasant way to spend my evenings. I did the swirls around the neckline and added a patch in the middle of the back, then did a couple of apliqued swirls on the sides. I finished by changing the buttonsâ€¦I just know this is going to get a lot of wear over the summers for many years. The  scraps of printed cotton, threads and buttons were all in my stash. 
The pinafore I made from a small pair of old curtains. This magnificent fabric is a 1970s Sanderson interpretation of a William Morris fabric.
There is no doubt that hand stitched garments become loved garments.

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 14 Slow Fashion Solutions.
Well, this is a big one! Although I am an optimist by nature I am not naive and I realise there are so many different things to be done by Governments, industry and us. I can only speak for myself but I personally think the answer to adopting slow fashion is to have the confidence to develop your own personal style. This way there is no need to follow seasonal trends, whether they suit you or not. This does not mean that your wardrobe never changes, we are constantly seeing ideas that we want to incorporate into our dress, often using things we already own. If we only buy or make clothes that we love and we feel good in, we will want to keep them longer. I think the key is dressing to suit ourselves and not to impress others, it is how we feel about ourselves not what others thinkâ€¦I hope this makes sense.
A huge thank you to @readorn.london and @blesseddesignsco for hosting this challenge again.

This is my favourite mend on my favourite pair of jeans. I embroidered these thrifted jeans over lockdown when I had a lot of time on my hands, they took a long time to do but it was fun. Then on my first trip out after Covid I tripped down the steps at Ickworth House and took the knee out of them. The sun is coving the hole and when the other knee goes it will be a moon patch.
It might sound daft but I only wear jeans that are embellished and these are definitely one of my favourite garments. 
When I was younger mends were always discreet and the aim  was to make them invisible. I am embracing this current trend to display your repairsâ€¦as repairing your clothes is definitely something we should be proud of.

It's my third winter in this coat â„ï¸ 

This coat is a piece I always look forward to unearthing in the colder months, and it's a welcome reminder that rewearing my own clothes is the best way to practice slow fashion, and hone a personal style. I'm sure there'll be many more winters in it.

In case you missed it, I'm doing the #75hardstylechallenge, which involves not buying any clothes (including secondhand) for 75 days, along with some other rules. Like many slow fashion enthusiasts that discover the endless possibility of buying old clothes, I've gone from once buying new, to hardly buying any clothes, to buying only secondhand, to then seeing my consumption slowing tick up again. In part, I attribute this to enjoying the journey of searching for, finding and curating a secondhand wardrobe, socialising through fun secondhand fashion events and markets, and having so much secondhand fashion available at my fingertips through resale apps. On the other hand, I definitely open up a resale app if I've had a stressful day, or for no reason at all, except to search for something and buy it - the barriers are much lower when secondhand clothes can be quite cheap.

In recent months the result has been that I've found myself less interested in styling what I already own, instead focused on finding new (old) stuff for the sake of it. I've found less joy in fashion, and have been inching further away from my goal of enjoying fashion in a slow and sustainable way.

I'm hoping this challenge is the kick up the bum I need to stop gathering new clothes, becoming reinspired with creating new outfits and getting more wear out of what I already own. Meanwhile, I want to practice what I preach by enjoying slow fashion in the ways I know how, without buying stuff. This might be learning new skills to look after my clothes, helping other to find secondhand clothes who want to reduce buying new, and engaging with slow fashion advocates.

I'd love to hear if you have goals of your own this year ğŸ‘‚

Today was when of those days that I stood in front of my wardrobe and didn't know what I wanted to wear. One rule in the #75hardstylechallenge is to minimise the use of external resources to get outfit inspiration (for example, looking up outfit ideas on Pinterest) to encourage more consideration for your own personal style. 

I took a leaf out of @oldloserinbrooklyn 's book and looked back through my own outfit photos for inspiration. This denim jacket caught me eye - around this time last year I was in Budapest, wearing it as a layering piece (swipe to see!). I love how it breaks up an outfit and sits comfortably under a winter coat. I  imagine it'll make it into lots of outfits over the next couple of months of the challenge.

Outfit details ~
Jacket: @ebay 
Top, coat and scarf: @vinted 
Trousers: 6 months old, bought new

On day 16 of the #75hardstylechallenge, I've reflected on the fact that, over the past year or two, I've started to prioritise buying and wearing clothes that are durable and made of natural materials, and that will keep me properly warm/cool as needed. A few years ago, I'd get some good eye rolls over Christmas when I'd go out for a hike with my family in a faux fur leopard print coat. I've since learnt from enough cold and wet days and blistered feet that it's worth investing in a suitable rain jacket and some shoes I can actually walk a few miles in.

Today's outfit was a wool skirt, wool jumper and wool scarf to keep me warm, paired with my very light coloured trench coat that has it's ups and downs in terms of practicality. It has a wool button-in lining that means I can wear it all year round, but the back of the coat gets dirty pretty quickly if it's puddly outside (which seems to be most of the time). Surprisingly though, it does pretty well being thrown in the washing machine for a quick spin, and it's survived 4 years of that now!

I'm interested to hear if you have any priorities when you buy new clothes.

Outfit details~

Coat: @asosmarketplace 
Bag: 2 years old

The secondhand market is set for remarkable growth, projected to nearly double in value by 2027, reaching an impressive $350 billion globally.

Iâ€™d like to think that the driving force behind this boost is a much-needed shift in consumer behaviours, where sustainability takes the lead and the timeless allure of secondhand and vintage is attracting younger audiences. However, if weâ€™re being realistic, fast fashion is set to double in size by 2029 and is forecasted to reach a value of $80 billion. Thatâ€™s quite a contrast.

This video, captured by the brilliant @chemiteijanet at the Gikomba Market in Nairobi, shows the reality of what happens with the unwanted clothes donated by the global north. The used, and very often brand new, clothes found at the market come from fast, ultra-fast, and even sustainable brands. Many still have tags from charity shops like Oxfam, Value Village, Goodwill, etc. Thereâ€™s no proper waste collection or management system, so most of the waste is left lying around. Tailors situated close to the river dump this waste on the banks, which often ends up in the river.

ğŸŒ¿ So my take is: keep buying secondhand! Thatâ€™s not where the problem lies, and anyone pointing fingers elsewhere but at fast fashion is wrong. Theyâ€™re deflecting and trying to justify their own unethical shopping behaviour. However, Iâ€™d love to know your thoughts â€“ should we also be conscious and not overconsume secondhand items either?

When asked why do you make upcycled clothing, sustainable, recycled, thrift flipped, vintage garments, thereâ€™s lots of good reasons, in fact there are lots of facts about how bad fast fashion is but also I make them because I love vintage textiles and I think the outfits I make look cute. Style without contributing to the global impact of textile waste, winner. ğŸ’«ğŸŒ¿ğŸ§¡#vintagefinds #thriftedfashion #vintageclothing #thriftfinds #vintagestyle #summerfashion2023 #sustainablefashion #upcycledclothing #fashionfinds #upcycledfashion #reusereducerecycle

Returns from fast fashion purchases contribute to a shocking 5 billion pounds of waste every year, but the environmental toll doesnâ€™t stop there. Every return involves transportation, packaging, and processing, all of which require resources and contribute to carbon emissions. When items are ultimately discarded, they often contain synthetic fibers like polyester that take hundreds of years to break down. 

So what can we do? By making more thoughtful decisions about what we buy - buying secondhand, choosing quality over quantity, supporting sustainable brands or simply asking ourselves if we really need that extra pair of jeans, we can reduce the demand for fast fashion and its wasteful returns cycle ğŸ’•âœ¨

Pro tip - I always pop by my local charity shops (or any I came across for that matter ğŸ˜…) and keep a wishlist of specific pieces I want to add to my wardrobe, this way I avoid buying things I donâ€™t need and donâ€™t get overwhelmed by the stock diversity! âœ¨ #secondhandclothes  #sustainablelifestyle #charityshop #outfitideas #sustainablefashion

Thatâ€™s exactly what fast fashion wants you to believe. They rake in billions by convincing you that you need to speed up your shopping habits, constantly increasing the frequency of your purchases.

But hereâ€™s the kicker: trying to keep up with slow fashion at the same pace as fast fashion is downright impossible. Slow fashion lies in shifting your mindset from QUANTITY to QUALITY âœ¨ Itâ€™s not just about buying clothes; itâ€™s about valuing the process and the product.

Here are some tips to switch from fast to slow fashion without spending a penny:

ğŸŒ¿ Delete Shopping Apps: If this idea worries you, ask yourself why. Are you really in control of your shopping habits, or are they controlling you?

ğŸŒ¿ Unfollow Fast Fashion Influencers: Donâ€™t forget that influencers are businesses too, they also make money by selling you stuff you donâ€™t need. Surround yourself with inspiration that aligns with your values.

ğŸŒ¿ Be Mindful of New Purchases: Donâ€™t give your money away to companies that donâ€™t align with your values. Consider who made who made your clothes, how much they were paid, and who benefits for your dough!

And even though the algorithm will still tempt you with clever marketing, once you go slow, youâ€™ll see the difference on how you react to it ğŸ’•

ğŸ« Visiting the UKâ€™s oldest blueberry farm, where LUSH sources the blueberries for many of their products, including the Catastrophe Cosmetic face mask - a personal fave. This farm isnâ€™t just historic; itâ€™s also Soil Association certified Organic, maintaining high standards for environmental stewardship.

ğŸª¶ Birdwatching wasnâ€™t really on my bingo card for things Iâ€™d thoroughly enjoy doing, but here we are! We took a boat ride with @birdsofpooleharbour, a charity completely dedicated educating people on the stunning variety of bird life in one of the countryâ€™s most picturesque locations, helping you make the most of this truly breathtaking natural harbour.

Thank you so much to everyone that reached out from my stories last night, it's honestly done me a world of good

I've decided to make a plan on how to fall back in love with fashion again and making myself feel good in the clothes I'm wearing. Last night I decided to put away everything that doesn't fit me and I will revisit in the new year...(after the baileys, mince pies and cheese I'm expected to consume over the next 30 days)

I'm also thinking of investing in some staple comfy pieces so if anyone can point me in the direction of some small/ethical businesses that can help me with that I will be very appreciative

Last night I put together 3 outfits using pieces that I know are comfy and make me feel good and went with this one today. I don't love love it but it's a start

This time last year I made a video about how bad my shopping habits were despite shopping secondhand. I kind of made a pledge to myself that I would change and not buy as much.

Did it work? The amount I've been spending on Vinted and in charity shops has certainly changed and I'm still cherishing the pieces in my wardrobe I was loving from previous years.

I've had this coat for 2 years and I still get so much joy from rewearing it.

 Black Friday can throw all these sparkly shiny deals at you, but realistically you don't neeeeeed a brand new coat. The one you already have is just fine. If it's not why not try shopping one secondhand. There are tonnes on Vinted and other reselling platforms and I got this one for Â£1 at a charity shop so you more than likely will find bigger bargains than the Black Friday "deals" if you look in your local ones.

Where has the time gone?! There's hardly any pictures in my camera roll for the second half of 2023 and it's probably been the year I've posted the least since I started this account. Looking back though, there's been some wonderful real-life moments in the world of slow fashion and sustainability. Here's part 1/2 of 10 pictures that reflected my year in slow fashion:

1. Another year of asking my friends and family to 'please take a photo of my outfit': this was my favourite outfit picture of the year. I felt thrifty and fashionable with my layered jacket and overcoat ğŸ¤ 

2. A lunch with eBay: it was such a pleasure to be invited to a lunch with @ebay_uk to learn more about the preloved partnership with Love Island. It's been so exciting seeing secondhand fashion blend even more into the mainstream. This event was also special though because it was one of the first times I met lots of other fashion bloggers and content creators in person cc @easypeasysustainability @izzy_manuel @anishakalsi @the_oluwaseun @bethlucyblogs and others ğŸ’š

3. A little bit of crafting: an afternoon spent making a crochet bag with @kimranacrochet. This was such a fun workshop and it reminded me how much joy I get from making something with my own hands and learning a new skill. More crafting and creativity in 2024 ğŸ¤

4. Finding new ways to shop secondhand with friends: this year I explored new modes of secondhand shopping, and made some lovely days out from it. One of the highlights was two visits to @the.reloved.club with @thethriftyedit_ ğŸ˜Š

5. Interrailing: in May I embarked on a flight free trip around Europe, half solo and half with friends and family. It reminded me how easy it can be to get about by train when you've got enough time. I loved mapping out the journey and seeing how far I could get without boarding a plane ğŸš‚

The aim was to spotlight this charity shop mac, but it's been slightly overshadowed by the backdrop behind me ğŸŒ¸ğŸ’™

I wanted to reshare this collarless mac that I bought for a few quid from the Scope in Hackney Central four years ago, around the time I started posting my outfits online. I didn't recognise the label at the time, and it's since fallen off from how much I've worn this. It's one of those pieces I get into a rapid rewearing cycle with and then retire for a few months. It's currently back in circulation and it makes any basic outfit feel a little more interesting, with its wide cropped sleeves and big buttons. For all the ease of searching for secondhand clothes on a resale app, it can never beat the feeling of finding a gem in a good chazza shop.

What's your favourite charity shop? Let's take a moment to celebrate them below!! 

Outfit~
Jacket: @scopecharityshops
Blouse and jeans: @vinted

Grinning because I think I've found my autumn uniform - and it's all secondhand ğŸ‚ğŸ

Do you know the feeling when you wear an outfit that makes you feel like 'you'? I think I tie a lot of self-expression to the clothes I wear, so when I wore this outfit and it felt just right, I made a mental note to rewear it again and again. 

There's something about developing a 'uniform' like wardrobe that I think helps to develop a recognisable personal style. It felt like a win for me when my Dad once pointed to a woman wearing a beret and said, 'that's you!' Besides feeling stylish, I think developing a seasonal uniform helps me to slow down my consumption. If I know I've got a reliable base outfit to fall back on that I know makes me feel good, my wardrobe doesn't feel 'empty' or lacking when a surprise event pops up or there's a seasonal change. I've fallen back on this outfit a few times in different variations over the past two weeks and I can keep going.

I'd love to hear if you've developed a uniform, and how you feel about 'personal style'? It's something I'm still working on! 

Outfit~

Denim shirt: from my friend Eliza â™»ï¸
Skirt and bag: @vinted

Closing out 2023 with part 2/2 of 10 highlights for me in slow fashion and sustainability for 2023. It's been a quiet year on my account, but it's been sweet to look back on some small moments that I hope to do more of in 2024: 

1. Finally cracking capsule dressing: living out of a small suitcase for 5 weeks on my interrail trip gave me a renewed appreciation for having less stuff. I had to think hard about how to pack a small wardrobe that would be both practical and interesting enough to keep me going for 5 weeks, and it inspired me to keep practising having less when I returned back to my full wardrobe at home. More rewearing and not buying new in 2024 ğŸ¤

2. Tackling 'outfit panic': I went to the Henley Regatta for the first time in 2023, and pulled together an outfit slowly and thoughtfully, rather than collapsing into last minute outfit panic and buying new. A themed or dress coded event usually tests my slow fashion strength, but thinking ahead and focusing on what I already had meant I could avoid that stress. I'd like to lean on this outfit again in 2024 ğŸ’š

3. The rise of charity retail: I attended a panel discussion hosted by @the_bhf on the rise of charity retail this year. It's incredible to see the growth of preloved shopping against mainstream retail, and events like these always leave me feeling inspired and motivated to keep spotlighting the sector â¤ï¸

4. New ways to wear secondhand: my focus has always been on secondhand fashion clothing, and I don't usually mention other ways in which I wear secondhand. This year I completed a 3-day cycling tour from Lille to Brussels, and needed a few more pieces of kit to wear over the trip. I found this jersey from Rapha (with tags!) on @vinted for a fraction of the price. Always worth checking secondhand first before buying new ğŸš²

5. The Thriftify Thrift-Off: the last event of the year I attended was the @thriftify Thrift-Off final. There was a panel discussion, a catwalk, a mini pop-up shop and more. It was an absolute blast and another opportunity to be surrounded by other content creators, bloggers, thrifters and slow fashion advocates for an evening ğŸ’œ Looking forward to more of this in 2024 ğŸ¤

Saying goodbye to summer by sharing the secondhand outfits that didn't make it to the grid this season ğŸ‘‹â›…ï¸ğŸ‘’

The summer to autumn wardrobe switchover might be my favourite time of year for fashion...anyone else!? I'm so ready to 'shop my own wardrobe' and rediscover what I thrifted last year ğŸ¤ª

#slowfashion #slowfashionfits #slowfashionoutfits #slowfashionseptember #secondhandseptember #secondhandfashion #fashionblogger #discoverunder10k
#charityshopfind #thriftshopping

How to get reinspired by your own wardrobe:

1. Download Pinterest and force yourself to recreate outfits you fancy with clothes you've already got. Ignore when the outfit isn't an exact replica (you've made it your own).

2. Lend out your lesser worn clothes to your mates and get jealous when they make a jazzy outfit from them and then politely ask for them back (immediately wear yourself).

3. Store away your out of season clothes so every time the weather changes you feel like a youtuber unboxing your summer haul.

All jokes aside, we're so encouraged to buy more, that we forget about the abundance of clothes we already have. The above actually help me to keep interested in my own wardrobe and keep the inspiration flowing when the *I have nothing to wear* kicks in. 

Outfit~

Jeans: @vinted

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 3 World Environment Dayâ€¦.this is such a vast topic but today I am restricting myself to one aspect of sustainable or slow fashion. 
In case you are wondering this is me in 2018 rummaging for pre loved textiles to make into clothes. The picture was taken several years ago @vintagemischief in Beccles, Suffolk. Those of you who know me will know this is my favourite way to find fabric, there is already a vast amount of fabric out there, both already made into items and some that has just been languishing in storage for years. Please donâ€™t think I am suggesting you shouldnâ€™t buy new this is just my preferred way of doing things. 
There are many things I like about old fabrics, some of the designs and patterns are really out there but itâ€™s the feel of a fabric that has been laundered many times that I loveâ€¦often so soft and buttery. If there are little stains or flaws it is a great excuse for a spot of embellishment.
The environmental impact of fast fashion is staggering and using fabric that is already in the system is just one way to reduce our impactâ€¦plus it is enormous fun to hunt down and sew with. From a financial point of view it can also be easy on the pocket.
#slowfashionchallenge #sewover50 #sewover50june24 #sustainablesewing #slowsewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #upcycledfashion #upcycledfabric #vintagefabricaddict #vintagefabric

caption:
Well itâ€™s Day 1 of @slowfashionchallenge hosted by @readorn.london and @blesseddesignsco and its introductions today.
My name is Marcia, Iâ€™m 72 and by day I am an antique dealer. This is the job I have always wanted, but until I retired 10 years ago I always did sensible jobs so now is my time to have fun. My shop, @smokingmonkeyantiques is in Bury St Edmunds and it feels like my second home.
Something I feel passionately about is the importance of the High Street. For centuries the high street has been an important place for social interaction and in times of rising mental health issues and loneliness I think that it is critical that we support  our local shops if we want them to survive.
Although I love sewing, in particular making clothes, I am aware of the environmental impact of fast fashion. The vast majority of my clothes are made from thrifted or vintage fabricsâ€¦not only is this far more fun but I prefer to use fabrics that are already in the system and that otherwise could end up in landfill. I really enjoy hand stitching and decorating my clothes with appliquÃ© and embroidery.
Other things I love are cafes that serve good coffee, going to antique fairs, playing with my old doll houses and days out with family and friends.
This is me outside my shop wearing clothes all made from thrifted fabrics, the coat is made from old tablecloths.
#slowfashionchallenge2024 #slowfashionchallenge #sustainablefashion #sustainability #sustainabilitymatters #supportthehighstreet #sewover50 #sewover50june24 #imakemyclothes

#memademay2024 day 3 and the weather has reverted to dull and wet but decent coffee and a day at the shop sounds good to me.
There are so many good things about sewing your own clothes and one of these benefits is that you build up a stash of bits of fabric. These can be left over from other projects over the years, bits found in charity shops and bits that friends give you. One of my favourite things to do with these is make patchwork garmentsâ€¦you will probably see several of these over the next month. They really are such fun to make and a great way to use up small bits of fabric.
I made this frock several years ago from tartans and florals, itâ€™s a simple pinafore shape with front button fastening to flaunt your petticoats.
The cardigan is from the 1980s, I found this in a charity shop about 25 years agoâ€¦and I still love it.
The coatigan was made many years ago from a cabled knit fabric using New Look 6514â€¦a really useful garment.
The petticoat is made from some wide broderie anglaise found on EBay.

#memademay2024 day 9 and Iâ€™m road testing my new gingham frock at Stowe Gardens near Buckingham. As you may have gathered we have spent a few days in the Cotswolds and we dropped by Stowe on our drive homeâ€¦just check out this amazing shell grotto.
This frock started with an old gingham table cloth and a couple of remnants from my stash. This is a shape Iâ€™ve made many times but I really like it and they are so comfortable and easy to wear all year round. Great for winter layering or nice and cool in warmer weather.
The only shaped pattern pieces are the bodice, the skirt can be made as long or as full as you like. It doesnâ€™t need to have buttons down the front, but I think if you are wearing it over slacks or petticoats a button fastening is nice.
The armholes, neck and fronts are all neatened with binding, I generally prefer binding to facings.
The aplique and embroidery is to hide red wine stains I didnâ€™t notice till Iâ€™d attached the skirt!
I just know I will get lots of wear out of this frock.
#memademay #ginghamdress #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #imakemyclothes #upcycledfabric #handmadewardrobe #ilookmyage #grannycore #recycledfabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #nothingwasted #oldladystyle

#slowfashionchallenge2024 Day 5 Summer Style.
For me personally I love a big frock and a nice basket and if the sun is shining a sun hat and parasol.
This photo was taken yesterday at Flatford Mill and as you can see it wasnâ€™t a bright sunny day and further layers were required. I find unlined jackets and coats made from cotton or linen really useful for the British summerâ€¦so this is probably how I will be dressed for most of June and beyond.
I do love a pretty basket and they are so useful for carrying what you need for a day out. This one Iâ€™ve had for years and it was really looking sorry for itself. I relined it, added new handles and pimped it up a bit including pom-pomsâ€¦as you do.
The pinafore frock is made from a vintage remnant and a huge gingham tablecloth. I tend to wear pinafores as they can be used all year round and are great layering garments.
The coat is an old mattress cover and the pattern is the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps.
The petticoat, shoes and tee shirt were all thrifted.

#memademay2024 day 18 and this is me looking pleased with myself after a good few days in the shop. Iâ€™ve sold enough to warrant going to an antique fair tomorrowâ€¦and yes I am excited.
Believe it or not this is my entry for #magamsewalong Minimal May, and the reason is this is just made from one fabric with no embellishment. 
These thin coats are really useful in an English summer, they give a bit of warmth and seem to finish an outfit off nicely.
This fabric started out as five thrifted cafe tablecloths, washed many times so they are beautifully soft. The pattern is my old favourite, the coat dress pattern from Stylish Wraps by Yoshiko Tsukiori.
As you can see I cut the button bands and pockets on the bias, and Iâ€™m quite pleased with the result. To add a bit of weight and structure to the skirt I added three rows of tucks. The buttons are from my stash.
This is worn over a thrifted tee shirt and simple linen pinafore I made many years ago.
Thank you to @suestoney @sewing_in_spain @lizhaywood3754 for hosting this challenge

2 days in Paris ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡·ğŸ–¼ğŸ‘—ğŸ¥

The last destination on my interrail trip was Paris. It was my third time visiting and an inevitable pitstop before getting my Eurostar home, so I wasn't necessarily expecting it to be one of my favourite solo trips - but it absolutely was!  Two full days of art galleries, tasty food, cracking the metro and a lot of thrifting was just what I needed to round off a wonderful five weeks.

The thrifting was outstanding, so this list comes first. My favourite spots (with thanks to @easypeasysustainability for sharing some of these in a Paris guide!) were:
Troc en Stock - 6 rue Clauzel
Preloved by CrushOn - Carrousel du Louvre
Vintage DÃ¨sir - 32 Rue des Rosiers
Mamz'Elle Swing - 35 bis Rue du Roi de Sicile
Free 'P' Star - 93 Rue de la Verrerie
Bobby - 89 Rue RÃ©aumur
BIS Boutique Solidaire - 7 Bd du Temple
Celia Darling - 5 Rue Henry Monnier
Debardeuse - 16 Rue la BruyÃ¨re

Alongside the thrifting, I loved wandering Le Merais, with a well recommended lunch stop at Las du Falafel and Fulvio for dinner (thank you @elizaperi for the tip and for many more for future Paris trips). I also visited Musee d'Orsay and Musee de l'orangerie, which were perfect to wander as a solo traveller. 

I'll be back!

Thrifty formal wear ğŸ‘—ğŸš£â€â™€ï¸ 

I dressed up for the Henley Regatta this weekend and here's how I put together a fully thrifted outfit! 

I went interrailing last month and in Paris I went to this vintage shop in Le Merais that was full of so many gems. I was very taken with this light green tailored dress and whilst I don't go to dressy events very often, I thought this would be a gorgeous piece to add to my wardrobe ready for an occasion where I wanted to feel a bit chic. It wasn't a perfect fit but for 10 euros I thought I'd get it professionally tailored. I've got some sewing machine skills but I was worried I'd mess this one up.

I finished off the outfit with a bag I got for 2 euros from the same shop and for shoes I wore these secondhand Russell and Bromley fisherman sandals. These retail for Â£195 but I got a nearly new pair from Vinted for Â£35.

This was the full outfit. I felt comfy and dressed up, but most of all pleased to do a dressy event in full secondhand. I'd love to know what you think about it!!

Hereâ€™s the thing: Fast fashion thrives on making you believe you need to keep buying more, faster. But sustainable fashion isnâ€™t just about swapping brands - itâ€™s about shifting how we think. Itâ€™s about quality over quantity.

Yes, ethical fashion can cost more upfront, but hereâ€™s the key: buying fewer, well-made pieces and taking care of them. Over time, this approach not only saves money but also reduces waste and supports a more responsible fashion industry. 

Affordable, sustainable brands are popping up everywhere and itâ€™s so easy to make the switch without breaking the bank. Letâ€™s normalize choosing pieces that last, tell a story, and make us proud of what we wear ğŸ’š

La Rossa, La Dotta, La Grassa â¤ï¸ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ“ğŸ½ (the red one, the learned one, the fat one)

On my second return to Bologna post Erasmus, I connected less with La Dotta element and spent most of my time exploring the terracotta streets and eating the rich food. Italian food might be my favourite and I think Bologna comes out on top for me. If you've never visited, I'd recommend adding this Emilia-Romanian gem to your travel list. Here's some highlights from my trip and a few bonus tips:

Where to eat and drink:
â˜•ï¸ğŸ¥ I don't think I've ever had a bad coffee in Italy, but some personal favourites are @bottegaportici for a coffee and pastry with a view of the famous due torri, @scuderialivinglab for a cool coffee and @principebologna for somewhere outside the walls with the best pistachio brioche.
ğŸ½ ğŸ•Osteria Broccaindosso for tasty food and warm service, @osteria_dellorsa for a quick and casual lunch in a bustling space (be prepared to queue at peak times, but it'll go quick) and @osteriaal15 for traditional cuisine with a familial feel (recommended to book ahead). For quick and cheap takeaway pizza slices, see Pizzeria Due Torri. Salumeria Simone is a great stop if wine, cheese and cured meats are your thing. 
ğŸ«’ğŸ· For aperitivo drinks and snacks paired with a bit of people watching, explore the bars around Santo Stefano (for non-drinkers, these bars also did some of the best non-alcoholic cocktails I'd had for a while!). For a more animated vibe and some apericena (more substantial snacks with your drinks) I'd recommend the bars on Via Pratello.
ğŸ¨ğŸ¦For gelato, try Cremeria Cavour and La Sorbetteria Castiglione.

ğŸ‘£â›ªï¸ğŸ‘—Things to do: I promise there's plenty to do that isn't eating! For thrifting, head to the market in Piazza VIII Agosto on Friday's and Saturday's (with smaller pop-ups throughout the week). Walk outside the walls (or take the tourist train) up to the Santuario Madonna di San Luca - the walk is around 3 miles long through the longest portico from Porta Saragozza - see views of the countryside, the city and the stadium along the way. Wander the portici in the streets and visit Piazza Maggiore and Neptune's fountain. Climb Asinelli tower for a bird's view.

2 days in Turin ğŸğŸ‘—ğŸšŠ

By the penultimate stop on my interrail trip I fancied doing something a bit more organised. The highlight of my stay in Turin became my experience taking part in a cookery class with Le Cesarine. I've always wanted to do an Italian cookery class (if I love to eat it, why not learn how to make it?) but I'd always been put off by slightly more technical culinary courses. I fancied learning a recipe or two in a casual setting and came across this program on Air BnB (though I believe it's available on other platforms too).

The Cesarine program was founded in 2004 in collaboration with the Association for the Guardianship and Protection of the Traditional Culinary-Gastronomic Heritage of Italy and sees passionate Italian cooks opening up their homes and kitchens to visitors to learn about local foods and cooking techniques. Along with 3 other visitors, we learnt how to prepare focaccia for an aperitivo, tagliarini ai ragu and agnolotti con burro e salvia for mains, and tirimasu for dessert. A scheduled 3 hour class went on for over 6 hours, ending late with us happy, stuffed with good food we'd prepared together and full of knowledge on how to bring those recipes back with us. I'd recommend looking it up if you want to learn more about preparing Italian food whilst on your travels, especially if you are travelling solo like me and fancy a different interaction for your evening.

After such a rich evening, the rest of my time in Turin was pretty slow going, but other highlights for me were the following:

ğŸ‘—Usato Firmato Turino Centro: A highly curated secondhand store and one of the best I've visited in a while, featuring vintage, Ganni, Ralph Lauren and more. I spent ages scanning through the racks, though I didn't take anything away with me.

ğŸ½Fiori e CaffÃ¨: A bustling spot for a set menu lunch amongst locals.

ğŸŒ³Giardini Reali di Torino: A pleasant place to sit in a deckchair in the palace gardens and recover from the food coma from the night before.

Whatâ€™s better than a head to toe @lebonshoppe outfit?

(AD/PR) Iâ€™m so happy and honoured to be repping my favourite sustainable brand from across the pond. Le Bon Shoppe has become a firm favourite of mine, you know how much I love their colourful socks but I have also become the biggest fan of their clothing too and they are now absolute classics which will always have a place in my wardrobe. 

Le Bon Shoppe pieces are a range of simple, easy to wear basics which have been perfected to become the piece you reach for time and time again. Those everyday pieces youâ€™re always trying to find? This is the place to find them! They defy fast fashion trends instead focussing on timeless clothing without the pressure of keeping up with constant new season crazes. 

I could go on about all the things I love about this brand but finally I wanted to mention their refreshing approach to production and marketing, their honesty and authenticity is so distinctive and charming in an age of pressured fashion sales. They believe that â€˜those who love us will find usâ€™ which is a concept I love and Iâ€™m so honoured they have trusted me with this and given me the opportunity to share their incredible products with you. 

You can find @lebonshoppe at some excellent independent stores in the UK including @mercantilelondon @cissywears @wordstoreldn @bristolgeneralstore

Itâ€™s all about the back ğŸ™Œ 

I love clothing which has something interesting happening on the back, itâ€™s not that often you see it and also to see it done well so hereâ€™s a few of my faves :

1. @dreamersrebels this knit is made to order and so cute, itâ€™s made in the softest non-itchy mohair and if youâ€™re a cat lover thereâ€™s a ğŸˆ version too. This brand also makes lots of reworked one of a kind pieces, think frills, lace, bows and the prettiest two pieces. 

Worn with @emikostudios trousers

2. @second_stories__ * still loving this t-shirt which doubles as a short dress for me too. The weight and quality is amazing and in my fave colour combination. Iâ€™m hoping for more designs ğŸ™ 

Worn with @ganni dress

3. @studio.spokes how these vintage tea towel tops look at the back is very much a part of the design process which Tash talks you through when making these bespoke. They are also available in limited ready to wear drops and each time I see them I find another I love. 

Worn with @lebonshoppe via @mercantilelondon skirt 

4. @stellanovacopenhagen definitely one of my favourite Scandi brands, they make a piece in this kind of style almost ever collection and itâ€™s not just fun to look at and impressive at the back but the motifs are all over, theyâ€™re so unique. Up close you can appreciate the embroidery, beading, sequins used on each item too. 

Worn with @stalf.studio * dress

5. @theslowlove my faves ğŸ«¶ I could have picked almost any of my Slow Love knits for this reel as most have something happening at the back. Itâ€™s one of the many qualities that drew me to this brand and they do it so well. I went for the wool tiger cardi in this reel as itâ€™s one I donâ€™t wear and share quite as often as my cotton knits. 

Worn with @adidasoriginals skirt

6. @picante these tees are the perfect fit, another high quality heavyweight cotton, I spent ages on the waitlist for this one last year and when I finally got one it was worth the wait. It looks like pretty much all the brandâ€™s t- shirts have something on the back too which I love. I will definitely be back for more of these. 

Worn with @lebonshoppe via @mercantilelondon trousers
