I was determined to finish this frock in March as itâ€™s my entry to #magamsewalong #mucklemarch 
I wanted to try a patchwork project with added appliquÃ© so it was important that it was a tried and tested and also relatively simple shape. I decided a while ago to collect old check shirts to make a quilt but some of the fabric has been used here. The base is a rescued curtain lining, some of the shirts were a bit worn so needed to be attached to something firm. Iâ€™ve shown pictures of the reverse so you can see how I attached themâ€¦basically made strips of pieces then attached from the top downwards. 
The appliquÃ© is an old frock that just wore out many years ago. I cut out the bits I wanted, attached to lightweight iron on interfacing and used blanket stitch to attach.
The binding is another thrifted shirt and the faux button fastenings are also reclaimed shirt buttonsâ€¦nothing is wasted in this project!
I think this also qualifies for #wearhappycolor2024 week 4 rainbow week.
I have had such fun making this pinafore and itâ€™s cost me very little to make and itâ€™s used a lot of stuff that could have ended in landfill.
Thank you @suestoney @sewing_in_spain @judithrosalind for #magamsewalong

I made this frock over the winter but when Iâ€™d finished it felt like a warm weather frockâ€¦so today was the day as the sun was shining in Ely. This is McCallâ€™s 7969, Iâ€™ve seen so many lovely versions of this that I thought I would give it a go. The fabric is a pair of old cotton curtains and the binding is an old striped shirt. I more or less stuck to the pattern but decided to stitch the front up as I found it kept a better shape, this is decorated with assorted mother of pearl buttons. I also ruched the sidesâ€¦just because I felt like it.
Overall Iâ€™m rather pleased with it and will probably use the pattern again.

Well itâ€™s still pretty nippy here in East Anglia but I am  determined to wear summer clothes so itâ€™s just a matter of wearing lots of them. 
When I was at secondary school in dressmaking classes in the 1960s there were rules about the length of your layers, your petticoat was definitely shorter than your frock and your coat was a bit longer than your frockâ€¦and slacks under your frock were unheard of. Anyway times change and itâ€™s so nice rules arenâ€™t as rigid anymore.
I had a lovely day in Ely with @nancyvoak strolling, eating and lots of sewing chat. Check out that amazing zero waste patchwork jacket.
My coat is old French ticking, itâ€™s the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wrapsâ€¦one of my favourite patterns. 
This is worn over linen slacks, gingham frock and fairisle sweaterâ€¦although it was cold I was really quite toasty.

For those of you who donâ€™t know, when Iâ€™m not sewing I am a shop keeper, I am the proud owner of Smoking Monkey Antiques. This is my retirement project that I set up eight years ago. 
Over three last couple of months I have been working with a website designer and this week www.smokingmonkey.co.uk has gone live. I wanted the site to reflect the shop and I really think it does.
When you run a small business or shop it becomes far more than just a job, itâ€™s a huge part of your life, almost part of who you are. 
Apart from a place of work the shop is somewhere that I have made new friends and old friends come to visitâ€¦Iâ€™ve even had buskers and a Morris dancing side passing through.
You may recognise @justjillrosalind @slowsewmo @judithrosalind  @nancyvoak and @ladynorfolkandlordrust_ and there have been many more.
Yesterdayâ€™s outfit was my autumnal patchwork frock, with a self drafted sweater made from a thrifted remnant. The coatigan is New Look 6514 made from a poly viscose fabricâ€¦such a useful garment.
#sewover50 #sewover50april #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #donttellmehowtodress #supportsmallbusinesses #supportthehighstreet #supportsmallbusiness #shoplocal #smalltownshopping #antiqueshop #antiqueshopping #grannychic

As you probably know I love knitwear, and Iâ€™ve always loved a cardigan with a ruched satin trim, then when I saw the scrumptious one by Molly Goddard recently I thought I might give it a goâ€¦and if you are interested this is how I did it.
This one started with a striped cotton sweater from the Â£1 rail in the charity shop and a length of ribbon. I shortened the body and the sleeves and cut up the middle of the front then neatened with a couple of rows of zigzag stitching.
I measured the length of the front opening and cut double the length, folded it in two and slip-stitched the one side together. Then with the fold at the top I clipped this to the front and using running stitches I stitched it in place. Using the same method I bound the bottom edge as well.
The cuffs I just turned a small hem and secured with herringbone stitch, and I used a large fabric coloured hook and eye to fasten the front.
If this doesnâ€™t make sense I took pictures of the process which I have included in the post. I was pleased with the result and I think it will be a useful summer layering piece.
The frock was my mother of the bride outfit several years ago that just wasnâ€™t getting worn so as I loved the fabric I turned it into a pinafore that I am getting a lot of wear out of it.

So itâ€™s #memademay2024 , I always enjoy seeing everyoneâ€™s me mades and getting an insight into the thoughts behind your choices and makesâ€¦and also being inspired.
Quick introductionâ€¦Iâ€™m Marcia, Iâ€™m 72 and Iâ€™ve been sewing all my life but itâ€™s over the last ten years that Iâ€™ve become totally addicted to making clothes. Wherever possible I now make my clothes from secondhand fabrics and this is mixed in with mainly thrifted items. I continue to be shocked by the impact that fast fashion has on the environment and strive towards a sustainable wardrobe and at the same time having fun.
When Iâ€™m not sewing I have an antique shop @smokingmonkeyantiques and I collect old doll houses.
It seemed appropriate to have this first picture in my sewing room, and as you will notice the sun is shining! 
I made todayâ€™s frock several years ago and it is made from a vintage Collier Campbell curtain. The pattern is from Sweet Dress Book by Yoshiko Tsukiori. I have used this pattern many times.
The sweater is also several years old and is self drafted.
The linen culottes and tea shirt are both secondhand.
Thank you Zoe @sozoblog for continuing to host this challenge

Well it was actually warm yesterday and I feel quite justified in having put my winter clothes away. Since Iâ€™ve been making my own clothes I really enjoy getting reacquainted with seasonal clothes when the weather changes.
I made this pinafore in December, mainly because Iâ€™d found this ticking remnant and I fancied an embroidery project for those long winter evenings. It is just a simple pinafore pattern and I just managed to get the two main pieces and three pockets out of the ticking. The appliquÃ© is scraps from my stash and the binding is made from Peteâ€™s old pyjama slacks.
The shoes are a pair of patent Mary Janeâ€™s bought many years ago that I addded a bow toâ€¦and now I feel the need to add bows to all my shoes!
The slacks are red linen and the pattern is from Everyday Style by Lotta Jansdotter.
The tea shirt and cardigan are both thrifted.

I just wanted to show you what you can make from a double duvet cover and pillow cases. I found this brushed cotton set in a charity shop a couple of years ago, it was Â£5. 
I started by making this huge smock frock from vintage Laura Ashley pattern 7917, then I had enough to make a Pilvi coat from the Lotta Jansdotta Everyday Style book. I lined the coat with brushed cotton making it very cosy. I still have some bits left which I am intending to piece together to make a winter petticoat.
Both of these pictures were taken this week, cold but sunnyâ€¦my favourite weather.
I knit the tank top and shawl a few years agoâ€¦both patterns I made up as I went alongâ€¦but fortunately I wrote them down so I can repeat them.
In the second picture I am wearing the coat over a frock made from vintage Laura Ashley cotton twill, the pattern is Cotton + Chalk Zoe dress. The sweater is a thrifted and shortened fair isle bought several years ago. 
I rather like the combination of fair isle, floral, tartan and stripesâ€¦itâ€™s such fun mixing patterns.

This is my entry for #magamsewalong Around April, and Iâ€™m creating around an inspiration photo. My inspiration is the second picture, Iâ€™m pretty certain itâ€™s from Pinterest but Iâ€™m not sure who the maker is.
I thought it would be nice to have a little layering piece to wear over summer frocks and pinafores. The fabric is a thrifted white cotton/linen shirt that I dyed yellow, together with some old cotton lace. I used the bucket method and a Dylon dyeâ€¦the colour took beautifully.
I made the pattern myself and I reused the original buttonholes and buttons which saved a bit of buttonhole stress! I am hoping to make a couple more for the summer as I think they will be rather useful.
I made the pinafore last year from a piece of 1960s fabric I had in my stash.

#memademay2024 day 2, early morning picture in the garden before Iâ€™m off for coffee and a day at the shop.
One of the exciting things about your sewing journey is when you get to that stage when you see a picture of a garment and you think â€œI could make thatâ€. This jacket was one of those times, so this is a combination of a random Pinterest post and a piece of thrifted old ticking. I hacked the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps and this is the result. Probably one of my most worn summer makes.
The frock was something I made a couple of years ago for a prairie style sewing challenge. It is based on a 1970s sewing pattern but with added frills and layers made from lace and curtain lining dyed to match.
The sweater is made from a small piece of thrifted knit fabric, possibly 1970sâ€¦I donâ€™t think there was a pattern.
The scarf was made from an old tee shirt.

As Iâ€™ve said many times one of the best things about Instagram is getting to know likeminded womenâ€¦and occasionally you are lucky enough to spend the day with them. To be honest it was mainly a tour of very nice cafes, morning coffee, lunch and afternoon tea, with a forage round an antique centre thrown in. Plus of course you can always rely on @justjillrosalind to bring you some lovely old fabric.

In the spirit of #75hardstylechallenge and #imperfectsustyfashion30 and wearing what I already own, I altered something that Iâ€™ve had for some time. This Cath Kidston frock was a second hand find from last year, I knew it was too small but I fell in love with the fabricâ€¦barkcloth with clocksâ€¦whatâ€™s not to like!
I think the frock was a size 12/14 which is clearly too small, with a fitted bodice. I undid the side and the waist seams, added a panel either side of the bodice then reattached the skirt. Rather than take some fabric from the skirt to make the panels I used a piece of linen from my stash. I envisage wearing this in cooler weather, so the chances are I will be wearing a cardigan on top anywayâ€¦but to be honest I am happy with the alteration anyway and I am sure this will now be worn regularly.
The â€˜newâ€™ frock is worn with my usual embroidered jeans and a cardigan I knit several years ago.

So we have another week of mindfully getting dressed each today, using what I already have rather than buying new. I always enjoy the process of putting daily outfits together but these challenges have encouraged me to look deeper into my wardrobe and I am discovering things I had forgotten I had got.
I am currently trying to get out of the habit of watching Pointless on the telly in the late afternoon as this hour was always my sewing time as I am bursting with ideas of things to makeâ€¦progress on this is being made.
Itâ€™s been a good week for seeing friends, @susanyoungsewing and I went to Ely to see the historic bridal gown exhibition and I returned to North London to catch up with @chris___art . Time with friends is always good.
As usual these clothes are either secondhand or made with old fabrics.
In case you are wondering that wonderful fabric in the first picture is a vintage Collier Campbell curtain.

So itâ€™s March and time for #wearhappycolor2024 brought to us by @katiekortmanart and week 1 is monochromatic. 
I found this harder than it sounded but Iâ€™ve had a good go at it and I even managed to find appropriate coloured backgrounds. I must admit it was rather fun putting these colours together as itâ€™s not something I normally think about.
First picture is a patchwork pinafore I made from lots of fabric scraps based on yellows, rusts and browns. It was made as a summer frock but layers up really well for colder weather.
On reflection perhaps two of these outfits are more analogous than monochromatic but Iâ€™m sure we can bend the rules a little bit

I am currently pretty excited as I have a ticket for #londonfrocktails in October and obviously for an event like this a girl needs a nice frock. 
I enjoy getting dressed but I am not good at dressing up I really dress the same way whether Iâ€™m going to work or going to a wedding. 
I think we all have a favourite frock, one that whenever we wear it we feel good, it just feels right. For some reason, Iâ€™m not entirely sure why this is my favourite frock and looking back at my photos it comes out a lot all year round. It always feels right.
As you can tell itâ€™s made from 1970s curtains and I made it during one of the covid lockdowns. Itâ€™s a simple self drafted pattern, one I have used many times. 
So over the next few months I will decide whether to make a posh frock or another frock I know I will wear many many times. To be honest I know it will boil down to what old fabric I happen to come acrossâ€¦watch this space.

caption:
In response to many messages here is my rather maverick way of shortening a sweater. I am not saying this is a correct way to do it but it works for me and itâ€™s quick and easy. 
Most of my sweaters I find in charity shops and they are generally too long for me, I prefer a cropped one without a ribbed bottom, I personally think they look nicer with frocks. I had been looking for a nice blue one for ages to wear with this pinafore and I found one last weekâ€¦it was on the reduced rail so I probably saved it from landfill!
1. Decide the strength you want your sweater, add 1 cm. and put in a row of pins.
2. Add a row of running stitches and remove the pins.
3. Cut along the running stitches.
4. Zig zag along the cut edgeâ€¦I tend to go round 3 or 4 times.
5. Turn up approximately 1 cm and pin.
6. Choose a matching thread and using herringbone stitch secure the hem.
This works well on machine knit sweaters, I think hand knits may be trickier! 
Good luck with your shortening. If itâ€™s a very long sweater you can actually make a little infinity scarf from the bit you chop off.
The coatigan I made many years ago from a poly viscose fabric using New Look 6514.
The pinafore is made from an old Sanderson loose seat cover from the lovely @justjillrosalind 
The jeans are thrifted and decorated with appliquÃ© flowers. 
#sewover50 #sewover50february #sewover50reworn #secondhandisnotsecondbest #makedoandmend #imakemyclothes #clothingalterations #oldladystyle #upcycleclothing #cutandstitch #wearwhatyoulove

Here is another week of #75hardstylechallenge  where we are mindfully getting dressed each day, recording what we wear and slowing down our consumption. 
If you are looking for what @izzy_manuel  describes as a less intense version of this challenge go over to her page and check out  #imperfectsustyfashion30 .
I personally think it is important to remember to be kind to ourselves and not beat our selves up if we occasionally give into temptationâ€¦none of us are perfect and these challenges can be fun as well as raising awareness of over consumption.
There is a new frock in here, the yellow pinafore, but I have actually had this fabric in my stash for many yearsâ€¦and I love sewingâ€¦what can I say!
Something else I decided to do this week is pimp up my patent mary Jane shoes with a big bow.
As before the majority of these clothes are made from old fabrics, thrifted or have been in my wardrobe for a while.

You know sometimes you just need to go to your sewing room and make somethingâ€¦well a couple of weeks ago this was the case. Iâ€™ve had this lovely fabric for so long I canâ€™t remember where it came from, it was a curtain and I suspect it was made in the 1960s.
This is my racer back pattern and there was just enough fabric for the pinafore and the pockets. All of the seams and edges are bound with binding made from a thrifted green gingham shirt. The sides are faux button fastenings. I made it to wear either over slacks or a petticoat.
The embroidered jeans were one of my lockdown projects and the appliquÃ© beret was a recent make.
#sewover50 #sewover70 #sewover50reworn #sewoverageism #upcycledfabric #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #dopaminedressing #grannychic #imakemyclothes #vintagefabric #handembroidery

As you know I love a bit of patchwork and appliquÃ© so I have decided to combine the two on a racer back pinafore. Apart from being rather fun it is also a very  economical project using a bundle of old shirts, either thrifted or Peterâ€™s castoffs, old curtain lining and old flowered frock for the appliquÃ©. 
I am making it knee length and with split sides so it can be worn with jeans or petticoats.
I was intending to tea dye it once the patchwork was complete but I really love the colours so Iâ€™ve decided to leave it. I will bind all of the edges with a solid colour which will bring everything togetherâ€¦not certain what colour yet. 
As many of these fabrics are a bit worn, I felt they needed to be attached to a base fabricâ€¦the old curtain lining.
The appliquÃ© flowers will be cut out more carefully and I will be using an iron on interfacing on the them and then attaching by hand, probably using blanket stitch.
As the  #magamsewalong2024 is #mucklemarch and I do think this is a fairly big project plus itâ€™s patchwork this will be my entryâ€¦but I am not optimistic that it will be completed this month.
Thank you @suestoney @sewing_in_spain @judithrosalind

Another week of mindfully getting dressed in what we already own brought on by #imperfectsustyfashion30 and #75hardstylechallenge 
I think in order to be able to stick to pledges of not buying new, it is important for the process to be fun. Finding things in your stash or wardrobe that need a little love or change can be a good way of having something different to wear. A little mending can go a long way.
The yellow cashmere sweater was a very good charity shop find a couple of years ago, beautiful quality but  beigeâ€¦I dyed it yellowâ€¦in a bucketâ€¦and now I love it. The yellow petticoat was once white tooâ€¦
For a little while now I have been noticing pictures of cute little girls with bows on their shoes and all it took was a length of satin ribbon threaded though the strap and tied into a bow. I did secure it with a couple of stitches so it wonâ€™t come undone.
As ever most of my clothes are either secondhand or made from recycled fabrics.
Something I am noticing with this challenge is that I do seem quite fond of red and yellow on winter days!
#sewover50 #sewover50january #sewover70 #sew50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #recycledfashionâ™»ï¸ #recycledfabric #ageismisneverinstyle #grannychic #oldladystyle #oldladychic

I wasnâ€™t working yesterday , it didnâ€™t rain and the sun shone most of the dayâ€¦so we had a day in Southwold. We had a wonderful walk along the beach and up to the harbour followed by lunch at @suziesbeachcafe 
As you know I like to find a beach hut to match my outfitâ€¦although this one isnâ€™t a brilliant match l think the colours go quite wellâ€¦and I really love the colours of this hut.
The coat is the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps by Yoshiko Tsukiori. The fabric is an old Sanderson barkcloth and itâ€™s lined with an old flannelette sheet. 
The jeans are a pair I apliqued last year.
The pink linen pinafore was a thrifted buy from many years ago.
I think these colours would qualify for week three of #wearhappycolor2024  week 3, Complementary and if Iâ€™m not the beach hut certainly qualifies
#sewover50 #sewover50march #wearhappycolour #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #japanesesewingbooks #yoshikotsukiori #adayattheseaside #sustainablesewing #slowsewing #oldladystyle #grannychic #dresslikeabeachhut #southwold

Iâ€™ve spent many hours this week sorting out pictures and text for a friend who is building a new website for @smokingmonkeyantiques . Itâ€™s been rather fun going back looking at lots of old pictures of the shop and what we have sold over the last seven years.
There is no doubt that when you run a shop or small business it becomes more than just your work,  but an extension of youâ€¦.I always feel like the shop is my second home. 
This picture was taken last week outside the shopâ€¦as were the previous onesâ€¦but over the last few years.
The coat is a Pilvi from #lottajansdottereverydaystyle made from 1960s cotton velvet, probably my most worn coat. The sweater is a hand me down from Peter that I just shortened. The pinafore is made from a piece of vintage brushed cottonâ€¦and of course there is a frilly petticoat.

An entirely secondhand September preloved outfit

This month is secondhand September and it aims to raise awareness of recycled fashion and encourage people to shop preloved over new and/or fast fashion.

Iâ€™ve always loved clothes and fashion, as a teenager and in my early 20s I was an absolute Topshop addict but as Iâ€™ve got older Iâ€™ve developed an inclination and love towards small, sustainable brands and also buying secondhand too. 

My message isnâ€™t to preach about only buying preloved and to guilt trip people into feeling terrible for shopping new season and latest trends. Itâ€™s something I do too and Iâ€™m just as partial, if not more, to a new clothing purchase than the average person, because apps like Instagram make it so easy for you to be influenced. 

However I will always use this platform to emphasise my fondness for small brands and to shine a spotlight on brands who do sustainability well, to share my secondhand finds and favourite stores to help you find things you love and to tell you about my preloved buying tips because itâ€™s something I really enjoy doing. 

So this month I will be sharing some more entirely secondhand outfits and I hope it helps show you the amazing pieces out there that you can find preloved to help slow down, shop more responsibly and reduce fashion waste â™»ï¸

#secondhandseptember #secondhandfashion #sustainablestyle #slowfashion #recycledfashion #circularfashion

They are an unbelievably soft and luxurious cashmere and wool mix, perfect for autumn and winter styling with the most beautiful mother of pearl buttons. 

These are so versatile and easily to style, they literally go with everything in your wardrobe and hopefully this styling reel gives you some outfit ideas. Itâ€™s definitely going to be a staple knit in my wardrobe ğŸ’•

For reference I am a UK size 10, 5ft6 and wearing a Small. This also comes in a grey and white colourway in both the cardi and a jumper version. Better yet if you love it like I do you can get 15% off the Poker collection with the code KAT15.

@slowfashionchallenge Day 7 Ethical souvenir. You will just have to bear with me on this one. About 40 years ago I visited a graveyard and saw this grave, very sadly it was a young Victorian girl called Rosabella who died aged 15years. I had never seen this name before and thought at the time how wonderful it would be to reinvent myself and become Rosabella. 
However, I never had the courage to do this but I did name my beautiful daughter Rosabellaâ€¦so the name lives on in my life.
Today we visited Arundel and I found the grave bearing the name that has meant so much to me over the years. Not a souvenir in the accepted sense I grant you, but definitely a gift from somewhere I have visited.
It was a grey autumnal day today but the town looked beautiful and definitely worth a visit.

Dressing for joy to combat the bleak mid winter ğŸ’ 

I will continue to buy clothes this year because not doing so feels like dieting and depriving myself of something that brings more than just function into my life. BUT I will do so consciously - shopping vintage, secondhand and from small sustainable ethical businesses. They need us now more than ever has they struggle to survive through the rise of fast fashion. 

I bought this purple vintage dress off vinted. It was Â£8 and itâ€™s a genuine handmade 30s piece. The treasures are out there if you look. 

The brooch on my hat is handmade by @luxulite 
The walking stick is made by @neowalksticks 
The eff Tories heart bag made by @jademuatdodd 

The shoes are vintage miu miu, the turban vintage 60s and the mint tulle bolero is vintage 50s.

Sharing and rewearing is caring ğŸ‘­

I'm wondering whether the key to successfully maintaining a minimalist wardrobe is to have full access to someone else's wardrobe when you need it ğŸ¤ª Thanks to @sian_popple for lending me this dress for my hand luggage only interrail trip - it's been in her wardrobe for around 5 years but she's let me loan it for a few weeks, because what's more versatile than a cami dress!? Not only that, I also nicked her denim jacket for the day.

On a serious note, there's something to be said for lending out, borrowing and renting clothes! It maximises utility in your own wardrobe and stops you buying new for those one-time occasions. 

Have you ever rented, borrowed or lent out clothes?

Highlights from a solo trip to Ljubljana ğŸŒ¿ğŸ‘—ğŸ·

Ljubljana was such a pleasure to visit solo. This was my second time in the city and the fourth destination on my interrail trip. This time I skipped the tourist spots I'd previously visited and instead spent some time enjoying a slow break in the city. Here's how I spent my two days there:

ğŸ˜ I stayed at @hostelcelica a former military prison transformed by 80 artists into a creative and lively space to stay. I'll post more on this in a reel, but it was one of the best hostels I've ever stayed in.

ğŸ½ğŸ· This was the first time I really enjoyed solo dining. I spent the first evening sat outside a wine bar, Ala PrÅ¡uterija. This was set along the river and I happily people watched and read my book with a glass of Slovenian wine and some cheeses recommended by the waiter. Another highlight was Abi Falafel for a quick lunch, which is always packed throughout the day.

ğŸŒ¿I wanted to explore more of Tivoli City Park in Ljubljana, which extends into Roznik Hill. The park is huge and there's lots of trails to explore. I planned a run around one of the outer trails and easily made it into a 15km run. Except for the road running parallel, even the outer trails felt removed from the city, with streams, wooden bridges and forests.

ğŸ‘—On Trubarjeva Cesta and the surrounding streets, there's a few secondhand stores worth visiting if you're into your slow fashion. Highlights were 2nd Chance for higher end high street and designer and @textilehouse_secondhand which had a vintage store and a more high street version up the street.

3 days in Bruges ğŸ˜ğŸºğŸš²ğŸ›¶

To sum up our time in Bruges in 2 words, I'd say buildings and beer - I loved the architecture and the beers were very good. A couple of people told me it was a bit of a tourist hotspot (I guess me being one of them?), but like most towns, stepping outside the very centre to quieter, local spots was lovely. It was easy to get there by Eurostar from London, changing at Brussels.

I've shared some spots I enjoyed below to save for your future trip to Bruges: 

ğŸ˜Where to stay: We stayed on Langerei, beside the canal in the North part of town. It meant we had a 15-20 minute pleasant walk into the centre each morning and could explore some friendly, local spots near the house in the evening.

ğŸ´Where to eat and drink: @bierbrasserie_cambrinus for tasty Flemish food. @Deplachocolatier for Belgium chocolate (we loved the dark chocolate covered orange slices). De Garre for excellent beers and recommendations (our favourite was the Triplel Van De Garre, which you can only drink there) but every cosy looking tavern we walked into was great (I loved trying the Cherry Chouffe fruit beer). @blendwijnbarwijnwinkel for wines and snack foods.

ğŸ¨Things to do: Getting lost around the cobbled streets and following the canal North to see the windmills - if it hadn't rained, we might have hired bikes and cycled to Damme. The Groeninge gallery for Flemish art from the Baroque and Renaissance periods to the 20th century - I'm not normally a huge fan of Renaissance art as I always find it hard to engage with, but the gallery offered room-by-room cards that explained the background to each work and so I spent ages taking it all in. 

ğŸ›Where to thrift: I didn't do any (!) but we passed some cool looking antique and secondhand clothes shops and I believe there was an Oxfam there.

POV you're watching me navigate taking pictures on my own whilst solo travelling ğŸ“¸

caption:
How to pack with hand luggage only ğŸ’¼

Whether you're travelling for a weekend away or an extended trip, packing with hand luggage/carry-on only can reduce costs and friction for your journey. If you're into your fashion, however, it can feel like a challenge to get your outfit opportunities into one small case and backpack. Here's some tips on how to maximise your outfits with hand luggage only:

1. Pack according to a colour pallette. Pick 2-3 complimentary colours for your outfits and stick to neutrals for the rest. For my interrail trip, I've packed a green and blue colour pallette, with a few bits of red.

2. Pack outfits not items. Don't just pack your favourite individual items, instead you should pack a capsule wardrobe of items that can be mixed and matched together in multiple ways. Test this out in advance by trying your items on and checking that they work together. 

3. Pack with a strong foundation. Base your outfits around wearable basics that perform day to night. For my interrail trip, I've packed comfortable and breathable cotton and linen basics, like black linen trousers, cream coloured jeans and cotton striped t-shirts. 

4. Maximise variety with accessories. Pack hats, silk scarves, coloured socks etc. to add some variety to your outfits, whilst not taking up additional space in your case. 

5. Maintain your clothes whilst your away. Rewear items multiple times by hanging them up at the end of the day and spot cleaning any spillages. Clothes made with natural fibres like cotton and linen will stay fresher for longer. If you're planning an extended trip, book accomodation that has a washing machine or pack some hand wash (easier on flight-free trips without liquid restrictions) to wash and rewear your clothes. I've packed some washing capsules for my interrail trip and have a few stops with access to a washing machine.

Share your thoughts on hand luggage only trips below!

A further five days of #75hardstylechallenge and as you can probably tell itâ€™s been pretty chilly recentlyâ€¦but at least weâ€™ve had some sunshine.
One of the challenge intentions is to â€œfind out what is important to you about getting dressed; comfort? self-expression? ease? I must confess that particularly since I have started making my own clothes I really enjoy the daily process of getting dressed. Obviously comfort and ease are vital, as I think itâ€™s important to get dressed and then be able to forget about your clothes and just get on with your day. However, self expression is very important to me, I dress for myself, I really enjoy mixing colour and patterns and I like a bit of whimsyâ€¦ there is no doubt that the way I dress affects the way I feel.
With the exception of the boots and socks these clothes are all made from secondhand fabrics or thrifted garments. This way I can satisfy my love of nice clothes and keep a sustainable closet.

I am often asked what I call my aesthetic and I will be honest Iâ€™m not entirely sure I have one. I am influenced by many styles I see on the streets as  well as on Instagram and Pinterestâ€¦ #cottagecorefashion  #fairycorefashion #morigirlstyle to name a few. As you can see I am currently into bright colours and mixing patterns and prints. The majority of this selection is made by me from old fabrics or bought secondhand.

I want to tell you all about yesterday, it was the Whittlesey Straw Bear Festival, the sun shone, amazing dancers and crowds of people having fun. Basically a man dressed as a bear heads a procession on the streets, followed by lots of dancers, mainly Morris, Molly and Clog dancers. I believe it happens the first weekend after Plough Monday. The bear is burned on Sunday. Like many customs it died out but was revived in 1980â€¦definitely a good day outâ€¦ but always very cold.
This is just a random selection of pictures taken on the day. 
I am super pleased with this recent coat I made, it really is so cosy, being very large you can comfortably get so many layers underneath. The pattern is 1970s Style 2410 and the fabric came from a couple of brushed cotton duvet covers.
#strawbearfestival #strawbear #whittleseastrawbear #morrisdancing #mollydancing #clogdancing #folklore #oldcustoms #dayofdance #fens #ploughmonday #whittlesey #sustainablesewing #upcycledfabric #secondhandisnotsecondbest #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #dopaminedressing #grannychic #donttellmehowtodress #sewover50 #sewover50january #oldcustoms

Original post had duplicate imagesâ€¦Iâ€™m trying again!Well it as a pretty exciting day yesterday as it was the first time we had been to the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge since before Covid. Not entirely sure why itâ€™s taken so long but I think itâ€™s probably taken a a while for many of us to continue where we left off before the lockdowns. Anyway it was wonderful, beautiful paintings and wild ceramics.
 Todays frock is one of my favourites, I generally wear this one on much warmer daysâ€¦but layered up I think it works well for cold days. It is a pinafore made from a pair of vintage Sanderson curtains, with all of the edgings bound in red gingham. Today it was layered up with polo neck sweater, cashmere waistcoat and tweed jacketâ€¦all thrifted. Obviously there was also a frilly petticoat!
One of the many reasons I love a pinafore is that they really lend themselves to being worn in all weathersâ€¦ensuring you get plenty of wear out of your frocks.

I recently came across #75hardstylechallenge hosted by @oldloserinbrooklyn Itâ€™s about many things including mindfully or intentionally getting dressed everyday, being creative with what you already and not buying anything newâ€¦itâ€™s definitely worth taking a look.
For me this time of year the biggest challenge is to keep warm but at the same time ensure that my wardrobe remains comfortable and colourful. I donâ€™t tend to keep clothes â€œfor bestâ€, I basically dress the same whether Iâ€™m going to work, going for a walk or  going out for dinnerâ€¦this way your clothes donâ€™t languish in the wardrobe waiting for an occasion.
So this is what Iâ€™ve been wearing so far this year. Most of this selection has been in my closet for a while and will continue to come out many times over the winter months and beyondâ€¦.particularly my big flowered frock made from 1970s curtains which must be my most worn frock. These clothes are all  thrifted or made from fabrics already in the system .

Iâ€™m a queen upon my wheel-ed throne ğŸ‘‘ ğŸ’–

Is there a correct way to sit on a chair or a wheelchair? Is it for good posture? I can never sit still in one position for too long. When Iâ€™m using my wheelchair I always seem to sit cross legged. Or sitting in a car or at the cinema. Is that bad? I mean it hurts my knees but everything hurts my knees anyway and I have to keep changing which leg is crossed. And I can never just sit primly with both feet on my footplate it makes me feel weird but I canâ€™t put my finger on why. 

Wearing a secondhand velvet pink maxi dress, pink velvet maxi platforms and a vintage bridal crown I dyed pink & lil vintage beaded bag and secondhand topshop beaded cape that looks very 20s 30s.

caption:
There should be a whole parade for today. I want to wave to adoring masses from a wheelchair throne perched on a floral covered float. Celebrate my disabled life with me ğŸ’– ğŸº ğŸ‰ 

Itâ€™s #DisabledPeoplesDay or International day of people with disabilities #IDOPWD as itâ€™s officially known but I think we need to workshop that more. Ideas? 

And the theme this year is â€œAmplifying the leadership of persons with disabilities for an inclusive and sustainable futureâ€. 

This aligns perfectly with the movement toward sustainable fashion. Disabled individuals often lead by example in making thoughtful, resource-conscious choices out of necessity, such as reusing, adapting, and customizing clothing to suit their unique needs. 

Their lived experiences offer invaluable insights into designing sustainable, accessible clothing that prioritizes comfort, functionality, and longevity. 

By centering disabled voices and leadership, the fashion industry has an opportunity to embrace more inclusive, innovative practices that benefit everyone while supporting a greener, more sustainable future.

The BIG message is DONâ€™T FORGET ABOUT DISABLED PEOPLE COZ WE ARE FUCKING AWESOME TOO!

2 days in Brussels ğŸ¨ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡ªğŸºğŸš²

The second leg of my trip was a 2 day stop in Brussels. It'd be rude to do an interrail trip without stopping at the de facto capital of the EU. Less than two hours by the Eurostar from London, it's technically quicker for me to reach Brussels than my family up in Manchester! 

Sharing below some recommendations to save for your future trip to Brussels:

ğŸ˜Where to stay: We stayed in an AirBnB in Saint-Gilles, which is not only within walking distance of Brussels Zuid-Midi Station (where international trains depart from), but also some sweet bakeries, restaurants and bars to pop to.

ğŸ½Where to eat and drink: We spent most of our time eating and drinking around Rue Haute and Parvis de Saint-Gilles. Some highlights include Pierre Et Louise for some Belgian specialities, Baba Ganoush for Lebanese food, Le Petit Lion and Brasserie Verschmueren for laid-back beers. 

ğŸ¨Things to do: We enjoyed wandering the vibrant streets coming off Rue Haute and there were plenty of secondhand stores in that area. The RenÃ© Magritte museum was excellent, showcasing the works of the Belgian surrealist. We visited the Parliamentarium, the Visitor's Centre at the European Parliament (as walking tours of the Parliament itself aren't running in 2023) - it had the potential to be really engaging but it was organised largely around audio-guide devices that failed on the day! Similarly, we visited the Comic Arts museum hoping to see some Tintin - it was an interesting journey through the history of comic art, but Tintin wasn't there anymore due to some rights restrictions..(slightly too close home for a media lawyer on holiday).

Have you ever visited Belgium? ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡ª

Last day of the Christmas break today so we decided to spend a day by the sea at Southwold. It was a really nice way to end what has been the best of weeks. 
I eventually got back to my sewing room this week and finished my ticking pinafore. This was a small second hand remnant I found recently and I just managed to cut out the pinafore and three pockets. As you know I love appliquÃ© and couldnâ€™t resist a bit of embellishment, I have had these cotton scraps for many years. I use a lightweight iron on interfacing and attach using blanket stitch, I have included some closeups. It is my usual simple pattern. This pinafore is really more suitable for warmer weather but you know what itâ€™s like when you  make something new!
If Iâ€™d have removed my coat I would have matched this Southwold beach hut but it was quite nippy on the seafront today. I am getting a lot of wear out of my big tartan coat, this is definitely a very useful make. Details of the coat are a few posts back. Jeans are my favourite embroidered ones. I have found another pair of jeans in a charity shop and I am currently working out an embroidery scheme for themâ€¦watch this space.

A slower approach to trends ğŸ”®

Following trends are a way to get inspired, express creativity and find community - it's hard to think of fashion without them. But there's another side to fashion trends. New micro-trends seem to appear (and die) every week on social media. I shudder every time I see a barely worn green House of Sunny Hockney dress washed up on a resale app, when a few summers ago they were everywhere you looked on a day out in London! Around 300,000 tonnes of textile waste ends up in household bins every year in the UK (sent to landfill or incinerators) according to a House of Commons Environmental Audit Committee report and I imagine micro-trends have only fed into that more. 

In a world where we want to embrace certain trends, how can we take a slower approach? Inspired by pictures of the Chopova Lowena pleated skirt and dressed up tartan kilts on my IG feed, I tried this formula recently when I set out to source a tartan style skirt of my own. Swipe for the five tips I put into action.

Let me know what you think in the comments - Can trends ever be sustainable? Have you tried out a new trend recently and did you take a slower approach? Save for the next time you want to embrace a trend!

Today I want to show you my new pinafore and petticoat. 
This wonderful fabric was a small pair of Sanderson curtains in a 1970s version of a William Morris design. I used a skater back pattern that I took from an old pinafore I had in the 1990s. I decided to have faux buttoned sides and bind the edges in a thrifted gingham shirt. I also added large patch pockets. I have added pictures of the pattern pieces I use and then I just extend the length depending on how much fabric I have.
The petticoat or waist slip is a thrifted duvet cover and some old cotton lace from my stash. I dyed it yellow with a Rit hand dye and I was really pleased with the result. It is basically made up of two rectangles with added lace and feather stitch embroidery.

The Charity Supermarket ğŸ’–

Last week I visited the charity supermarket pop-up - the first multi-charity shop store in the UK.

The shop's located in the old Topshop store in Brent Cross shopping centre, next to John Lewis and the Apple Store. The shop is divided into different sections for each charity shop, but it's all pretty seamless - with one changing room and one till. 

Some highlights for me included how well curated the shop is - the visual merchandising is great and it was really fun to browse through. I was pleased to see some designer brands alongside good quality high street and vintage. I spotted Shrimps, Carhartt, Missoni, alongside Miss Selfridge, Cos and & Other Stories. I was also pleasantly surprised to see some really stylish and wearable menswear. I often see secondhand menswear not getting much further than denim jackets and lumberjack shirts in charity shops.

I think the overall concept is great, especially having a second hand store with a prime spit in a pretty big shopping centre. It might present people with the opportunity to shop secondhand for the first time. The shop is open here until the 25th February and I'd love to see it pop up in other parts of the UK too.

A (sort of) sustainable guide to Budapest! 

I got so many recommendations from friends and family for Budapest that I'll have to go back to do them all. I've shared below a short list of small, local and/or sustainable leaning spots that I visited that you might want to save for your next trip! 

1) Places to visit:  @dohanystreetsynagogue was a highlight - the ticket got us a tour of the synagogue by a local guide and entry into the Hungarian Jewish Museum and Archives and another exhibition. Budapest is known for its thermal baths and we visited @szechenyithermalbath. I've heard it gets really busy at times, but we visited first thing in the morning mid-week and only used the outdoor baths - it was a lovely experience going from the freezing winter temperatures into the water. For a bit of greenery and a good view we walked up Gellert Hill and over Margaret Island. It was easy to get around the city - we walked everywhere (city bikes and public transport also looked good).

2) Things to eat: Breakfast is my favourite meal of the day and we were very spoilt on that front. Franziska was a lovely little oasis to park ourselves for a bowl of sour cherry porridge and some spiced chai. Freyja Croissant Story did beautiful pastries that didn't compromise on taste. The atmosphere at @mazeltovbudapest was excellent for a sit down meal in the evening with some nice food, but the real highlight was the cocktails, setting and live band.

3) Spots to drink: @zergecoffeeshop did a really impressive oat cappuccino, which stuck with me because we only initially stopped for the loo. We searched out some breweries and loved the selection at @kegsormuvhaz (they had a peanut butter and oatmeal stout on tap which I've been thinking about since) and @madhousebudapest . Twenty Six did brilliant cocktails.

4) Where to thrift: We spent a long time working our way through the beautiful @ludovika.vintage store - see my thrift highlight for some pictures of the shop. Thanks to @mrs.balmaks for the recommendation! Cream and Humana were more 'sift through' vibes. @retrockbudapest had great menswear and some pieces from local designers.

Thrifting rules I try to follow ğŸŒŸ

I recently thrifted this denim wrap jacket on @ebay_uk and having worn it already multiple times in different ways, it made me think about why it was such a thrift hit. Below are a number of rules I try to follow when thrifting clothes. I don't always abide by these but when I do, my purchases usually end up being long lasting, wearable additions to my wardrobe. When I don't, the item is far more likely to be resold, redonated or gifted to someone else, which isn't great for my pocket or the planet. Here's the five rules I try to follow in case helpful for you too:

â­ï¸ Build in a buffer period before buying. For online purchases, wait at least 48 hours before pressing buy, and for in-person purchases, leave the store and return after an hour if you can. I find this buffer helps me to question if I really do want the item, if it'll fill a gap in my wardrobe and if i'm just buying something for the sake of a dopamine hit. The only risk of building in time is that the item will be gone when you come back, but in the resell world you'll often come across the same item again if you look for it. 

â­ï¸ Consider if you can wear the item in three different ways to make sure it's a versatile addition to your wardrobe and won't just gather dust.

â­ï¸ Check a variety of resell apps to make sure you're getting the best deal and the best size for you. I found this same jacket on both @vinted and @ebay_uk . On this occasion, I got a better deal by bidding on @ebay_uk and waiting a week rather than an instant buy on @vinted . 

â­ï¸ For online purchases, get measurements or pictures of the seller wearing it if you can to check if it will fit in the desired way. In person, always try on. I've been caught out by items fitting in an unexpected way I didn't like or materials being far less quality than a picture re-used from the original retail site.

â­ï¸ Evaluate whether you already have something in your wardrobe that fits the same criteria and does the same job. It's different for a quality basic in multiple colours, but it's easy to forget you've already got something similar that you could entirely substitute.

Share your thoughts below!

I started my new winter coat several months ago but covid and life got in the way of my sewingâ€¦but itâ€™s now finished and I road tested it today in Cambridge. 
I wanted something roomy to accommodate my winter layers so I used 1970s Style pattern 2410, Iâ€™d previously used this for my big red raincoat.
The fabric and the lining were brushed cotton duvet covers so it is quite cosy. I was intending to use leather kilt straps for the fastenings but after sewing them on I discovered they were quite fiddly to use and did not look right so I added button loops and buttons instead.
Iâ€™ve included pictures of the inside so you can see how it is constructed.

I had a few hours in my sewing room today and cut out a couple of garments from old curtains. If you sew this way you have no control over the amount of fabric so you just have to adapt what you make to the curtain size.  You also have to take into account signs of wear, holes and fading and work around the faults.
The first one I cut out today was the striped ticking, a small piece of fabric so I used my short pinafore pattern and I was also able to fit in three pockets. Iâ€™ve decided to decorate with patchwork and embroidery in reds and greens with a flash of yellowâ€¦watch this space.
The brown fabric is a 1970s Sanderson version of a William Morris design. It was formerly a curtain with a few holes and some fading. This is the kind of fabric where pattern placement is key so I had to do some piecing on the back. This is a simple racer back pattern which I thought would show off the fabric well.
The thrill of finding a glorious old 
fabric is well worth the time and effort but you are limited to what you are able to makeâ€¦unless they are huge curtains.
Apart from the fun, I like the sustainable aspect of using fabrics that are already in the system.

@slowfashionchallenge Friday Freebie so I thought Iâ€™d talk about something I love and that is hand stitching and embroidery. This is something I have enjoyed for most of my life and not only is it great fun, itâ€™s so relaxing and a lovely way to spend an evening after a hard or stressful day. Plusâ€¦you can create a unique wardrobe and every rip or hole becomes an opportunity for more decoration.
My embroidery and appliquÃ© are not complicated, I use very simple techniques and only a handful of basic stitches. If you havenâ€™t already tried I would recommend giving it a go.
There is no doubt if you spend time embroidering your clothes you are inclined to keep them in your wardrobe for longer.
I have included a few pictures of embroidery projects I have worked over the last few years.

#slowfashionchallenge2023 todayâ€™s prompt is Fabric. I must confess I do have quite a collection of old fabrics, and most of my clothes are made from vintage or second hand fabrics. These generally come in the form of soft furnishings, mainly curtains but sometimes bed linen or tablecloths. I seldom buy fabric with a specific garment in mind, if I find something beautiful I buy it and then, depending on the amount, decide what to do with it. 
These pictures are garments that I have made from vintage curtains over the last few years. 
Using fabric that is already in the system is not only more sustainable than buying new, I personally think many of the patterns and colours are so delicious. This first fabric is one of my favourites, a 1960s Sanderson and the intensity of the colour is incredible.
Most of these fabrics are found at vintage and antique fairs and if Iâ€™m lucky in charity shops. There are also some good sellers on Instagram.

Iâ€™ve made a new frock, I bought this wonderful fabric from my friend @justjillrosalind last year and it seemed the right time of year to make it up. The fabric was quite narrow so I am assuming it is 1960s/1970s and I think it is a cotton twill.
The pattern, Cotton + Chalk Zoe dress really was designed for a wider fabric so I had to have an extra seam down the back, and the front is in four pieces. Unfortunately there was not sufficient fabric to Match the pattern but there was just enough to make two patch pocketsâ€¦a girl always needs decent pockets. It has a nice drape which really suits the pattern well.
The coat is one I made about five years from a poly viscose mix using New Look 6514. This coat is so useful and washes beautifully.
The linen slacks, tea shirt and necklaces are thrifted.
Knitted cotton beret from @lordandtaft

Iâ€™ve recently bought this rather splendid new brolly which I am modelling outside my shop. The reason I made this purchase is that last Friday someone stole my lovely William Morris brolly from just inside the shop door where Iâ€™d left it to dripâ€¦I canâ€™t deny I was a bit cross.
This beautiful new brolly is based on a Klimt painting and looks so pretty in the rain and hopefully will keep me dry for many years as long as Iâ€™m careful where I leave it! I was really pleased to be able to buy it from a wonderful local shop @loftandspires . I always try and buy locally if I can as I am passionate about keeping the High Street alive.

@slowfashionchallenge todays prompt is Slow Fashion Tip. I personally think the way to embrace slow fashion is to develop your personal style and not follow trends. 
I love seeing what is out there  but I think it is far more fun to adapt other styles to suit yourself and your lifestyle rather than just follow them. Wear what you love and what makes you feel good, this way you will love your wardrobe and not want to be constantly buying new. Fast fashion feeds on us wanting the latest trends which results in so much waste.
In the early 1980s I discovered a book called Finery by Maria Da Conceicao and it is really about clothes as art. She used old fabrics and so many different techniques to create beautiful clothes. The book cost me Â£7.95, which was a lot of money for me in those days but I still get so much pleasure from it and I have no doubt about the impact it had on my approach to dress.
This is a picture from last year. The frock is one of my patchwork numbers made from odd bits from my stash and the cardigan is a charity shop find from the 1980s and still going strong.
#slowfashionchallenge2023 #sewover50 #sewover50october #slowfashionmovement #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #clothesasart #wearwhatyoulove #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #iwillwearwhatilike #patchworkdress

Todayâ€™s post is all about altering stuff so you will enjoy continuing to wear it. Earlier this year I was diagnosed as pre diabetic and as I really donâ€™t want to go down that route I decided to change the way I eat, mainly cutting down on refined sugar and carbs. I am still eating quite a lot, just differently, but to my amazement I have lost quite a lot weight and feeling much better.  As a consequence of this my jeans are way to loose around the middle so I have done some reversible alterations to reduce the waist. Basically I measured across the inside back of the jeans, halved the number and cut that amount of 2cm wide elastic. I then pinned down either end and every 5 cms, I then zig zagged top and bottom of the elastic, stretching as I stitched. I am sure there are better ways to do this but it is quick, easy and reversibleâ€¦I have included a picture.
I found this fairisle cardy in a charity shop recently, I love the pattern and the fit but probably because I am not very tall I feel better in a short cardy. I cut, zigzagged three times then stitched the hem using a herringbone stitch.
The pinafore I made several years ago from an old curtain.
The make of the thrifted shoes is Oxygen.
#curtainstocouture #sewover50 #sewoverseptember24 #makedoandmend #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #donttellmewhattowear #secondhandseptember #ilookmyage #grannychic #oldladystyle

Well then! Time to officially launch the Curtains to Couture account! Curtains to Couture is founded by 5 friends with a vision to save the planet one curtain at a time! Our aim is to nurture a community of like minded souls - connected by a love of soulful stitch using reclaimed fabrics. We invite you to slow down, stitch and create mindfully, and return to the values of using what you have or whatever already exists. Upcycling, recycling, mending and re-using, itâ€™s all about breathing new life into old textiles. Tag us using #curtainstocouture @curtainstocouture to feature on our grid on Follower Fridays, starting next week. Donâ€™t forget to follow the hashtag too! At the weekend, there will also be a regular feature of Sustainable Sunday, with top tips and facts. Guest posts and editors, lives and interviews also planned.
We are: 
Clare @clare.burnage 
Jill @justjillrosalind 
Lisa @vintage_dahling 
Sorrel @slowsewmo 
Marcia @marcialoisriddington 

Curtains to Couture artwork courtesy of the very talented @princeslikequinces

Todayâ€™s prompt from @slowfashionchallenge is upcycled which is right up my alley. 
I always try and use fabrics that are already in the system and I personally find old soft furnishings a very useful source of fabric. The frocks and slacks in these pictures are all made from old curtains. I think these are mainly vintage Sanderson and the colours and patterns are exquisite. Just for the record the slacks are also lined with an old flannelette sheetâ€¦makes them so cosy.
I think these fabrics demonstrate that if you choose good quality fabrics they will stand the test of time and look good for many yearsâ€¦plus sourcing them is such fun and you rarely bump into anyone else wearing the same frock. The downside is that you do get people telling you that their granny used to have curtains like your outfit!

@slowfashionchallenge prompt today is oldest threads. If you knew how long it took me to knit this cardigan and how many ends I had to run in you can understand why I still have it. I knit this in the early 1980s, it was designed by Zoe Hunt from the 1982 â€œThe Sweater Bookâ€. It is many different types of yarn but all of DK weight with added silver lurex thread. I adore 1980s knitting books, they can be bold and exciting with amazing styling.
The top picture was taken on the train to Brighton about 1985 and as you will notice my hair do hasnâ€™t really changed. The most amazing thing is that it still fits albeit a little more snug.
We had a lovely day in Cambridge yesterday and Iâ€™ve included a few pictures taken there, itâ€™s such a beautiful city.

#slowfashionchallenge2023 day 2 Autumn Layersâ€¦what can I sayâ€¦I love layers. 
I have some frocks that are seasonal, but many of my clothes remain in my wardrobe all year round.
This is probably my favourite and most worn frock. I made it in the spring of 2021 during a covid lockdown and wore it the day my shop reopenedâ€¦so itâ€™s a bit special. 
This frock is my own pattern and made from a pair of 1970s barkcloth curtains and some vintage gingham. 
As you can see I wear this all year long, either with a tee shirt for warm weather or layered up for colder days. The majority of the jackets and accessories I either made or are thrifted.
Iâ€™ve included 10 ways of wearing it including one on the beach at Sheringham with the lovely @justjillrosalind 
#sewover50 
#sewover50october #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashion #repurpose #reuse @slowfashionchallenge #slowfashionmovement #ageismisneverinstyle #dopaminedressing #dopaminesewing

I love hats so I am always excited when it cool enough to wear a beretâ€¦and this is my new one. This is a thrifted yellow beret that I appliquÃ©d with felt oak leaves in autumnal huesâ€¦then added a big pompomâ€¦as you do. I found the little wooden leaves on the front at The Works and just stitched them on. 
The jacket I up cycled from a thrifted manâ€™s needlecord shirt.  The frock is made from a vintage Collier Campbell curtain and the pattern is from the #sweetdressbook by #yoshikotsukiori worn with my recently repaired jeans.
With the cooler weather coming Iâ€™ve been making some infinity scarves from old tee shirts. These are proving to be really useful.
#sewover50 #sewover50october #beret #aplique #handembroidery #embroidery #upcycledclothing #upcycledtextiles #sustainablestyle #ilovehats #ageismisneverinstyle

Well itâ€™s day 1 of #slowfashionchallenge2023 and the prompt is intro.
My name is Marcia and I now live in Bury St Edmunds. My entire working life I did administrative jobs I didnâ€™t really enjoy so when I retired I decided to have fun. I did what I always wanted to do and started dealing in antiquesâ€¦I am now the proud owner of Smoking Monkey Antiquesâ€¦best job in the world.
My other passion is sewing, I make the majority of my clothes from second hand or vintage fabrics, a lot of my clothes have had a previous life as soft furnishings. 
I also have a wonderful collection of old doll houses which give me a great deal of pleasure.
As you can see my life revolves around old stuff!
I think it is so important to show that slow fashion is not only beneficial to the planet but actually far more fun than the alternatives.
Todays pictures are taken by the canal at Shardlow, lots of beautiful old buildings and peeling paint. 
@slowfashionchallenge 
#sewover50 #sewover50october #slowfashion #slowfashionmovement #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #slowfashionmovement #ageismisneverinstyle

Another day another beach hut and look who Iâ€™m sharing it with today, only the lovely @judithrosalind 
We spent such a nice day with Judith and Robert and believe me there was plenty to talk about. 
Just in case you were wondering why we are so colour coordinated, Judith posted a picture earlier of her holiday wardrobe so I knew exactly what colours to wearâ€¦and we knew exactly which beach hut to use.
Although I regularly pose in front of beach huts today was the first time I have ever sat in oneâ€¦it was surprisingly excitingâ€¦thank you Judith for letting me sit in yours.
My frock is one of my favourites, made from a 1970s curtain and some old brown ginghamâ€¦itâ€™s my own pattern. The tee shirt is thrifted and I made the petticoat from rust covered broderie anglaise. 
Judithâ€™s frock was gorgeous, made from lovely striped linen.

Last week I rather foolishly tripped down the terrace steps at Ickworth House. Luckily just a grazed knee and a fair bit of bruisingâ€¦however the up side of this fiasco was the opportunity to mend my jeans. The embroidery on this pair of thrifted jeans was a lockdown project and I decided to patch them with a smiley face sunshine. The rays are a circle of feather stitch extended with chain stitches. As I tend to fall over quite frequently I am already planning a moon for the other knee.
The pinafore is made from a 1970s barkcloth curtain. I knit the cardigan many years ago using a 1970s pattern.

Seven years ago this weekend was the beginning of Smoking Monkey Antiques. We kicked off with a party on the Friday evening and had the official opening on the Saturday. What larks we have had over the last seven years!
I thought Iâ€™d go for a bit of mixing patterns today. The jacket is a recent reworking of a thrifted 1990s floral shirt. 
The pinafore is a reworking of the frock I made for Rosaâ€™s wedding. It was such nice fabric it seemed a waste not to be wearing it. 
I made the slacks from yellow linen many years ago.
The shoes are Josef Seibel.

Back at the shop today after three wonderful days with Rosa and Rufus. 
Celebrating #secondhandseptember in all preloved items. I make the majority of my clothes from vintage or secondhand fabric and this frock is made from old cushion covers. I wanted a frock with a sort of nautical look so I made a pattern based on those 1980s sailor frocks. 
The red petticoat is made from cotton broderie anglaise.
The T-shirt, scarf, jewellery and shoes are all thrifted.
#sewover50 #sewover50september #so50reworn #secondhand #secondhandstyle #sustainablestyle #sustainablefashion #upcycledfashion #secondhandnotsecondbest #ageingwithattitude #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #grannychic

Iâ€™ve made a new winter pinafore. Iâ€™ve had this gorgeous piece of brushed cotton for a little while and it just seemed perfect for this time of year. 
I used my usual pinafore pattern and just managed to squeeze out the pieces but I did have to piece together the bodice piecesâ€¦absolutely nothing left! I lined the bodice with a piece of old curtain lining.
Itâ€™s now getting cooler so Iâ€™m able to indulge my love of layering. The sweater is a hand me down from him indoors, it just needed shortening. The coat is a #pilvicoat from the #lottajansdotter book, made from some 1970s cotton velvet, one of my most worn coats.
The petticoat is made from a piece of wide broderie anglaise. The black felt hat is an old M&S one I bought recently from a vintage shop

It will come as no surprise that I am a huge fan of second hand and vintage shopping so I am very excited to be working on a little #secondhandseptember project with @officialoxfamsudbury . More will be revealed soon. 
Back to todayâ€¦we visited the totally weird Landguard Fort. Fascinating history and gorgeous flaky paintwork.
This is my autumnal coloured patchwork frock made from an old linen frock that no longer fit and scraps from my stash. The sweater is a thrifted piece of knitted fabric that I just managed to squeeze a top out of.
The Clarkâ€™s sandals were found on EBay and the accessories were all thrifted.

locationName: Castle Acre Castle and town walls
caption:
Firstly, thank you for all the good wishes when I wasnâ€™t wellâ€¦greatly appreciated. 
This is my entry for #magamscroungingseptember I didnâ€™t exactly scrounge this fabric from my friend @justjillrosalind but I did pester a bit till she sold it to me! This was originally a loose cover that Jill painstakingly unpicked, then all I had to do is piece it together to make a pinafore. The pattern is one I took from a 1990s Gap pinafore. The bindings are made from a thrifted gingham shirt. The fabric is a vintage Sanderson and such a beautiful blue. There are lots of small bits left that I am hoping to piece together and make a little jacket. 
The jeans are thrifted which I recently appliquÃ©d with blue flowers. 
The jacket is made from old mattress ticking and is one of my most worn garments.
Scarf, hat and bag are also thrifted. #secondhandseptember for me is all about making stuff from secondhand fabricsâ€¦which actually is such fun.
@suestoney @sewing_in_spain @anakiequilter

Just to prove Iâ€™ve been to Great Malvern this is me next to one of their famous wells, this one is in the town centre. Malvern is a beautiful spa town, pretty buildings, nice vintage and charity shops and good cafes. We stayed in a very picturesque Airbnb and explored the area and went to an 80th birthday partyâ€¦back to work today.
This frock is made from a really beautiful old Sanderson curtain. The pattern is from the Sweet Dress Book by #yoshikotsukiori . I lengthened this  one, dyed some cotton lace to match and added some hand embroidery.
Just in case you were wondering I did not take the waters, although I did see people filling their bottles here.

Oooh my #WomanCrushWednesday lives in a different hemisphere and is currently the joy of Spring to my cozy Autumn. This truly brought me happiness to put together. 

Itâ€™s @dreams.in.colour Based in Melbourne, Fran brings her radiant style to life by championing Australian & independent global brands and showcasing the art of dopamine dressing. Her feed is an explosion of vibrant outfits, playful patterns, and the perfect dose of whimsy-each post feels like a celebration of joy itself. Beyond her bold fashion choices, Fran also shares personal snippets and candid insights, making her account feel like catching up with a friend. Whether sheâ€™s layering unexpected prints or embracing bold accessories, Franâ€™s unique approach is all about lifting spirits, expressing herself, and connecting with her followers. Follow her for a daily dose of happiness and heartfelt style!

Today wasnâ€™t the day weâ€™d planned as some outdoor antiques events were cancelled due to wet weather. However I managed some indoor foraging and later met friends in Aldeburghâ€¦so a very pleasant Sunday.
Todayâ€™s picture is on the front at Aldeburgh where it was pretty gustyâ€¦but not raining.
This jacket is made from a 1960s Sanderson curtain. Sanderson took the William Morris design and dyed the fabric some amazing vivid colours including this bright green. I based the pattern on the coat dress from #stylishwraps by #yoshikotsukiori I lengthened the bodice, added a frill and then another frill to the collar.
The frock is my own pattern made in linen gingham I bought online during lockdown.

To celebrate World Embroidery day I thought Iâ€™d show you the progress on my new embroidered jeans. The jeans were thrifted and the denim is beautifully soft and faded. I wanted to stick to a blue colour palette so Iâ€™m using up a lot of old Laura Ashley scraps Iâ€™ve had for years, with blue, green and yellow stranded thread. Iâ€™m keeping it simple with chain stitch, blanket stitch and French knots. At this stage Iâ€™m not entirely sure where itâ€™s going yet but Iâ€™m having fun.
I thought Iâ€™d wear an embroidered frock today too with embroidered tucks and pockets. I think pockets really lend themselves to a little embroideryâ€¦a very manageable size and shape.

Very excited to finish my appliquÃ© jeans, probably a bit warm for them todayâ€¦but I wanted to wear them.
I found these well worn jeans on a charity shop sale rail for Â£1, the denim is so soft and the fit is goodâ€¦perfect for embellishment. I have been looking at a lot of appliquÃ© clothes recently on Pinterest so I thought this might be fun. I backed the shapes with iron on interfacing and attached them with blanket stitch. The stems are three rows of chain stitch. When they start to wear I will add more patches in the same colour palette.
I taught myself to smock a few years ago and this frock is my first attempt. I made this up as I went alongâ€¦there isnâ€™t a pattern.

What an evening! On Wed night we hosted a panel talk at @somersethouse on â€˜Redesigning Your Wedding Dressâ€™ with the most inspiring speakers @carolinearthurbridal @robertastylelee @studio.kuhu @what_chloe_thrifts 

It was such an insightful evening discussing all the things that you can do with your wedding dress - from a simple redesign to using natural dye (with the flowers from your bouquet!), transforming a family heirloom, knitting a jumper from the scraps or even turning the remnants into Christmas baubles which can be cherished forever! 

We will be uploading a full recording of the talk within the next week which we canâ€™t wait to share with you. If youâ€™d like to enquire about redesign your wedding dress, you can simply #PostYourProject via the link in bio or send us a DM #UpcycleWithLoom #SustainableBridal #BridalUpcycle #CircularFashion

I do love an herbaceous border and this one at Oxburgh House is no exception. 
Last year I acquired another wonderful Japanese sewing book #cottonfriendsewing , they are lovely basic patterns and beautifully styled. I really loved this simple pullover pattern, a nice relaxed shape. As I know my body shape is different to the model l made the pattern out of old curtain lining so it was easy to get the fit I wanted. The fabric was donated to the fabric swap at our recent get togetherâ€¦so if it was you, thank you. I also managed to get an infinity scarf out of the fabric as well.
I often pick up old fashioned knitted blankets in charity shops which I am intending to dye and make up using this patternâ€¦they will be really useful layering pieces for the colder weather.
The frock is a big tiered shape made from vintage cotton.

My self love journey has been a long one. Holidays are always a time when I reflect on my relationship with my body. 

Today I can rock a bikini showing cellulite, rolls, jiggly arms, stretch marks and still feel sexy. I can see myself from a side angle and not be horrified by the fact that I am not flat. Truth be told I am the most confident I have ever been!

At the end of the carousel I included some pics of 13 year old Amy. (10 WHOLE YEARS AGO.) So desperate to look as skinny as possible and not eating before taking photos to avoid any bloating. Saving posing ideas stolen from the Kardashianâ€™s. All with the aim of making my waist as small as possible. 

Every day when I look in the mirror I am kind to my body. I point out all the things I love. And try to work on the areas I am learning to love. Your thoughts are so so powerful. 

I am perfect the way I am. ğŸ’™

Meet THE linen set of the summer 

(AD/PR) @second_stories__ has only gone and made the most beautiful linen shirt and skirt set Iâ€™ve ever laid eyes on. Meet the Penelope blouse and skirt ğŸ˜ this is  an absolute dream to wear, the embroidery, hand done cut out details and quality are unbelievable ğŸ‘Œ I love it worn as a set but it also works so well as separates and you can create lots of great summer outfits from these pieces. Hereâ€™s a few styling ideas and more info on the set below. 

Each piece is available to order as individuals so you can choose one or both, I personally would recommend them as a set though ğŸ˜‰ the skirt is made to measure (and has pockets of course!) and the shirt is one size 8-14 but likewise the fit can be adjusted to your measurements too! If youâ€™d like it longer/shorter, a different colour or embroidered to create something unique let Nicci know and she and her team will create you a one of a kind piece you can wear year after year. 

Thatâ€™s the joy of made to order, sustainable small brand purchases, the quality, the personal experience, the uniqueness of the final product. These sets take 4-6 weeks to receive from ordering so donâ€™t sleep on it and best of all you can use the discount code KAT25 to get Â£25 off the skirt and/or the shirt so you can save a total of Â£50 until next Saturday â˜ºï¸

#summerstyle #sustainablefashion #linenlover #embroideredclothing #slowfashionstyle

It was party time today, my dear friend Pat is 90 and we had a lovely party in her garden. Sadly I didnâ€™t take any pictures!

We are in Rutland for a long weekend and currently staying in a beautiful cottage in Uppingham, such a beautiful little town.
Todayâ€™s excursion was to Kirby Hall, one of the most beautiful abandoned and derelict houses I have ever seen. The building was started in 1570 but was later abandoned. It is so picturesque with plenty of niches to pose for photos!
It was very warm today so Iâ€™m wearing one of my hot weather frocks. Itâ€™s my own pattern with cap sleeves, a full tiered skirt and a big bow at the back. The fabric is a vintage printed cotton.
#sewover50 #sewover50june #so50reworn #summerfrock #summerfrocks #sustainablesewing #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #memadewardrobe #imakemyclothes #grannychic

I will admit to looking a bit folksy today which sort of leads me to a conversation I had earlier. A customer was wondering why I added hand stitching to my clothes as this could make them look homemade.
Itâ€™s actually a fair question but I think the point is do I want to look like Iâ€™m wearing shop bought clothes or am I happy for people to know Iâ€™ve made them myself. 
I make my own clothes for many reasons, the pleasure of sewing and the creativity, not having to wear what someone else thinks I should, plus itâ€™s fun!
I know most of my clothes donâ€™t look shop bought and this makes me very happy. I enjoy foraging for beautiful old textiles and turning them into folksy clothes it is definitely more fun than civilian shoppingâ€¦and possibly more sustainable. 
I think why we make our own clothes is such a vast and varied topic and one that really interests me.
Todays frock is made from vintage brushed cotton and some dyed cotton lace, it is 1970s Butterick 4317 with added frills. Itâ€™s worn over a vintage white frilly skirt.
#sewover50 #sewover50july #so50sustainablesewing #so50reworn #imakemyclothes #handmadewardrobe #sustainablesewing #handstitching #handmadeclothing #grannychic #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood

Thought Iâ€™d just show you my reworked summer basket. Iâ€™ve had this many years, the lining was ripped and stained the straw handles were broken and it needed a bit of a facelift. So I raided my stash and made pompoms out of old sock yarn, relined it with a damaged vintage apron (even used the pocket), the straps were left from my Christmas bag making extravaganza and I added a few old buttons just for fun. This should now see me through a few more summers.
Todays frock is a vintage cotton made from a 1970s Butterick 4317 with two added frills. Decluttering part 1 

My overconsumption strikes again. I've found myself holding onto those pieces that I probably won't wear again, either they're not my style anymore or they simply just do not fit, just for the 'what if' in the future - IT NEEDS TO STOP

I want to get better at curating instead of just buying because its cheap and because I want it, not because I need it. I'm stuck in an endless cycle with this and want to try and make changes â™»ï¸

This is a really good exercise to participate in during secondhand September, selling on resale sites like Vinted, Ebay or through Facebook Marketplace, swapping with friends or at an event, or donating to charity shops 

#secondhandseptember #declutter #clearout #vinted

I am seeing a lot of talk around wearing VS styling. On an every day basis I feel like I just wear my clothes, throwing on whatever is clean and comfy. But I really am trying to get better, and wear outfits that make me feel confident every day. Adding on a pair of sunglasses and cute bag really do help the outfit feel more intentional and I am enjoying the results.

These added extras donâ€™t have to cost a lot. My bag and sunglasses were only Â£1 each!! So next time you are in a charity shop be sure to check the baskets of glasses and shelf of handbags. ğŸ•¶ï¸ğŸ‘œ

Carrying on from my previous post Iâ€™m hand stitching againâ€¦and lots of it!
I found a lovely pair of jeans in a charity shop for Â£1â€¦beautifully soft and a perfect fit. The last two pairs l embroidered were just around the turn ups so I thought I would start going up the legs this time. This is just the start and I am not yet sure where it is goingâ€¦I will post updates in my stories.
I have a lot of tiny pieces of printed cotton in my stash so I sorted out the bluish bits and some matching threads. I am backing the cotton pieces in lightweight iron on interfacing and attaching them with blanket stitch. I decided to undo the inside legs to make it easier to work with. I do love a big embroidery project.
