Slow fashion and sunshine? â˜€ï¸âœ¨ yes please! I stopped by @percy.langley before going on holiday and was impressed by how â€œtrendlessâ€ the shop is - and thatâ€™s a great complement in my books!

Donâ€™t get me wrong, everything there is gorgeous but itâ€™s also very timeless and can navigate so well between seasons. When you compare it to the fast fashion model and their 52 seasons - which btw is absolutely dumb and unnecessary, you can see why youâ€™d start buying less and start saving money, even with a higher price tag ğŸŒ¿

Tee - @percy.langley in collaboration with Studio AK Threads, clothing made by communities of women who support a conscious, compassionate, and circular future in the textile industry.

Shorts - @saywood.studio Made in small volumes, from dead stock and eco-friendly fabrics, their emphasis is on quality designs that last, but leave as little mark as possible on our planet through all stages of their lifecycle.

Sunglasses - @zoedepass_eyewear Handmade from premium acetate with strong, unique lenses, ZoÃ« de Pass frames are built to last.

Blouse - @the.wellworn made vintage and deadstock fabrics. The Well Worn also mends and upcycle vintage clothing and giving these garments a new lease of life, they help to keep them out of the landfill and contribute to a more sustainable future.

Although I have many frocks that I wear all year, I have a few that only feel right on warm sunny daysâ€¦ and this is one of them. I made this a couple of years ago using a couple of old cotton tablecloths. It is based on the tunic dress pattern in the Japanese Sweet Dress sewing book, I altered the armholes, lengthened it and added embroidery to the tucks and pockets. 
The necklace is another of the crochet ones someone made for me a few years ago.

We had a lovely weekend celebrating Rufusâ€™s first birthday followed by a trip to Wimpole Hall on the way home. The gardens were beautiful and the chapel was beautifully cool. This picture was taken in Richmond before we leftâ€¦and before it got very hot!
This is one of the frocks I made last year for the very warm weather, basically itâ€™s a long roomy frock made from vintage printed cotton, with cap sleeves and a big bow on the backâ€¦not even a petticoat! The jacket is based on the coat dress pattern from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps, itâ€™s made from some old ticking.
#sewover50june #sewover50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #vintagefabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #japanesesewingbooks #yoshikotsukiori #grannychic #handmadewardrobe #memadeeveryday

Unsurprisingly I really enjoyed yesterdayâ€™s @britishsewingbee as I love sewing with upcycled fabrics. These days many people tend to change their interiors quite frequently so household linens such as curtains, bedding and tablecloths are frequently discarded and end up in charity shops. 
Today (middle picture) is a frock made from a discarded duvet cover, itâ€™s a simple shape with buttons all the way down the back. There is so much fabric in a double duvet cover, and often the front and back are contrasting patterns which can be great fun to work with. 
Iâ€™ve included other recent pictures of clothes that have been made from household linens over the last few years.
Itâ€™s both fun and sustainableâ€¦whatâ€™s not to like.
#sewover50june #so50reworn #sewsustainable #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #upcycledtextiles #upcycledfabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #memadewardrobe #handmadewardrobe #grannychic #oldladiesrock #reducereuserecycle

We had a lovely day in Kings Lynn yesterday, such an ancient and interesting town. Apart from the obvious beautiful old buildings there are so many interesting and pretty little alleysâ€¦I love an alley! 
I am standing in front of an incredible steel sculpture on the South Quay. It represents the racks that were used for drying fish in parts of Norway.
Todays frock was made from a pair of 1970s barkcloth curtains, worn over a waist slip made from rust coloured broderie anglaise. I knit the cardigan several years ago from a 1970s pattern. #sewover50 #so50reworn #sustainablefashion #sustainablesewing #vintagefabric #wearwhatmakesyouhappy #wearwhatmakesyoufeelgood #grannychic #yesiamwearinganoldcurtain #upcycledfabric

On IG recently Iâ€™ve noticed a lot of what my friend Sorrel @slowsewmo calls â€œwalk awayâ€ frocks, so I thought Iâ€™d try making one. I love a pinafore and a big bow and as this combines them both I definitely thought it was worth a go. 
When we had the fabric swap table at our recent sewing get together Lucie @nelliefromthefarm left this gorgeous fabricâ€¦it was love at first sightâ€¦thank you Lucie.
I used my usual bodice pattern but added to the sides so it would wrap around. The ribbon is attached to the back, crossed over at the front then joins the ties to make a bow. I bound the armholes and neck and added some hand stitching. Obviously I also added some nice big pockets.

The more I learn about fashion and meet truly well dressed and chic women, more obvious it becomes that micro trends, â€œmust havesâ€ and overconsumption are the exact opposite of genuine style.

These characters main relationship with fashion was purely about glamourising shopping, selling us the myth that a wardrobe overflowing with new clothes is the key to looking stylish or loving fashion. They pushed the notion that fashion is exclusive to a certain type of person, and that somehow, buying more would solve all of lifeâ€™s problems - cue the cringeworthy concept of â€œretail therapy.â€ ğŸ« 

But letâ€™s be real: constantly refreshing your wardrobe with the latest trends wonâ€™t give you true style. Trends are marketing tools, designed to drive sales and boost profits. When we chase after every new trend, we often prioritize consumerism over our own values and personal expression.

Whatâ€™s your take - do you still have style icons and like to follow trends or prefer do trust and invest in your own personal style? âœ¨ #sustainablefashion #timelessfashion #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion

Having a digitalised wardrobe means you can see what you've got without being overwhelmed with that 'I've got nothing to wear feeling' and wanting to add new items to your wardrobe. 

I'm an avid thrifter and even my overconsumption is terrible, but I'm trying to change that and having the option to style my items and have a record of what I've worn is so fun 

I can't promise I'll be doing an outfit each day this month because life is busy but I want to try and share some tips for any who may be wanting to make changes to their shopping habits while encouraging myself to do the same

The most important step we can take towards ditching fast fashion is rewiring the way we think about the constant barrage of trends and must haves force fed to us everyday. 

And no, these brands are not â€œcheapâ€ - theyâ€™re fairly priced. You might have to save a little to buy some of their pieces, but youâ€™re not supposed to be buying as many clothes as you are!  Wear what you already own, swap and buy secondhand first and foremost, but if you need a few new clothes, these are great brands to fall back into ğŸŒ¿

Letâ€™s stop making excuses for fast fashion giants. You canâ€™t pay the same price for sustainable and ethical clothes, because you can only buy that cheap is through an exploitative system and this is what weâ€™re fighting against ğŸ–¤

#ethicalfashion #sustainablefashion #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #fashionrevolution

Becoming a conscious shopper is a journey that starts with awareness and research. By dedicating some time to understand where to shop and which brands to support, you contribute to a more sustainable and ethical fashion industry. 

A general rule to apply when researching whether a brand is sustainable, is that if itâ€™s difficult to find its credentials, chances are they arenâ€™t as green as they claim to be.

Ask questions, learn, and gradually build a collection of trusted, sustainable brands. Remember, your choices matter, and every sustainable purchase is a step towards a greener planet! âœ¨ ğŸŒ¿

#ethicalfashion #sustainablefashion #whomademyclothes #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #fashionrevolution

This one is for the girlies who say â€œsome people can only afford fast fashion!â€ ğŸ˜’ hun, @anthropologie @freepeople @andotherstories @arketofficial @oliverbonas and other boho coded brands are fast fashion!!! 

And I donâ€™t know about you but these are are crazy expensive to me. If you have the budget to buy at any of these brands, you have no excuse to not shop from sustainable brands âœ¨ ğŸŒ¿

#ethicalfashion #sustainablefashion #consumerism #slowfashion #breakupwithfastfashion #fashionrevolution

This is an â€œus problemâ€ ğŸ˜” We are always blaming companies for all the waste and impact of the industry, but each and every one of us has an equal responsibility to protect and preserve our planet and the people that inhabit it. Fast fashion companies thrive off our demand as consumers, so to address the problem we need to address our own addiction.
ã€°ï¸

We as consumers need to remember that we all have a voice and we need to use it to demand immediate change. By changing perceptions on our wardrobes and on sustainable fashion, we can collectively make steps towards a circular economy, in which we keep resources in use for as long as possible ğŸ–¤â€¢

In a world where fashion trends change faster than the seasons, our closets often overflow with barely worn items. The fast fashion industry has made it easy to over consume, creating a throwaway culture and leading to a significant environmental impact.Â 

A fun way and community-driven solution to combat this is hosting a clothing swap event. Not only does it help in reducing waste, but it also fosters a sense of community and promotes sustainable fashion practices.Â 

Continue reading at thefairedit.com ğŸŒ¿ link in bio!

â€¢
â€¢

#ecomadesimple #sustainablefashion #zerowaste #sustainableliving #sustainability

Can we normalise borrowing clothes? We all have a friend whoâ€™s wardrobe we drool over and @crystal_nightingale_style is definitely one of mine âœ¨

On average, each Londoner buys 48 new items of clothing every year but also discards 44 items annually. This means weâ€™re adding a 155,000 tonnes of new clothes to our wardrobes each year â€“ thatâ€™s a pile of clothes more than 1 kilometre taller than the London Eye! At the same time, 142,000 tonnes of clothes are being thrown away, and sadly, less than 10% of the clothes we donate or put in recycling bins actually get reused in London. 

But hereâ€™s the easy fix: if each of us swapped out just 12 new items for second-hand instead and repaired only 5% of the garments already in our wardrobe, we could significantly cut down the cityâ€™s carbon footprint by an incredible 30%! 

Buying secondhand, renting, swapping and of course borrowing from stylish friends should be the main way we fill up our wardrobes to have a meaningful impact on the environment ğŸŒ¿ 
Would you lend or borrow clothes from friends or family?Â 

ğŸŒğŸ’š #SustainableFashion #EcoFriendly #ReduceReuseRecycle #LondonLife #SustainableLiving

Even though I love shopping, I also enjoy the concept of shopping within our own wardrobes. Not only is it sustainable, but itâ€™s also great for our wallets! 

While buying new clothes is fun, the truth is many new purchases are quite similar to what we already own. Rediscovering ways to style old clothes can be a great styling exercise. Trust me, one can â€œlookâ€ stylish if theyâ€™re mindless jumping from trend to trend and buying huge amounts of clothes âœ¨

#fashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #whomademyclothes

â€œBut sustainable fashion is not size inclusive, blablabla, same old, defends fast fashion ğŸ¤ªâ€œ Iâ€™m a size UK 14-16 and I have larger hips, still Iâ€™ve not once had any issues finding secondhand clothes on my size. 

While itâ€™s true that sustainable brands struggle to produce a wide range of sizes, buying new eco-friendly clothes is not the only way to have a sustainable wardrobe ğŸŒ¿ Buy less, take care of the clothes you have, swap and shop secondhandâ€¦ thatâ€™s how you can make fashion sustainable â£ï¸

#sustainablefashion #whomademyclothes #ethicalfashion #timelessfashion #thrifted

Would you like to learn more about making a difference with your fashion & style choices? Donâ€™t know where to start as it all feels really overwhelming? (Hello greenwashing, and conflicting information!) 

So excited to announce our next Sustainable Style event for the St Albans Sustainability Expo will be an incredible Fashion Panel on Saturday 8th June at 11am at Alban Arena in St Albans. 

We have an amazing panel of experts lined up for you, and weâ€™ll be discussing the topic of sustainability in the fashion industry. 

How do we make a difference as one person and what can we do to improve our consumption habits for a better future for people and planet? These are a couple of the questions that will be addressed with our expert panel spanning fashion industry experts, influencer, brand owner and charity expert. Topics will include fabrics, secondhand fashion, supply chains and psychology/buying behaviour.

Read on for information on our fabulous speakers:
Alex Standley Personal Stylist @luxeleopardlifestyle 

Katie Carr Sustainable Brand Founder @tommyandlottie 

Beatrice Turner Ethical Fashion Influencer @beatriceturner 

Gemma Metheringham Ex Creative Director Fashion @the_elephant_in_my_wardrobe

Emma Thompson Director of Marketing @rgphospice 

This is a FREE event organised as part of Sust Fest Expo supporting @sustainablesta. So mark your diaries and save the date to come and join us. 

Plus you can have a browse at the same time of all of the fabulous sustainable stalls and other events happening at the expo!

I see this comment a lot: â€œI canâ€™t find cute clothes secondhand so I have to buy from ~ insert ultra fast fashion brand ~â€

Hhmmmâ€¦ WHAT? Are you ok?  The privilege of prioritizing personal style over the ethical treatment of garment workers is jarring.

Brands undoubtedly bear responsibility for their practices, from exploiting labour to environmental impact. However, consumers must also acknowledge their role. Every purchase fuels a system, either perpetuating unethical practices or supporting sustainable alternatives. Itâ€™s time to recognize the power in our choices and demand accountability from both brands and ourselves. 

Remember, every time you shop, you cast a vote for the kind of world you want to live in. Letâ€™s make it one where human rights and sustainability arenâ€™t compromised for the sake of fleeting trends ğŸ–¤

#fashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #whomademyclothes

Why do we donate our unwanted things? It could be out of altruism, or maybe itâ€™s about easing our guilt (or perhaps a bit of both). Shockingly only between 10 and 30% of second-hand donations to charity shops are resold in store. The rest disappears into a vast sorting apparatus to be graded and sold on to commercial partners, often for export. 

I am NOT saying you should just send it all to landfill but instead of just dropping off items without thinking, letâ€™s consider the impact of our choices. Investing in quality pieces for a capsule wardrobe means youâ€™ll enjoy them for years to come. Plus, when youâ€™re ready for a change, they can easily find new homes. Here are some more tips:

ğŸŒ¿ Repair and Mend: Instead of discarding items at the first sign of wear and tear, consider repairing them. Learning basic sewing skills or finding a local tailor can extend the life of your favorite pieces.

ğŸŒ¿ Clothes Swaps: Host or participate in clothing swap events with friends or in your community. Itâ€™s a fun way to refresh your wardrobe without spending a dime and gives your clothes a new home.

ğŸŒ¿ Upcycling: Unleash your creativity and transform unwanted clothes into something new and exciting! From adding unique touches to creating entirely new pieces, the possibilities are endless.

Donâ€™t forget to hit that follow button for more tips and tricks on sustainable living! â™»ï¸âœ¨ 

#sustainablestyle #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #aestheticedit

Here are three simple steps to help you make the switch to a more sustainable wardrobe:

ğŸŒ¿ 1: Unsubscribe from fast fashion newsletters and email lists. By cutting off the constant stream of tempting deals and promotions, youâ€™ll be less tempted to make impulse purchases that contribute to the cycle of overconsumption and waste.

ğŸŒ¿ 2: Take a critical look at the brands and influencers you follow on social media, and unfollow those that prioritise profit over ethical and sustainable practices. Instead, try to support companies that are transparent about their supply chain, use eco-friendly materials, and prioritize fair labour practices.

ğŸŒ¿ 3: Embrace ethical and sustainable fashion choices by shopping mindfully. Invest in high-quality, timeless pieces that are made to last, rather than trendy items that quickly go out of style. Consider shopping second-hand or supporting independent designers who prioritize sustainability.

By taking these steps, youâ€™ll not only reduce your environmental impact but also support a fashion industry that values people and the planet over profit.
#sustainablewear #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion

Yes, you read that correctly: $800 SHEIN Haul ğŸ¤¯ The average fast fashion consumer is 35, earns over $65k and spends a minimum of $100 a month on clothes. Still, every single time I advocate for quitting fast fashion, Iâ€™m bombarded with the same tired excuse: â€œbut some people can only afford fast fashion.â€ 

Fact: Some folks are barely scraping by, deciding between clothes and basic necessities like food. But if youâ€™re buying consciously, opting for a few quality pieces youâ€™ll wear repeatedly, youâ€™re not the issue here! They are NOT the reason the fashion industry is one of the most unethical and pollutant on the planet.

My point is, no one needs a closet bursting with new clothes every season. If you can drop $800 on summer attire, you sure as hell can invest in sustainable options - itâ€™s just a matter of priorities!

tâ€™s time we stop glorifying wardrobes full of crappy clothing and influencers still pushing this toxic consumerism ğŸ¤® #quitfastfashion #fashionrevolution #sustainablefashion

The sun has been shining and Spring is definitely in the air and thoughts are turning to possible additions to our Summer wardrobes. I actually went to work without a coat yesterday although there were times when I did regret it!
This patchwork pinafore is one I made a couple of years ago and is one I wear all year round, either with a tee shirt or fairisle sweaterâ€¦but always with a petticoat. This is my usual pattern but I decided I wanted a wrap over top and side button fastenings. 
The bodice and pockets were made from an old linen frock that no longer fit, and all of the squares are pieces from my stashâ€¦some of which I have had for many years. 
As for Summer sewing I am experimenting with some little linen tops to wear over my pinafores in the warmer weatherâ€¦watch this space.
Something else I find useful for this inbetween weather are the little cotton jersey circle scarves, I made these from old tee shirts, so quick to make and so easy to wear.

How can we shop more consciously and choose fashion items that match our values? 

Want to shop with a conscience and align your fashion choices with your values? Start by digging into brandsâ€™ backgrounds, staying alert to subtle cues, and actively seeking answers, even if theyâ€™re not readily available. Here are some tips for your next shopping spree:

ğŸŒ¿ Do your homework: Before hitting that buy button, check out the brandâ€™s website or peruse their corporate responsibility report to learn about their social and environmental commitments.

ğŸŒ¿ Check the label: Take a peek at what your clothes are made of. Different materials have different impacts, and items made with a single material are generally easier to recycle. Look for certifications like Cradle to Cradle Certifiedâ„¢, Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS), FairtradeÂ®, OEKO-TEXÂ®, and others for better practices.

ğŸŒ¿ Opt for organic: When it comes to cotton or natural fibers, go organic. Theyâ€™re gentler on biodiversity since they donâ€™t involve toxic chemicals in their production.

ğŸŒ¿ Speak up: Canâ€™t find the sustainability info youâ€™re after? Donâ€™t hesitate to ask a salesperson or reach out to the brand via email or social media. Your inquiry could spark some serious internal reflection.

What other steps are you taking to make your shopping habits more sustainable? Drop your tips in the comments below! ğŸŒ± 

#sustainablewear #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion

The comments and lack of empathy I get on some of my posts are scary but not surprising. Too many people completely miss the point, even though it doesnâ€™t take two neurones to understand that the work conditions in those videos are horrific regardless of the circumstances. Trying to justify the unethical practices and the way fashion is currently produced is unacceptable.

The reality is that money talks. If you stop buying from brands that produce their clothes this way, they will most definitely get the message! They will ensure factories are providing safe working conditions, fair wages and environmentally responsible practices. 

So I repeat: ITâ€™S TIME TO QUIT FAST FASHION! Period, end of story. ğŸŒ¿ğŸ’š #sustainablewear #slowfashionrevolution #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage

When was the last time you considered the impact of your purchases on the planet and society? ğŸŒ¿Sustainability goes beyond buying sustainable items. Hereâ€™s a few steps to become a more mindful shopper:

1ï¸âƒ£ Think Before You Buy: Pause before adding to your cart. Ask yourself if the item truly adds value to your life beyond the initial excitement. 

2ï¸âƒ£ Shop Consciously: Support brands committed to sustainability and slow fashion. Look for quality materials, zero waste policies, and efforts to reduce environmental impact.

3ï¸âƒ£ Shop Less, But Better: Resist the allure of fast fashion bargains. Invest in pieces that align with your values and will last beyond a single season. 

4ï¸âƒ£ Take Good Care of Your Clothes: Extend the lifespan of your wardrobe staples through proper care. Learn how to maintain different fabrics and consider repair services when needed. 

5ï¸âƒ£ Think Circular: Embrace a circular economy by shopping secondhand, upcycling, or repairing items instead of discarding them. Reduce waste and minimize resource consumption. 

6ï¸âƒ£ Donate or Resell: Give your pre-loved items a new life by donating to charity or selling them through resale platforms. â™»ï¸

Remember, cheap often means unethical. Be mindful of the human and environmental costs behind steep discounts. Choose ethical brands that prioritize fair labor practices and sustainability. ğŸŒ 

ğŸ“¸ Aaron Weiss

#MindfulShopping #SustainableFashion #ConsciousConsumerism

Golden rule of thrifting: never skip on the homeware ğŸŒ¿ 

As the charity shops bring out all the Easter goodies, Iâ€™ve picked up these napkins and more candles for a charming and effortlessly chic DIY project. All you need is some baking paper and a hair or clothing iron (or a heat gun for those feeling fancy).

Iâ€™m absolutely smitten with the result! How about you? Are you tempted to give this a try?

#EcoChicDecor #GreenLivingSpaces #SustainableStyle #UpcycledHome  #ConsciousInteriors

Hey! This post is for anyone who buys more clothing than they need. If you rarely buy clothes and can only do so on a very small budget, keep scrolling. Iâ€™m not telling low-income folks, struggling to make ends meet, to purchase from a sustainable brand if fast fashion is the only thing they can afford. 

However, these are some of the fast fashion brands that thrives on overconsumption, relying on our excessive purchasing habits. And itâ€™s clear that many of us own more clothing than we truly need. These brands also consistently receive the lowest ratings on @goodonyou_app, which meticulously assesses companiesâ€™ environmental and social impact.

We are buying more clothes than ever, but weâ€™re wearing them a lot less. By being mindful of our purchasing decisions and opting for quality over quantity, we can contribute to a more sustainable and equitable fashion industry

If you want to shop more sustainably and stop supporting brands like these, make sure to follow me and check my previous posts for more tips ğŸ’šâœ¨ğŸŒ¿

Ditching fast fashion may seem daunting initially, but trust me, itâ€™s a decision that pays off. The best part? As well as making a difference for garment workers and the planet, you will experience positive changes in your life, too.Â 

âœ¨ Youâ€™ll find and embrace your own style âœ¨ 
Fast fashion keeps churning out new clothes to follow the ephemeral and quite frankly, boring trends. Gaslighting you into buying random clothes on an impulse. Well, I said goodbye to that chaos and hello to finding a style thatâ€™s truly me. 

ğŸ’°Youâ€™ll save money in the long run ğŸ’°
Okay, so sustainable clothes might cost a bit more upfront, but in the long run, theyâ€™re actually cheaper. Still, the average fast fashion consumer spends at least Â£100 a month in clothes and only wear each item 7 times! When you break free from that vicious cycle, you can invest in fewer but higher-quality garments that are actually made to last (yes, planned obsolescence is a thing in fast fashion).Â 

ğŸ’ƒğŸ» Youâ€™ll become even more creative ğŸ’ƒğŸ»
Bid farewell to the notion that an outfit can only be worn once for the â€˜gram. Embracing ethical fashion empowers you to explore the art of mixing and matching, breathing new life into your wardrobe with each innovative combination

ğŸŒ¿ Youâ€™ll open your eyes to more sustainable options, beyond your wardrobe ğŸŒ¿
Breaking up with fast fashion isnâ€™t just about clothesâ€”itâ€™s a lifestyle change. Iâ€™ve started paying more attention to the little things, like using reusable stuff and cooking with seasonal ingredients. Every little swap adds up, and it feels pretty awesome to know Iâ€™m making a difference

So yeah, breaking up with fast fashion has been one of the best decisions Iâ€™ve ever made. If youâ€™re thinking about doing the same, trust me, you wonâ€™t regret it! âœŒï¸ #BreakUpWithFastFashion #SustainableAF #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion

Wearing â€œtrendsâ€ doesnâ€™t have to mean sacrificing sustainability. Instead of contributing to the fast fashion industryâ€™s harmful practices, why not opt for secondhand pieces? ğŸŒ± Not only does this approach reduces waste, our carbon footprint and saves clothes from landfill, but it also adds a unique flair to your wardrobe.

By choosing pre-loved items, youâ€™re making a statement about conscious consumption and supporting a circular economy. Whether itâ€™s repairing and repurposing old favorites or exploring eco-friendly materials, there are countless ways to express your style while reducing your environmental impact.

Letâ€™s redefine what it means to be trendy and letâ€™s prioritise sustainability and creativity. ğŸ’š 
#SustainableStyle #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #SustainableFashion #thrifthaul #MindfulConsumption ğŸŒ±

Hi! Iâ€™m Bea and Iâ€™m here to de-influence you, so hop on if youâ€™re into making your wardrobe more sustainable ğŸ’š Whether itâ€™s repairing, reusing, swapping, embracing secondhand and vintage finds or buying from ethical brands, sustainable fashion encourages us to tread lightly on the Earth while expressing our individuality.

Letâ€™s consider the impact of our choices, not just on ourselves but on the broader ecosystem of fashion. Letâ€™s support brands that champion quality, ethics, and longevity, and letâ€™s redefine our relationship with fashion, one reel at a time.

Seriously, whatâ€™s stopping you from ditching fast fashion? ğŸ’«  I promise itâ€™s easier than you think. Here are some of the reasons why Iâ€™m head over heels for hitting up secondhand stores:

ğŸŒ¿ Saving money is just the beginning of the thrifting magic. Sure, this full outfit might have cost less than Â£100, but snagging a linen trench thatâ€™s Brand New With Tags for a fraction of the retail price? Best feeling! Plus, thrifted gems are typically way more budget-friendly than buying new stuff and you canâ€™t convince me otherwise.

ğŸŒ¿ Letâ€™s talk sustainability! Thrifting isnâ€™t just about revamping your wardrobe; itâ€™s about giving a second life to pre-loved pieces. By opting for thrifted finds, youâ€™re not only reducing waste but also minimizing the environmental footprint that comes with producing new clothes. Itâ€™s a win-win for Mother Earth and your style game!

ğŸŒ¿ Embrace your uniqueness! The thrill of finding that one-of-a-kind piece is unparalleled. Thrifting isnâ€™t just about following trends; itâ€™s about curating a style thatâ€™s uniquely yours. Each thrifted treasure tells a story and adds a dash of personality to your wardrobe. 

#ThriftLove #SustainableStyle #sustainablefashion #secondhandfirst #timelessfashion #modernvintage #streetstylelondon

Supporting small and ethical brands is amazing and important but sustainable fashion is not about buying eco-friendly clothing - itâ€™s about reducing overall consumption and waste. By making intentional choices about what you buy and how you wear it, you can make a big impact on both your wallet and the environment ğŸŒ¿âœ¨ğŸ¤

UNPOPULAR OPINION? ğŸ˜ ok, letâ€™s get realâ€¦ Fast fashion operates on a model built for speed and disposability. Garments are made at lightning speed, at the expense of worker rights and fair wages. The race to keep up with demand leads to unsafe sweatshop labor and exploitation in many parts of the world, including the UK.

And letâ€™s not forget the environmental toll. From toxic chemicals used in production to the massive carbon footprint of transportation and disposal, fast fashion is a major contributor to pollution and climate change. 

The truth is, fast fashion can never be sustainable or ethical. So, letâ€™s rethink our approach to buying clothes. Letâ€™s prioritize secondhand and choose quality over quantity, investing in timeless pieces that are ethically made and built to last. Letâ€™s support brands that value transparency, fair labor practices, and sustainability. And letâ€™s reject the notion that following trends blindly is cool. True style isnâ€™t about whatâ€™s hot this season â€” itâ€™s about expressing yourself authentically and responsibly. ğŸŒ¿ğŸ’š 

#SlowFashion #EthicalChoices #FashionRevolution #minimalstyle #slowfashion #sustainableliving #capsulewardrobe #slowliving #sustainablefashion #secondhand #thrifted #thriftedstyle

Seriously, Iâ€™m SO happy to have you here! Despite what you might think, having a timeless and mindful wardrobe is not hard at all. It just takes a little more thought and a perspective shift, but Iâ€™m here to help with that ğŸ¥° 

What is stopping you from having a more sustainable wardrobe? Let me know in the comments below.

Some tips on how to declutter consciously ğŸ‘—ğŸª‘ğŸ 

***

I'm starting the process of moving to a new flat and so I've been doing some decluttering. Here's some tips on what you can do with some of your unwanted stuff!

if you're downsizing your wardrobe, consider if you could make a few pennies from it. My preferred resale platform for high street fashion is @vinted because there's zero selling fees and shipping options like Evri are integrated within the app. If you're not running a business from it, I'd generally recommend listing stuff for max Â£10 per item, but I often go much lower as its just more likely to be bought faster.

For odd bits and bobs, I give away stuff to local residents for free using the @olio.app. It never fails to amaze me how quick things that I don't want anymore are reclaimed by other people, from old tea towels, to spare sandpaper and empty jars.

Finally, for furniture that's still in good shape, I list @facebookmarketplace

For all of the above, obviously keep your local charity shops and donation points in mind for good quality bits.

#slowfashion #alowfashionblogger #slowfashionstyle #slow-moving #springclean #springcleaning #decluttering #minimalism #minimalist #vintage #secondhand

Whilst clearing out a drawer in my sewing room I discovered this lovely red aran weight yarn, no idea what kind it is as I bought it in a charity shop a few years ago. 
This sweater is a good example of how simple knitting a sweater can be, very few shapings and fairly big needles (6.5mm). I am confident that if you can knit a scarf you could knit this sweater. It is based on a pattern I first knit in the late 1970s but didnâ€™t bother with the lace pattern. 
I decided to finish it off with an appliquÃ© heartâ€¦a you do.
The pinafore is my winter weight tartan flannel patchwork frock, itâ€™s also lined with red flannel so itâ€™s very cosy.
You may also notice Iâ€™m standing by my Christmas tree!

Have you ever thought about redesigning your wedding dress? Or know someone who might?

@theloomapp reached out to me and connected me with a local designer to completely revamp my wedding dress into something that I can now wear over and over.

The process has been so wonderful, it's got me excited to upcycle in the future! Any project whether it's an old shirt, a pair of ripped jeans, dying something stained or wanting to change the colour of a garment that no longer fits your colour pallette,  or a complete redesign like mine, @theloomapp will take care of everything ğŸ’œ

Thank you so much to @recondition.mcr for creating this beautiful set for me, I'm already planning so many different looks âœ¨ï¸

You can get 10% discounted off your first upcycle project with @theloomapp using code 'CHLOETHRIFTS'

Let's keep our clothes in circulation and not be afraid to try something new with what we already have hung up in our wardrobes â™»ï¸

The fashion choices we make can foster innovation, create local jobs, and sustain businesses that prioritize people and the planet over profit.

Slow fashion goals for the upcoming year âœ¨ï¸

I hope everyone's year is off to a slow and steady start! The new year marks an opportunity for many (like me) to reflect on the year before and think about setting new resolutions or intentions for the year ahead. This year I've decided to go for goals over resolutions, the difference being that goals can carry a fixed, achievable target rather than a less measurable mindset shift. Like last year, I'm also keeping it pretty easygoing and simple by setting myself a couple of goals that can be put in a diary to look forward to ticking off.

With that in mind, here are some slow fashion themed 'goals' in case helpful to guide the expert slow fashionistas or first time thrifters that want a couple of ideas to guide the start to the new year. 

My slow fashion goals for 2023 are to âœ¨ï¸ plan a flight-free trip abroad, âœ¨ï¸ book onto a sewing machine course and âœ¨ï¸ give away a couple of bits I'm not using in my flat on my local buy nothing group, Olio or FB marketplace, like old uni textbooks and soft furnishings. 

If you're a goal, resolution or intention setter, share yours below! âœ¨ï¸

A (sort of) sustainable guide to Oslo! 

I've shared below a non-exhaustive list of small, local and/or sustainable leaning spots that I visited in Oslo. Whilst the way I travel is by no means sustainable (which I'd like to explore more in future!! trains > planes etc.) I always like to focus my itinerary towards places like these:

1) Places to visit: @oslobadstuforening is a non-profit association that runs saunas in Oslo. We visited the Sukkerbiten sauna one morning and had a couple of dips in the fjord. It was a fun experience made even better by the friendly staff and views of the Opera House. It's also next to @fotografihuset an outdoor photography exhibition in its pilot phase. Another highlight was wandering round Frogner Park, home to 212 sculptures (including one very angry granite baby). It evoked some interesting reactions and I've since seen the sculptures described as reflecting "the cycle of human life".

2) Things to eat: @vippaoslo is a colourful food court on the edge of the fjord. It started as a space to bring together farmers, producers, chefs and people from around the world. Elsewhere, I found a new favourite snack in pÃ¸lse topped with potato salad. We visited @syverkiosken which is one of the last wooden hotdog kiosks in Oslo (but also enjoyed the convenience store version too). A special mention for all the waffles with raspberry jam eaten without catching a name.

3) Spots to drink: Oslo is spoilt for coffee and pastry fixes, especially on the fjord around BjÃ¸rvika. We also visited the @timwendelboe shop for some award winning coffee. The main drink of choice however was beer and we enjoy a few flights from some excellent taprooms, highlights being @grunerlokkabrygghus and @roor_oslo .

4) Where to thrift: A special moment was chancing upon the Sonsdagmarked whilst walking along the river, where I bought some wool mittens from the makers' market. Grunerlokka is a cool area home to the Birkelundenmarked which had more of a flea market vibe. Thanks to @welldresseddad for letting me know that (amongst other great tips) Uff and Fretex are the popular vintage / secondhand stores in the city. Whilst I didn't visit one, they were everywhere!

Being a 45-year-old physically disabled autistic woman with chronic illnesses, l often find myself struggling to figure out where I fit in. 

Navigating the online world has been challenging, as I feel caught between spaces that donâ€™t fully embrace me. In mainstream spaces, lâ€™m often seen as â€œtoo muchâ€â€”my experiences and complexities too far from the norm. Yet, even within the disabled community, I sometimes feel like an outsider, too â€œweirdâ€ or unconventional.

Where I do find acceptance, though, is among the neurodivergent crew, the fashion lovers, who seem to understand my quirks, my joy in self-expression, and my love for vintage sustainable fashion. Itâ€™s in these circles that I feel celebrated for my uniqueness, but the journey to truly feel at home online has been anything but straightforward.

Who else can relate?

Donâ€™t call me ğŸ¤£

As an autistic person, Iâ€™m obsessed with old plastic rotary phones and the satisfying clunky sounds they make. The weight of the receiver, the tactile feeling of turning the dial, and the distinct clicks create a sensory experience that brings me comfort. However, despite my love for these vintage phones, I canâ€™t actually answer one. The unpredictability of real-time conversations and the anxiety that comes with it is overwhelming for me, making phone calls something I avoid entirely. For me, itâ€™s not about using the phone to talk, but about the sensory joy it provides.

Secondhand September ğŸ—£ Tips for both the first timers and the expert thrifters â˜‘ï¸

Secondhand September was launched by @oxfamgb back in 2019. It's a campaign that seeks to encourage people to buy only secondhand items for one month. It's a great opportunity to try out secondhand for the first time or refocus your efforts and reflect on your existing shopping habits. Whether you pledge to take part for the whole month or give secondhand a go just once, you'd become part of a growing movement of people shopping preloved over new. 

Buying secondhand keeps clothes out of landfill (according to Oxfam, this stands at 11 million garments per week in the UK) and decreases demand for new clothes, reducing the impact of the fashion industry on the lives of garment workers and on the planet. 

I'll be sharing tips all month, but here's some ideas to get started for the first time thrifters and the experts among us! 

Please do share your ideas in the comments too and let me know if you're planning to take part!

A secondhand era is here â€¼ï¸

People have been shopping secondhand for years - way before I did, way before it was 'cool', but to see it go big in mainstream media is huge!

 I started my ig page around 3 years ago and over that time I've been an on and off @loveisland fan. I don't think I'd have believed it if 3 years ago someone told me that the islanders would be styled in clothes from @ebay let alone that one of the finalists @tashaghouri would become a preloved ambassador for one of the biggest resale sites. To see this play out alongside @ekinsuofficial signing one of the biggest deals that Love Island has seen with Oh Polly only makes this news more interesting - we're seeing secondhand and new playing on the same field, which to me is one of the best ways to reach those that haven't considered it yet. 

The secondhand clothing market is expected to grow to twice the size of fast fashion by 2030 (thredup) and it's moments like this that make this sound realistic. Meanwhile Pimp My Ride Uk is coming back with @imladyleshurr and in partnership with @wrenchstudios and @ebay_uk, putting upcycling and secondhand at the centre. Preloved is popping up all over, with Bella Hadid in vintage Versace at Cannes and Olivia Rodrigo on the red carpet in vintage Jean Paul Gaultier. It's in our museums and galleries, with @toast partnering with @somersethouse at the Eternally Yours exhibition, celebrating creative reuse and repair. The @britishsewingbee has featured reduce, reuse, recycle episodes. I wonder what will be next -  Home Reno shows using secondhand, more style departments on film sets sourcing preloved? It's exciting times for secondhand and slow fashion and lifestyle!!

Secondhand forever > Secondhand September ğŸ¤ 

Secondhand September is the best time of year to celebrate and try out shopping secondhand (thanks to @oxfamgb !), but as the month draws to a close I wanted to share some facts that keep me shopping #secondhandfirst beyond this month: 

â–ªï¸ Buying one cotton shirt produces the same emissions as driving a car 35 miles (WRAP)
â–ªï¸ Garments are the second highest at-risk product for modern slavery (Fashion Revolution's Impact Report, 2019)
â–ªï¸ The average consumer now buys 60% more clothing than they did 15 years ago (The UN Alliance for Sustsinable Fashion)
â–ªï¸ Less than 1% of textiles and clothes are genuinley recycled into new textiles and clothes (The Ellen MacArthur Foundation)
â–ªï¸Extending the life of clothes by just 9 months would save Â£5 billion in resources used to supply, launder and dispose of clothing (WRAP) 

I say #secondhandfirst because whilst I don't shop 100% secondhand, any purchase I make I consider first and wait to see if I could buy it secondhand. It's facts like these that make me realise how significant the small switches can make when done by more people ğŸ’š

#DifferentAidsForDifferentDays

As a fabulously disabled person, I use different mobility aids depending on the situation and my physical needs at the time. 

Around the house & on flat surfaces, I might walk unaided if I feel stable and comfortable, but on uneven terrain or during periods of fatigue, a walking stick or rollator offers extra support and safety. In more challenging environments or for longer distances, a wheelchair helps conserve energy, prevents pain & injury. I also use crutches around the house when Iâ€™m unable to weight bear but these can be tough on my shoulder joints. And I use my beloved stair lift daily. 

Each aid allows me to navigate the world more independently and adjust to the varying demands of my body and surroundings. Mobility aids give me freedom!

Slow fashion is not just about *what* you buy, but *how* you take care of the clothes you already own ğŸ§µğŸª¡

It's easier to say than put into practise, but your clothes, wallet and the planet will thank you for doing so. 

My @yesterdaysbabevintage blazer bought a while back needed a spruce up after lots of wears, so I dropped it in my local dry cleaners for a clean, press and a small mend and as if by magic, I immediately starting wearing it again when it returned home ğŸ’Ÿ

Here's to hopefully not buying another swimsuit for a good few years â›±ï¸

I've not got any statistics to share on how wasteful the leisure swimwear industry is, but from my own experience it's not been great. For every beach holiday I've had as an adult I've been scrabbling to find swimwear that is fit to last and that I find flattering. I think the key is to find something that you will use year after year, particularly for those based in the UK who I assume (like me) don't often find the opportunity to wear a swimsuit. That could be buying new, buying custom-made (thinking @slowgarments) or even secondhand (looking at @one_scoop_store that has loads in stock!) 

For me, I've settled on @you.swim. Not an ad, but thought I'd share some thoughts if they're on your list too!

@you.swim has been on my radar for a while - I like the colour ways of the swim suits and seeing a more diverse representation of models on the website. I was initially put off by the slightly steeper price than I'd usually look to pay and the fact the swimsuits are 'one size', which if Brandy Melville is anything to go off, is never really 'one size fits all' and more 'one size only'. I found a few people online that had similar dimensions to me that rated it, so I went ahead and ordered one - its genuinely the best bikini I've ever bought for fit and quality and I've just ordered a second for an upcoming beach holiday.

I can't speak for all on the 'one size' piece - YouSwim's FAQs say they fit UK size 6-18, which doesn't represent all sizes (I understand YouSwim acknowledge this and are working on extending sizing, but I haven't seen anything further just yet). For me, the 'one size' point is more compelling in a longevity sense - the bikinis are marketed as being able to adapt and change with your body throughout fluctuations in life, which aligns with my desire to buy a bikini that sees multiple holidays over several years and not just the one. 

Any other swimwear brands you rate? Let me know â›±ï¸

Shopping vintage alongside new - thoughts? 

This jumper has been in heavy circulation in my wardrobe recently, and I picked it up from @reformation Shoreditch. I knew Reformation as a brand that sold vintage style classic pieces and that took a more sustainable approach to business. I've read that the clothing has a focus on natural materials and Reformation seek to make their products and stores carbon neutral. I'd never actually been to one of the stores or bought the clothes, until a couple of week's ago when I popped into the Shoreditch branch to browse an interesting looking collection near the window. Reformation began as a brand selling vintage clothes in LA in 2009, and the collection I saw in the Shoreditch store was a vintage collection sat alongside the new Reformation pieces. 

I'm seeing more and more brands offering preloved and vintage collections alongside new too. From the @theofficialselfridges edits to the curated collection in @reformation, I think it's a great way to present secondhand as a legitimate option against new. It also might reach some shoppers who are otherwise put off by the more grungey reputation of preloved fashion. 

But not all brands have received praise for introducing preloved resale into their model - Pretty Little Thing launched its reGain app, allowing shoppers to 'turn unwanted clothes into discounts' off your next PLT purchase with the aim of reducing the number of clothes that end up in landfill. It's not clear where the clothes go once you send them in, and it's arguable that the model ultimately feeds the same problem by encouraging people to go and buy more clothes. Perhaps if PLT reserved the new app only for peer to peer resale on PLT items and not in return for discounts off new, the model might go some way towards reducing waste. 

So, what are your thoughts on resale alongside new? Is it all greenwashing, or is it a welcome extension of the preloved market into the spaces so far reserved for new?

caption:
Buying less is much easier to crack once you work out what to buy in the first place ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

Whether you buy new (and get presented with countless micro-trend cycles throughout the year) or buy second hand (and have affordable fashion at your fingertips) it's just so easy to buy too many clothes. 

When I started shopping almost entirely secondhand three years ago, my clothing consumption slowly went up as I found myself surrounded by endless options in new places, in charity shops and resell apps. Secondhand fashion is a great way to experiment with style, but it led to my wardrobe becoming overfilled and underworn. In the last six months I've slowed it right down, practicing my own tips I post on here and thinking hard about the difference between admiring clothes (and putting the card away) to actually buying and adding something to my wardrobe.

 I'm now only buying the clothes that fit my personal style, which means often scrolling past things I like, but wouldn't wear that often. The past three months in particular I've had the same few pieces on a loop. I'm less interested in buying more when the clothes I'm wearing tick the style boxes.

I find it hard to describe personal style, but for me it often looks like:

1. Boxy fits (wide leg trousers, high neck tops) 2. natural colours (blues, greens, browns) 3. and some good checks and leopard prints. 

Spend some time thinking critically about what you actually want to wear, and follow that through to what you actually buy. It'll make buying less and repeating more so much easier !!

No greenwashing bulls**t here 

Iâ€™ve always been a lover of small fashion brands for so many reasons and even more so when their products are sustainably sourced and ethically made. Recently Iâ€™ve seen a lot about brands greenwashing, especially high street ones - misinforming their buyers to make them believe that they are making environmentally friendly fashion choices by shopping with them and that just feels so wrong. So it felt like a great idea to share some of my favourite small brands who do slow sustainable fashion so well. 

I adore all of these brands and their makers so much and Iâ€™ve been lucky enough to meet some of these lovely ladies too. They all use existing, deadstock, recycled, generally unloved materials and bring them to life as new pieces of really special, and often one of a kind, clothing. 

A quick round up: I love this new concept from @lydiabolton_ where all her creations this year are rental instead of purchase plus she also does amazing scrunchie/bow making workshops which I would highly recommend. Laura's handmade @themarconcourtproject dress designs are so iconic and they have pockets ğŸ™Œ and I love Emilyâ€™s @medley_vintage Lily blouses so much I own two (you can see both here, the second one is a bespoke design we created together). SJ brought my tartan/giant collar/satin bow blouse vision to life with this one of a kind @madebysjp piece and Nicci @second_stories__ has the best range of slogan caps ever as well as an amazing curation of vintage and reworked clothing too. She has just started a line of made to order linen pieces which are perfect for summer. 

Are you already a sustainable fashion lover? If not hopefully this convinces you, look how many incredible brands and beautiful pieces there are out there â™»ï¸

More cake than clothes pictures this Christmas break, which sets the tone for some 2022 intentions:

1. buy less and track buys, including secondhand - secondhand over-consumption is still over- consumption

2. spend (and make the time for) at least 30 minutes of free time a day doing something screen free that I enjoy - I took up a bit of knitting this week and whilst I'm pretty bad at it, it's enjoyable nonetheless 

3. learn a few new things outside of work - I've so far signed up to a weekend language class

Micro-trends: What are they, and how can we quit them? 

We buy on average 60% more clothes than we did in the early 2000s, but we're not necessarily wearing them more. The number of clothes that end up in landfill is shocking.

The problem is perpetuated further by the growth of micro-trends, and our exposure to them on social media. Whilst once trends spanned whole decades, they now last a matter of months or a couple of years.

Swipe to learn more about micro-trends, and for four tips on how to quit>

How to find your personal style ğŸŒ» 

Did you know that between 2013 and 2018, clothing utilisation (the average time you wear a garment before it is no longer used) decreased by 36%? Swipe for some quick tips on how to counteract this!

I partly blame this on the increase of micro-trends - the quirky styles that fill up the "new-in" section for a couple of weeks before disappearing and hitting the re-sell sites. They become like collector's items for no good reason, and it's certainly something I've bought into before, without even wanting to wear. Avoiding trends and wearing (and understanding) what truly makes you feel great helps to build a long-lasting wardrobe that you want to outfit repeat every season. This dress makes me feel like it, and it's how all clothes should - but i'm still working on it!

Autism & loneliness 

I spend a lot of time alone. I live rural with closest friends & family hours away, I canâ€™t drive nor leave the house on my own. My husband travels often and during these periods I often go days without even talking to anyone irl.  And I know you are provably thinking â€œoh no Rue thatâ€™s terribleâ€. But Iâ€™m not lonely and for most of my life I felt broken for feeling this way.  But Iâ€™m not. I just do life differently. 

I like doing my own thing. These fashion outfits I share with yall are my autistic hyper fixation. My specialist interest. Itâ€™s what I think about every day for large parts of my day. Researching, planning, buying/selling and just obsessing about clothing. Vintage, secondhand & sustainable in particular. It takes up a lot of my time and if I donâ€™t get time/energy to indulge in this it has a negative impact on my mental health. Being autistic is complicated. Being physically disabled is complicated. Being chronically ill sucks. But fashion opens up the world for me to enjoy it all more and participate socially at a level that doesnâ€™t stress me out. I have enough in my plate already. So this disability pride letâ€™s celebrate the differences we might not like for ourselves but that work for others ğŸ¤£ there is no right way to live life. 

Image description: rue in a series of colourful vintage 69s or vintage style outfits having a wee pose to her self and loving every second of her alone time.

3 outfit changes later, it was always going to end up being a puff sleeve top and blazer situation ğŸ”†

My go-to evening-out outfit has been a bit of sleeve and flare *drama* for a couple of years now. In a way, it feels like one of my style uniforms. In "A Life Less Thowaway", Tara Button talks about dressing up for the roles you play in life. She highlights that feeling of having nothing to wear, and suggests it might stem from not already having the 'costumes' in your wardrobe you need to play those roles. Button suggests making a list of all the roles you play, from the obvious to the obscure, and thinking about how you want to feel and be perceived in those roles. It's important to have your costumes ready, and the whole exercise is ultimately intended to help you buy less, choose well, and avoid the pressures exerted by trends. 

 Whilst I've cracked my 'goes for dinner and maybe a few drinks' uniform (lol), I'm still working on some of my others, especially post pandemic office wear!

Do you have any style uniforms you can rely on? ğŸ”†

caption:
You might be thinking: â€œBea, what do you mean? I know that. I know Iâ€™m not an influencer.â€ But do you, though? Because the only way to â€œkeep upâ€ with every trend or new aesthetic that shows up on this app is if you do it for a living.

Hereâ€™s the thing about most influencers: Most of what they show you is gifted, and everything they buy is to make money. They wear it in a video, convince you that itâ€™s â€œviralâ€ and the first place our brains go is, OK, if I want to be like her, I need to go out and buy everything she has.

But listen, sis: There is no serum. Thereâ€™s no shake. Thereâ€™s no green juice. Thereâ€™s no handbag or pair of shoes that is ever going to turn you into another person. Going to their Amazon storefronts and LTK pages, and buying everything there to create a carbon copy of someone elseâ€™s life isnâ€™t going to make you them. Thereâ€™s only one of them and thereâ€™s one of me and thereâ€™s one of you. And we all have to start realizing that no matter how much money we spend and how much stuff we buy, itâ€™s never going to turn us into someone that weâ€™re ultimately not.

Hereâ€™s what weâ€™re going to do: Weâ€™re going to get a grip. Weâ€™re going to close out all of our tabs. Weâ€™re going to empty out all of our carts. Weâ€™re going to stop trying to buy things that ultimately canâ€™t be bought. Weâ€™re going to stop trying to be someone that weâ€™re ultimately not ğŸ’šğŸŒ¿

What are we going to wear? Something we already have! ğŸ’š

Replacing that worry of "What am I going to wear for X event" with the feeling of knowing you can just outfit repeat, is pretty liberating. Swipe to see when I've worn this outfit before. 

It clicked for me around 2 years ago when I was looking forward to another festival. Around a week before, I got the outfit panic, so headed down to Westfield to scrabble something together with my part time job wages and absolutely no creative direction. After about 50 laps of the shopping centre, hunger and stress setting in, and no outfits I liked, I knew it was the last straw. No more Westfield laps, no more new clothes for the sake of newness. I'd spend 10 minutes going through what I already had, or asking a friend to borrow, and would spend more time getting excited for a day in the sun with my friends. Once you give up scrolling the "New in" sections of fashion stores, there's no going back! 

Have you had a similar penny drop moment? 

For what we have left of this summer, try outfit repeating for your next event ğŸ’š

Second hand meets a new staple ğŸ¤

The staple: A new "goes with everything" coat bought in the Boxing Day sales. After a sustaina-fail trying to buy a secondhand wool coat online pre-Christmas (the measurements were all wrong and it turned up smelling like smoke), I felt this new one was the better choice on this occasion. Im a big advocate for #secondhandfirst, and buying less and buying used is my preferred choice, but i've come to realise that sometimes the most sustainable thing might be the one you'll wear the most and will last the longest. 

The second hand: An everyday cross body bought off Depop. I was looking for a bag that I could pick up and go out with everyday and would last me years. I looked across Ebay and Vestiare Collective but eventually landed back on Depop with this second hand All Saints one. The seller had such a detailed listing, wrapped it in bubble wrap and sent the dust bag. 10/10 sustaina-win.

Adjusted these trousers and then wore them 4/5 days this week ğŸŒ¥

I found these tailored balloon leg trousers on @depop in my size, but when they arrived, they didn't quite fit how I wanted on the waist. A couple of YouTube videos later, I learnt how to take them in slightly by pulling in the back seam. I wanted to retain the volume in the leg, so I tapered the adjustment from the waist down to the crotch seam. Swipe to see the process!

Learning some simple hacks on how to adjust and tailor clothes of your size to better fit you is a great way to make your clothes more wearable, and for me, ultimately encourages less new purchases ğŸŒ¥

N.B I wouldn't advocate for thrifting clothes outside your size range and adjusting them to fit you. Unless in a clearance area and saving from landfill, this could limit availability of second hand clothes for other people. I'd always stick to my sizes, and would only adjust from there.

Let me know if you've learnt any adjustment hacks!

Slow fashion evening wear âœ¨

Some recent evening wear looks put together with second hand, old and sustainable fashion. Which is your favourite - 1, 2 or 3? âœ¨

Now, I still love find a 'new to me' second hand piece for the odd occasion, but for most of my evenings out, I try to reinvent something I've already got - It's pretty liberating!

Postcards from a sunny weekend ğŸ”†

I was up in sunny Merseyside this weekend catching up with an old friend where I grew up. This friend introduced me to charity shopping way back, and she definitely trained me up into the thrifter I am today! 

She showed me round some local spots I hadn't been to before, including the Green Community Shop & Centre in Oxton. It's a non-profit community shop run by local volunteers, and one volunteer kindly invited us into the back yard for tea and pastries mid shop (explaining the absolute joy in pic 1). It's a great initiative, focusing on sustainability, co-operation and local participation. More places like this! I'd love to get involved in something similar in East London.

These shorts used to be jeans âœ‚ï¸

Clothes should serve a purpose to take up in space in your wardrobe, or they might be better used by someone else. I bought these jeans last summer, and the fit had always been a bit too relaxed in the leg for me. When I found some better fitting white jeans this summer, they had to find a new place.

City style shorts have become more popular this year, and rather than buying new shorts to try it, I upcycled my old jeans. Using another favourite pair of shorts as a guide, I cut across with scissors and distressed the hem by pulling out a few threads. I then dropped off the remaining fabric at a local textile recycling box, and my #newtome shorts were ready to go.

These shorts are a great length and fit for hot summer days strolling or cycling around the city. Before you get rid of clothes, think first if they could serve you in a different way.

Have you upcycled something recently? Tell me below!

How well do you know the origin of your clothes? ğŸŒ±

Knowing where my clothes have come from is important to me, particularly when buying new. 

Sustainability is on very much on the agenda for consumers and retailers alike. Whilst I'm pleased to see it, the reality is that this becomes a trend, and an obvious way to attract customers. As a consumer, it's hard to wade through and distinguish what is and isn't legitimately sustainable. With a lack of universal standards and regulation, it all becomes a bit of a maze to shop new and know for sure that there's no evidence of unethical practices anywhere on the supply chain.

That's why I'm so thrilled to find shops which do the work for you. A couple of week's ago I stopped at the @knowtheorigin pop-up in Islington. Quite quickly I noticed that the shop stocked some of my favourite ethical brands, from @ilkandernie to @girlfriendcollective, as well as plastic free beauty and sustainable homewares. I'd been looking for a summer jacket, and picked up this white organic cotton one from @thinkingmu. The team at the store were eager to chat about @knowtheorigin' s story, and about the brands they stocked. On the website, I can see what product standards this jacket meets, exactly where in the world the jacket was cut, sewn, and the materials supplied, and what the jacket is made from. It should always be that easy!

@knowtheorigin launched in 2016 with the aim of building a new supply chain in the fashion industry. A few years later, the brand is home to a collection of certified brands, setting high standards for sustainability. In a world of greenwashing, it's a great place to buy clothes that meet a set of clear ethical standards ğŸŒ± (Not an ad - just love to see it!)

Less is more? ğŸŒ¾

When I think "Less is more", it's not in the detail of an outfit, or how many accessories should be put on (sorry Chanel). It's more about how many clothes, and how much choice, we have in our wardrobes.

Last week I was away from London on a staycation with a suitcase of clothes. Having a smaller selection of my wardrobe that I'd curated in advance, meant that I had less choice, but  was more creative in how I put my outfits together. This is something you can practice at home too. By encouraging yourself to choose from less clothes to make an outfit, makes you realise how far each individual piece can go. It certainly makes me feel less inclined to reach for my phone to search for new clothes online. 

Here's how I'd emulate the same experience at home:

1. Set aside a rail or section of your wardrobe with a selection of clothes you want to wear and style that week. Treat it like a capsule wardrobe.

2. When you've worn an item in your wardrobe recently, turn the coat hanger hook backwards. Next time you go in, reach for the clothes on the hangers facing you, that you've not worn recently.

3. Store away the clothes that are out of season, or you aren't feeling at the moment. Having smaller choice to select from might make you feel more decisive in your outfit decision making.

4. Change up and rewear your outfits by adding different layers and accessories. Here I changed up my dress with a vintage blazer and some new sunnies.

Let me know if you have any tips to emulate that capsule wardrobe experience!

A dream dress â˜ï¸

This weekend I stopped at my parent's house in Manchester, and made an obligatory visit to @noodboutique in Chorlton. The shop is a small independent boutique, stocking a hand picked selection of timeless pieces, all of which align to their ethical and sustainable values. It's a lovely shop, and such a pleasure to take your time trying on and browsing in there.

I often talk about the different ways there are to 'do' slow fashion, and one of them, I believe, is to buy new, but slowly and thoughtfully. My Mum has a small curated wardrobe of high quality pieces, and only adds a small amount to that each year. Compared to my usual second hand shopping habits, my Mum's consumption of fashion is much more thought-through. It teaches me to always re-evaluate if I should add more clothes to my wardrobe. 

@noodboutique is one of my Mum's favourites, so I've recently started stopping by whenever I've visited home. This time I found this shirred maxi dress, having seen my Mum wearing it in another colour. I've been searching for a sleeper, maxi, shirred, puff sleeved dress for a while on the second hand sites, and to no avail. I even ordered one, and when the sizing came up wrong, resold it. This dress fits so well, and would be great to wear throughout the year. The brand is @sugarhillbrighton, and after doing some research pre-purchase, I found that 10% of their profits go to charity organisations, their productions are kept small, and all their suppliers are signed up to the Ethical Trading Initiative. These are a couple of reasons why buying new from this brand worked for me! 

After a couple of purchases recently, it'll be a no-buy month or a few for me! 

Outfit~
Dress: @sugarhillbrighton via @noodboutique 
Boots: 1 year old
Coat: @depop

Slow fashion is all about the versatility for me â™»ï¸

I've worn this linen jumpsuit with a blouse to the office, but yesterday I wore it to stomp through the countryside. Whenever I introduce clothes into my wardrobe, I want to be able to wear them in multiple ways, and this pinafore jumpsuit ticks those boxes! 

Yesterday we went for a long walk from Alnmouth to Felton along the river, stopping for brunch before heading over to Alnwick. We popped by Barter Books, one of the largest second hand bookshops in the UK, and then wandered round the centre. A charity shop might have been popped into, mainly drawn in by the display which seemed entirely dedicated to faux animal print. No clothes bought, but it's always good to say hello to the northern charity shops.

Outfit~

Tshirt: @vinted

Well itâ€™s 1st November and time for @slowfashionchallenge , day 1, introduction. 
I recently did an intro for something else so apologies if I am repeating myself.
My name is Marcia, Iâ€™m 72 years old and my day job is running my antique shop, Smoking Monkey Antiques in Suffolk.
I make most of my clothes using old textiles and what I donâ€™t make I generally buy secondhand. I personally think the best way to avoid being dragged into the fast fashion world is to develop your own style rather than follow trendsâ€¦plus this way is considerably more fun.
Slow fashion is something I feel very strongly about for many reasons. The pollution and waste produced by the fast fashion industry is totally unacceptable. These huge issues can seem overwhelming but I think we have to consider the phrase â€œthink globally, act locallyâ€. None of us can take on all the problems in the world but we can change the way we behave and encourage others to do the same. 
With this in mind some friends and I have recently started an instagram community called @curtainstocouture . The aim is to encourage a community that stitches using reclaimed fabrics, slowing down and breathing life into old textiles.
I think itâ€™s important not to guilt trip but to encourage by example and most importantly learn from one another.
This coat dress is one of my favourite patterns from the Japanese sewing book Stylish Wraps, it is made from five thrifted cafe tablecloths. I made the frock from a 1970s cotton twill bought from a friend. The necklaces, earrings, tee shirt and bag are all thrifted.

Summer in vintage, second hand and new ğŸŒ»

You don't have to be perfect to be more sustainable.

 I wonder if people would try out sustainable and second hand fashion more if they didn't feel the pressure to be perfect. We're often pushed to take an all or nothing approach to our lifestyle choices, but it's important to recognise that the small changes do count. 

I remember this more whenever I wear an outfit that's sustainable in different ways. These shorts are a vintage find from last year, the top an old second hand piece, and the hat bought new a few weeks ago. Who knew bucket hats came in small, medium and large, and that my head wouldn't necessarily fit all hats? ğŸ˜¬ Being able to pop into a shop and try on meant I just bought one hat, once, and not a couple of second hand hats, to later resell or donate because they didn't fit.

If you buy all new, and one piece second hand, or all new, but have a small, curated wardrobe, or enjoy regular charity shop hauls, you're always doing something to reimagine your clothing consumption habits. There's time here for all of those, and they should all be celebrated!

Outfit~

Top: @depop
Shorts: @beyondretro

A lot of people would be surprised by how easy it is to shop secondhand, either from charity shops, vintage shops or online, thereâ€™s so much great stuff out there, barely worn and stylish. If you canâ€™t find what you need secondhand, shop from the vast number of amazing sustainable brands available now ğŸŒ¿

The real moto here though, is to shop less and be more mindful - think about how much wear youâ€™ll get from that piece, what is made of (favour natural materials) and if you really want it or youâ€™re just falling for a marketing trick, because if you love your clothes youâ€™ll cherish them and theyâ€™ll last longer, resulting in a much more sustainable way to consume fashion.

#AutisticStimming 

For as long as I can remember Iâ€™ve been obsessed with curtain tassels. With alll tassels and fringing. If I see it, I gotta touch it. Iâ€™m very much a tactile sensory seeker with almost all fabrics but the pattern spotters amongst you will  have noticed how often Iâ€™ve worn curtain tassels as necklaces over the years.  They are a kind of stim toy for me, something I use to fidget with to help regulate myself when I need too or for joy. 

I also use finger movements to stim but as this made me feel like I stood out more I learned to replace it publicly with items like this. Or pieces I kept in my pockets that I liked to rub or sniff if nobody was looking â˜ºï¸

Do you have a favourite stim toy? Recommendations for tactile ones greatly appreciated?

Here are 5 questions that you should ask yourself before you shop for clothes, to become a more responsible and mindful shopper.

1 - Is this an impulse buy? Buying something just on a whim, without giving it a second thought, usually results in Buyerâ€™s remorse, making them feel guilty about their purchase.

2 - Is it ethically made? Suspiciously low prices are liked because someone else is paying the price. Most likely, the workers who made your clothes are being exploited and/or the materials used are cheap and a burden on the environment.

3 - How long will it last? Opt for garments that endure over time, resisting the temptation of low-quality items that seem affordable but quickly wear out.

4 - Can I buy this secondhand? Thrifting can benefit you and the environment in a big way, despite your lifestyle. Youâ€™ll always find great deals for high-quality clothing from brand names that you already know and trust if you opt to thrift.

5 -  Will I still want this next season? If we follow fashion trends and always buy clothes that are trending at the moment, we end up discarding clothes every season, having to recreate our whole wardrobe again and again.

Remember, being a mindful shopper doesnâ€™t have to be challenging. Each purchase, no matter how small, carries significant impact ğŸŒ #sustainabilityuk #sustainablefashion #sustyvibes #sustainableclothing

What is an  #AmbulatoryWheelchairUser ? â™¿ï¸

I am! I can move my legs & I walk short distances on flat surfaces. I can stand briefly in my heels. I use an electric wheelchair. I use walking sticks. I use a rollator. I use a stair lift. I use an all terrain wheelchair because I live in a mountain range. It be heckinâ€™ hilly. 

Iâ€™m also #autistic. I wore each of these epic outfits briefly today for some #dopaminedressing and to indulge in the #autisticjoy of my #specialistinterest. Then I was back into soft, baggy, cotton tee and big knickers with nothing else touching me for the comfort â˜ºï¸ 

Tomorrow I will rest as part of #pacing for my #chronicillness

#visabilityfordisability #disabledrepresentation #disabilityawareness #secondhandfashion #secondhandstyle #babewithamobilityaid #differentaidsfordifferentdays #disability #disabled #fashion #disabledfashion #disabledcontentcreator

Repeat with me: sustainable fashion is not expensive! And trying to excuse your need for â€œtrendyâ€ clothes at the cost of someone elseâ€™s welfare is just vile. While itâ€™s true that some sustainable brands may have higher prices due to the cost of using eco-friendly materials or ethical production practices, there are many ways to make sustainable fashion accessible to EVERYONE.

Firstly, shopping second-hand is a great way to embrace sustainable fashion at a very accessible cost. Many second-hand stores even offer online shopping options, making it easier to access sustainable fashion. I love @thrift_plus_uk @reliked @oxfamgb and @prewornltd but letâ€™s not forget @depop @vinted and @ebay_uk ğŸ–¤

Another way to make sustainable fashion affordable is to choose versatile, high-quality pieces that will last a long time. Investing in well-made clothing that can be worn in different ways and for different occasions can actually save money in the long run, as you wonâ€™t need to constantly replace low-quality, fast-fashion items. 

Sustainable fashion is NOT about buying eco-friendly clothing, but also about reducing overall consumption and waste. By making intentional choices about what you buy and how you wear it, you can make a big impact on both your wallet and the environment ğŸŒ¿âœ¨ğŸ¤

#sustainablefashion #slowfashion #boycottfastfashion #fashionrevolution #whomademyclothes

caption:
You ever do a really dumb thing knowing full well at the time youâ€™ll regret it but do it anywayâ€¦

Well hereâ€™s a pic of me wearing wearing a glorious gold secondhand gown after I had just crawled along the ground on my hands and knees and dragged myself back up into my wheelchair. 

Nope I didnâ€™t fall out. I had one of those momentarily thoughts of â€œIâ€™ll be fineâ€ as I stood in those skyscraper heels to put my camera tripod in front of me to take my piccie. I was not fine. I can only stand briefly in those heels on flat surfaces. I went down like a sack of potatoes. But carried on anyway because I get sick of #ehlersdanlossyndrome danlos and other crap getting in my way ğŸ¤ª

And today as I lie in bed thinking why is my shoulder blade falling out at the back after both my ankles have been killing me for days, my hip muscle kept giving way yesterday and both knees kept giving way as I lay in bed yesterday AND I have elbow pain, which is rarer for me so feels insulting. This is a lot more symptoms than Iâ€™m used to dealing with on the daily now with EDS. Then I saw this pic and last weekend came flooding back. 

Swipe for the pic of me today rueing the day I pulled a rue as Iâ€™ve done so many times before when I think â€˜Iâ€™ll be okâ€™ arghhh. I will be, itâ€™ll just take a minute. And welcome to a lesson for #ehlersdanlossyndromeawareness month. Protect your joints. Donâ€™t do daft shit because it will be quicker and you can ğŸ¤£

Wait till my husband sees this and says â€œfuck sake Rueâ€ and puts his hand to his head in loving exasperation!

Getting ready for a peacefully psychedelic sixties summer ğŸŒ¸

Moving to the countryside was the best thing ever for my mental health. I donâ€™t cope with people. We chose the least accessible house because it was high up a hill with no one out front so I had absolute peace. It was worth the trade off.

The truth is I canâ€™t cope seeing anyone unexpectedly. Even if I know and like you. My body needs time to heal from the constant pain and stress itâ€™s under and sitting out here alone is what works for me. And Iâ€™m really lucky to live here.

Secondhand Susty Queen ğŸ‘‘

Rewearing pieces because Iâ€™m a proud #OutfitRepeater I bought each of them secondhand but who knows how many people owned them before me. Do we have a term for that yet? 

Iâ€™m thrifty but not a thrifter as charity shops donâ€™t tend to be accessible to me as a wheelchair user with no ramps and lack of space. 

Iâ€™m a vintage and antique hunter and love the huge indoor/outdoor markets selling troves of treasures. I can sniff a good  textile piece out amongst the jumble if it all. 

And I love modern too but prefer sustainable, ethical, small brand businesses with big hearts â™¥ï¸ 

But mostly Iâ€™m an online shopper. A bed dweller. Preferring to peruse your old stuff you no longer want through secondhand market places and put my pennies straight to your pocket and prevent clothing going to landfill which is where lots of donated clothes end up now. 

A #SustyFashion connoisseur
